div.p: THE HAPPY SLAVE, A NOVEL. In three Parts Compleat.
Tranlated from the French.
By a Peron of Quality.
LONDON, Printed for Gilbert Cownly, at the Popes Head in the Lower-walk of the New-Exchange in the Strand. 1686.

div.head: To the Right Honourable, THOMAS Earl of OSSORY, Baron of MOOR PARK, One of the Lords of His Majeties Mot Honourable Privy Council, Knight of the Noble Order of the Garter, &c.
div.p:
NOthing was wanting to compleat the Happines of this Fortunate Slave, but to fall into the hands of o Generous a Patron as your Lordhip. And I who had undertaken to furnih him, was willing to find him one o qualified, that he might have reaon to be well pleaed with my Choice. To whom then could I
with more Reaon Addres my elf for making this Preent, than to a Lord, who by Excellent Qualities, as well as Eminent Birth, every day gains Slaves and Creatures to himelf. To atisfie any of the truth of what I ay, they need not make a particular enquiry, or hearken after the Publick Attetations of this Kingdom. The Fame of your Glory extends beyond England; there is not in Europe a Court, where it hath not arrived, to gain you the Heart and Admiration of the bet. But, my Lord, to know your Merit more perfectly, we need only conider the particular eteem always had for you by the greatet and mot dicerning Monarch in the World; the choice he hath made of your Peron for the greatet Employments of War, and the mot important Negotiations of Peace; the weight and tres he
lays on your Advice, and the confidence wherewith he relies on the clearnes of your Judgment, and greatnes of your Capacity in his Council. How fair a Field, my Lord, are your Praies to enlarge on, were my Faculties proportionable to my Subject, or my Offerings of value anwerable to the Dignity of the Peron they are made to, but the Enterprize is too vat and too difficult for uch an Author as I; and your Glory tands o ure in that univeral eteem the whole World hath for you, that it hath no need of new Elogies or Panegyricks. It becomes me better to tudy your Pleaure: The Happy Slave hath an impatient deire to entertain your leiure hours with the Relation of his Adventures. And if he prove o happy, as not to dipleae you, I hall eteem it the highet piece of good Fortune
he hath met with in his Life; at leat, I believe he cannot deire any thing with greater paion, unles it be, that he who hath taken the Liberty to preent him to you, may with all due repect ubcribe himelf,

closer.signed: Your mot Humble, and mot Obedient Servant, S. Bremond.

div.head: Advertiement.
div.p:
THE Book I Publih carce deerves an Advertiement. But that I give you, is not to bepeak the Criticks in my favour. I cannot believe any Peron of Wit will exercie his Faculty on a Trifle, which perhaps I have pent les time to Compoe, than he mut to cenure. But 'tis becaue ome Perons having mall kindnes for an Author, have been pleaed heretofore to comment on my Tables, to make tories of my tories, and to tretch my fancy to conjectures which never came into my Head: It were eaie for me to jutifie my elf in this particular, if it were deired; but I conceive my manner of proceeding hath ufficiently done it, to Dedicate it to one of the Principal Lords of the Kingdom, a Book, uch as they make my former, by their trange interpretations to be, and to put my Name to it, was it not the way to gain my elf Enemies, and utterly ruine me? I have
committed faults in my time, but never of this nature. Therefore I declare to the Publick, and epecially to thoe who buie themelves in penetrating into other mens intentions, that under the literal ene of my Tales there is not hid any Allegorical meaning, that when I peak of the Turks and of Africk, I have not any Ideas in Europe or any other Nation, and that they will make me think quite otherwie than I think, if they make me peak any otherwie than I peak, if the Intrigues or Adventures I write of, have ome conformity to thoe of our times, I am not to anwer for it: 'Tis the fault of Chance and not mine. There are o many in Love, that though Love takes infinite ways, they can hardly avoid meeting ometimes: were Writers confined to entertain you only with things rare and extraordinary, they would be oon drawn dry, and all their tories quickly exhauted; the Reader is intreated to do me Jutice herein, and not pay me with ingratitude for the Preents I make him of my Toys: This hall be followed by a Second Part, where the Hitory of Laura, who hall bear the principal part in it, hall be matter of Gallantry, and far exceed this of the Sultanes.

div.head: THE HAPPY SLAVE, A Novel.
div.p: AFRICK, for ome Ages, hath pat for a part of the World, where the People were no les Cruel and Savage than the Lions and Tygers that fill the Dearts of that Countrey: But ince the dicovery of Love there, it hath appear'd, that as Love grows in all Countreys, o Barbary it elf hath nothing of Barbarous but the Name. To verifie this, I hall entertain you with a piece of Gallantry acted there, which may jutifie what I affirm.

Count ALEXANDER, a young Roman Lord, very coniderable for Etate, (but more for Birth and Parts,) had carce appear'd to act his part on
the great Theatre of the World, but he found himelf pret by his Relations to Marry: He was handom, high pirited, and witty, as thoe of Old Rome, but addicted to Pleaure, as thoe of the New; humourome, and wholly given up to the puruit of his Fancy and Inclinations. As for Marriage (upon the good Advice he had received not to engage, but as late as he could,) he uually aid, What a pitiful Utenil a Wife is? witnes the greatet part of thoe Gentlemen dignified with the Illutrious Title of Husbands; epecially now a days, when Men eem to have Wives onely for this, That others may make ue of them.

Thee Conequences he drew, as well from Experience as Example; for being Young, Handom, and Rich; he was ufficiently qualified not to fail of good Fortune, with a Sex (in our Age) very kind and uceptible, and had not wanted his divertiements of that Nature; and therefore he had mall inclination by taking a Wife, to give others the Opportunity to pay him in his own Coin.

In the mean time the Interets of the Family (which often prove Poion to the greatet pleaures of Life) obliging the mot excellent Perons to ordinary Actions: The Young Roman, to deliver himelf from the importunity of Relations, choe rather to quit the Pleaures of ROME, by Travelling abroad, than to make himelf ubject to a Law o contrary to his Humour, and that beloved Liberty he preferred before all things. He communicated his deign to his Valett de Chambre, who had erved him long, and being active and ingenious, quickly took order to have all things in readines that were neceary for their purpoe.

The Spring was come, and the Weather eaonable for Travel, when on a fair day the Young Gentleman and his Servant privately left Rome, and Imbarqued at Civita Vecchia in a Felucca hired for the purpoe. His deign was to viit the bet Courts of Europe, beginning with that of Spain. But there are Perons over whom Fortune is o rigorouly imperious, that he eems jealous of any thing they
undertake, without conulting her firt. 'Twas he who provided Count Alexander a Voyage into Africk, when he had deigned to confine his Travels to Europe: Of the Towns he was to ee, Tunis was marked out by Fortune for one; and though much out of his Road, yet where Fortune intermeddles, there always happens omething extraordinary; her excees and Extravagancies being that which chiefly makes us take notice of her.

The fourth day after he had left Civita Vecchia, this Young Lord began to perceive, that though all the Elements are terrible at Sea, yet Men who are Enemies are more terrible than the Elements. Till then the Weather had been fair to extremity, not a puff of contrary Wind: He proceeded in his Voyage with what peed he could wih, and bleed himelf at the happines of the Weather.

The Coat of Italy is dangerous, epecially in Summer, being then ubject to In-roads by People of the South, whoe livelihood is Robbery; and when the Weather is fair, their Trade is o great, that whooever is not upon
his Guard, is happy if he ecape them; I mean the Corairs of Barbary. Count Alexander, who never thought he had left Rome, to be led in Triumph to Tunis, aw himelf at break of day aluted by a Brigandine of that Nation: The poor Seamen preently took Alarm, the ight of one Turban was ufficient to affright them: And the Turks had carce dicharged three or four Muquets at the Chritians, but they leapt into the Sea to ave themeves by wimming; the Italian Count and his Servant taid in the Veel, not in hopes of being able to defend themelves againt that number of Enemies, which the trength of Rollando, and the Inchanted Armour of Amadis could carcely have done, (whereas now a Man is but a Man, and among other Secrets that of Inchanting Arms is lot.) But having no skill in wimming, he could not expect to eape as the Mariners: Yet he was not o out of love with his Life, but that he held it better to be a Slave than be drowned. But that thoe Barbarous Corairs might ee what a Peron they dealt with, and that he might ell his
Liberty as dear as poible; having commanded his Servant to throw his Baggage over-board, he gave him order what further to do. I will omit the Decription of the Action, though reputed the mot glorious ever done on the Mediterranean, being a Combate of Two againt Thirty, whereof they laid ix dead on the Deck, and many more wounded. 'Twas an Engagement of a Herd of Wolves againt Two young Lions, who defended themelves with unparallel'd Valour and Courage. 'Tis true, the Turks (not to loe the Money they did expect from their Ranom) pared them at firt, uing Cudgels only againt them; but at length the Blood and Death of their Comrades, and the hame and didain they had of o long and obtinate defence made by two rah Chritians againt them, being o many, having filled them with rage, they had recoure to their Symitars: And with o much advantage, that having killed the Valet, the Young Count (after everal Wounds received, his trength, not his Courage, having failed him in o tedious a Fight, was
forced to yield, being no longer able to lift up his Arm to make ue of his Sword. The Cowardly Villains had carce the Courage to board him, and durt not approach him till they aw him fallen flat on his back. They took him, and carried him on board their Brigandine, where they gave him all the help in their power for aving his Life, having no other mark of their Victory, but the taking one Valiant Peron, who had cot them too dear to be proud of their Prize: They beheld him with Admiration, and could not comprehend how an Age o tender could be capable of o much Courage; and that in a Body appearing o delicate, there was trength enough lodged to perform the actions they had een. And being Naturally Supertitious, they did really believe there was omething upernatural in the Young Mans Peron, or at leat, that he was the Flower of Chritendom; this conceit helped them to bear with more patience the hame of their Victory. And finding their Men thin, and having taken before ome
coniderable Prizes, they reolved to return directly for Tunis.

The Weather was favourable, and in few days ail they arrived at Gouletta, where going ahore they put the poor Count on Hore-back, bound and pinion'd like a Robber, and brought him to the Town; ome of thee Barbarians having got the tart of the ret, pread uch a Report of his Valour and Courage, that they drew together not the ordinary People only, (who are curious of mall matters) but the Principal Perons of Tunis, and the Baa himelf, who accompanyed with many of his Friends, came walking towards the Ruines of Carthage, to ee the arrival of this Famous Chritian, whom they imagined a Man that carried Terror in his looks: But how were they urpriz'd to ee a Youth pale and disfigured, yet keeping with his good mien the marks of Grandeur in his Countenance. He was pityed by all, and the Baa being a gallant and generous Peron, was preently eized with uch indignation againt the Villains, who ued in that manner one o little deerving
it, that he commanded them forthwith on pain of his dipleaure to unbind him upon the place; which they intantly did, not daring to diobey him, who next the Dey was of greatet Authority and Power in the Kingdom: He asked them the price of their Slave, and, having commanded him to be conducted to his Palace, paid the Corairs five hundred Patacoons, being the Money they demanded.

Count Alexander having happily fallen into the hands of o good and generous a Patron, began to recover. He was Lodged in a handom Apartment, where the Baa's Chyrurgions earched his Wounds: And being more carefully lookt to than on board the Brigandine, he oon found himelf better, though weak, and ore bruied by what he had uffer'd at Sea from the hands of thoe Barbarians, who having no pity for any, had not been too careful of him; yet there was no danger of his Life, the Fever he had was not great, and they had hopes to ee him well in few days. The Baa viited him Morning and Evening, and by degrees his care and kindnes grew
to that height, that he came more frequently to ee him, and not only took more particular notice of him, but increaed daily the eteem and friendhip he had for him.

Before I proceed, it may not be amis to atisfie the Curioity of the Reader, in giving him an account of the Peron; the Birth and Character of the Baa. Mahomet Baa. by the Father of Sidy Marat, and Mahomet Lapy the new Beys, was the Son of a Renegado of Corica, of the Family of Petroanty, who by the handomnes of his Peron and the excellency of his Wit, having gained the good Opinion of the Dey or King of the Countrey, made o good ue of the favour of his Prince, that he advanced him to the highet Office of the Kingdom, whereof he left his Son Mahomet his Heir. But, to horten the Story, Mahomet the younger being deeply embroyled with the Dey and the Divan, (who, jealous of the Authority his Father had gain'd, would have divided the Offices of Baa and Bey went to the Port, and returned Victorious: Tunis never flourihed as under him, being
as fit for Arms as Gallantry, of a great Spirit, and excellent Wit, the mot Brave, the mot Generous and Magnificent of Men: He loved the Chritians, and did them Jutice; and entertained a Commerce of Civility with many Princes of Europe. He ent and receiv'd Preents every Year to and from the Great Duke of Tucany; in a word, no Lord of that Countrey ever carried himelf better, and had more Merit and Reputation than he: Some reemblance of this Splendor may yet be een in the Peron of Mahomet Lapy his Son; he had inclinations worthy a great Lord, as he was, and the Soul of a Man truly Generous, and of Eminent Virtue.

The Baa was charm'd with admiration at the Wit of the Count, extreamly pleaed with his Converation, and ometimes pat three or four hours in familiar Dicoure, itting on his Bed. He was chiefly urprized to find his Apprehenion o clear, and Knowledge o general, that what Subject oever he choe to Dicoure of he poke of to admiration. This made the Baa peak of him to his Friends
with o tender affection, and o much to his Praie, that he gain'd him the Eteem and Amity of all the principal Lords of the Kingdom, who came to ee him, and made him Preents according to the Cutom of the Countrey.

The Baa, by many Illutrious marks and clear dicoveries, was induced to believe the Count a Peron of no ordinary Quality, but did not think fit to quetion him on that point; and had no further knowledge of him, than that he was an Italian. Nor durt the Count acquaint him with his Condition, fearing, the knowing of it might make his Enlargement the more difficult: But after o many favours from the Baa, he could not in gratitude conceal himelf from a Peron who had Obliged him o highly, and to whom he did owe more than his Life. Therefore being askt by the Baa, whether his Parents were living, and why he writ not to them: Sir, (aid he) I hould be the baet of Men, hould I ever forget the Obligations you have put upon me, nor could I be guilty of a greater dihonety, than to be prevail'd
upon by fear, or any other conideration, not to pay you what I owe you. I confes, (and I hope you will Pardon me,) that I crupled to make a full dicovery of my elf to you, for fear my Captivity might be the harder, my bondage more evere, and my Liberty valued at a higher rate: but having found you o generous, I cannot, after the favours you have heaped upon me, the Rights you have over your Slaves, by forbearing to tell you, I am a Peron of Quality, of one of the bet Families of Rome; that my Name is Count Alexander, and that if ever you retore me to my Liberty, I mut pay you my Ranom with mot grateful acknowledgments of your kindnes and favours.

The Baa mil'd, and with much tendernes anwer'd, Alexander, you hall not fare the wore for your dicovery to me; I am no Merchant of Slaves, nor did I buy you to ell you again: You are free, and hall live with me in this Countrey as if you were in your own, with one of your Friends: And if I detain you here a little longer than perhaps you would wih, it is becaue I can hardly part with one for whom I have o high an eteem, and o cordial affection. To thee he
added other expreions of Kindnes, which were joyfully received by the Count, and dipelled all his grief for the los of his Liberty.

As oon as he had recovered his trength, the Baa made him partake of his Pleaures and Divertiements, in Hunting, Walking, Hore-race; in all which the Count appeared Eminent above others, and became more Famous than ever any Chritian was in thoe Parts; every coniderable Peron was ambitious to viit him, and took pleaure to ee, and to treat him, which is a pecial favour to thoe of their Countrey, much more to one who profes'd a Religion, to which they are open irreconcileable Enemies. Hence you may oberve the power of Merit, and how irreitible are influences of a Fortunate Detiny. The eteem the Baa expres'd publickly for him, contributed much to all thee advantages; but you are to conider his Peron, and the weetnes of his Temper, and candor of his Actions as the effectual means for gaining him Amity, and that which won him the Love of the mot Excellent Perons.

But notwithtanding his Illutrious Acquaintance, and agreeable Divertiements, the Honours and Favours he daily received, he could not forbear wihing with ighs for a return into Europe. He lived as one free, but was really a Slave to the Affection of the Baa, from which he thought his deliverance more difficult, than from Fetters and Chains. His Wit and Inclinations were not for the Men of that Countrey; he loathed, and was weary of them: The Turks have a good ene, and will reaon well enough of the Affairs of the World, and are great and ubtile Polititians; but for Wit and good Breeding, they know not what it is; their Converation is barren, and conits more in the moak of Tobacco than Excellent Dicoure: Their Knowledge is mall, having ordinarily no advantage of Reading or Travel. The Baa alone had more Wit, and more Reaon than the ret altogether; but his Employment in the State engaging him in a thouand indipenible Affairs, would not allow him to be always with Alexander, who in the mean time pat
his Melancholy hours in the Garden of the Seraglio, where he had the priviledge to walk, being a retired and very pleaant place, and that wherein he took great delight. But alas, how different were thee days from thoe at Rome! the Italians are naturally apt to be Melancholy, and this Solitude made the Count o: The Baa, who loved him incerely, and paionately wihed to have him always in good humour, was troubled to find him ad and dejected; but having often enquired the caue, could not obtain farther atisfaction, than that it was an effect of his Temper: He had furnihed him to exces with all that Countrey could afford for the Pleaures of Life, and could not imagine the caue of the grief, but fancied at lat that to compleat his Divertiements, Alexander might want the converation of a Woman. The Baa being a Peron much given to Gallantry, was the more eaily inclined to believe he had found the true caue of his Melancholy. And looked upon it as no incurable Dieae, but preently reolved to find out a Remedy,
by furnihing him with a Mitres, which was a high train of complaiance in a Peron of his Character; but there were no limits to the Love he had for his Alexander.

The Law of Mahomet is very evere in this Point, againt Perons of another Religion, though very indulgent to thoe of his own. Thoe who fall into the hands of the Turks, and will make love to their Women, are under the neceity of changing their Religion, or Burning: thee Extremities are hard, yet of the many Chritians reduced to thoe traits, I know not one who hath thought Martyrdom o charming, as not to prefer Circumciion before Burning: the Baa, though no zealous oberver of the Law, was willing however to avoid the Scandal that might follow if the Intrigue were dicovered, and therefore deign'd to marry him to a Chritian. There was with the Sultanes his Wife, an Italian Slave, a young Maid of good quality, lovely and witty: it was not long ince the Baa had been in love with her, but without any ucces: whether it proceeded from the repect
he bore to the Sultanes her Mitres, who loved her intirely, or from cruple of Concience in point of Religion, with which he excued her elf, certain it is, his addrees were vain; and after three Months eager peruit of his deign, being not accutom'd to o much reitance, he quitted her, and cat his eyes on other les difficult conquets: he hoped that one Chritian with another might have better ucces, and that Alexander being very lovely, and young, needed only to hew himelf for gaining the love of a Maid of his Country, profeing the ame Religion with him: he endeavour'd to dipoe her for the purpoe, by raiing in her an eteem for the Gallant he provided her: he had often poken of him in the Chamber of the Sultanes, where Laura, the Slave we are dicouring of, did contantly attend.

And having formed the deign, he eldom entertained them with any thing ele, but Alexander did this, or Alexander aid that; of which he gave them o pleaant Decriptions, that he could not fail of making ome impreions
of love for him in a Woman, though never o little uceptible.

The Count knew nothing of all thee good Offices; the Baa miling ometimes at his adnes, would tell him, he hould hortly ee him in a different humor. One having dipoed all things on Laura's ide, (who had told him, he would not be dipleas'd to ee this Chritian) he took him into the Garden of the Seraglio to walk, and after a turn or two, asked him if he had ever been in love. The quetion did very much urprize him, apprehending, that being among a People naturally upicious, the Baa might perhaps have had ome Jealouie of him, though he could not imagine the caue. But to diabue him, he held it neceary to affect great indifference in the buines of Women, and (the truth is) to that day he had not been in love. And though it were ill courthip to the Baa, who was an admirer of Women, to tell him he had never been in Love; yet he choe rather to commit a olaecim in courthip, than to give him the leat caue of upition. The Baa advied him to
have a care of himelf, let Love hould one day be revenged of him, and told him, he depaired not of eeing him a Lover in Barbary: You are, aid he, handom and witty, and there are here, as in Europe, dangerous Ladies, who perhaps may have deigns on your liberty; and you are not yet got out of Tunis: This Dicoure unexpected, and poken with uch an Air, o troubled the Count, he knew not what anwer to make. The Baa much pleaed at the diorder he had put him to; What, aid he, doth Love appear o terrible to you, that you dare not encounter it? can a Man of your bravery be afraid of a Paion? Recollect your elf, and think it not o dreadful here as in Italy; you arm your Cupid with weapons of War, we dres ours with Flowers; nothing is les cruel than Love among the Turks: our Women are kind, and good natured, and never are the caue of any mans death by coynes and didain; the ole difficulty is in getting a ight of them; gain but that point, and nothing can be more eaie than the ret: your Ladies are crupulous and hy of hewing favour to their Lovers, and ours make a concience of
eeing their Languih: it is not o odious to be fond and coming with you, as 'tis to be cruel and inenible here. We follow in the firt place the Law of nature, preferring it to Mahomets, as being Men before we are Muulmans. We hold our elves obliged to pay kind regard and affectionate tendernes to Female Beauty, and expect from it a return of complacency. And thoe who approve not thee Maxims, we eteem unworthy to tate the pleaures of Love. I know that in Europe you ue this Paion an extraordinary way, making that Martyrdom which hould be a delight; but I would fain know, what the deign of that Woman can be, who ees a man every day on his knees at her feet, ighing for that which he alo deires, and it may be, more paionately. Why then mut he be tormented? Why o many ighs, why o many tears expected from him, when the paion of both Sexes is equal, if that of the Female may not pas for the greater?

The Count having in this time recollected himelf, anwered; I believe, Sir, that in Love as in other matters every one may have his particular fancy, and different Maxims for conduct: but if I,
who was never in Love, may be allow'd to deliver my opinion of it, I conceive that Men born under a Law, are inenibly dipoed to bear it with eae. And I dare confidently affirm, there is more weetnes, and charming delight in the torments we endure in our way of Loving, than in thoe eaie pleaures that cot you nothing: think not, Sir, thoe torments o cruel as our Lovers repreent them; they aggravate them only to affect their Mitrees the more, and to make them more enible. It would certainly urprize you to hear them cry, Increae, O love, Increae o weet a pain: their ufferings are pleaures. The Baa was o charmed with hearing him peak, that he would not interrupt him, o that he proceeded, What atisfaction can you find in a Love that is fulom and dull, without any pique to make it poynant, and eaon it for relih? What divertiement to be expected from an innocent Cupid, a Child without wit, without waggery, that permits you to do in all things as you pleae? The Baa could not forbear laughing, and told him, that to make him believe that Love the mot charming, that made him uffer mot, he
mut make it appear by trial in himelf by being in Love, enduring with pleaure all the torments he poke of: Sir, aid Alexander, I was never in love in my Country, where you know we have freedom of living, and Liberty of convere with the Female Sex; it is not probable then I hall fall in love here, where we are not allow'd o much as a ight of them: means may be found, replied the Baa, to atisfie you in that particular if you deire it. I do not conceive it for my advantage, aid the Count, to thrut my elf into the fire to try the experiment, or to change my Religion. No, no, aid the Baa, it is with a Chritian I would have you acquainted, and one in my judgment very beautiful, and not unworthy your ighs: had I been of your mind, and like the Lovers of your Country, taken pleaure in being vext and tormented, my buines might have been done. She made me pine for her above three Months, till weary of a Mitres that had o little ene of my pain, I betook my elf to others that were more of my humour; her beauty and wit will certainly charm you, and you may find her as haughty, as fierce, as cruel as you can wih: it may be difficult
to have a ight of her, as being with the Sultanes, who, ince he knew the inclinations I had for her, would never permit her to tep out of her Apartment: but I'le bring you thither diguied as an Eunuch; there is no other way of entrance for you into the Seraglio: and you are o young, that by Night you may pas for an Eunuch without any upicion. The Count gave him a thouand thanks for the favour, not but that he could have been very well content to have been without it, having no great deire to engage himelf in Acquaintance in a Country where he would tarry as hort time as he could; yet in complaiance to the Baa, and of Curioity to ee a Slave the Baa repreented o beautiful, he accepted this offer with ome kind of joy.

The fourth Prayer being over, be came to his Patron, being the time he uually went to the Seraglio: And having taken the Habit of an Eunuch provided for him there, he waited on the Baa to the Apartment of the Sultanes: Laura, who had notice of their coming, waited their entrance;
the Baa came milling up to her, and whipered her in the Ear, that he had brought her an Eunuch, who could tell her News out of Italy; pray'd her to have a care of him, and to ue him as a Peron he lov'd entirely. Laura fell a laughing, and anwered, he doubted not but the Eunuch hould give him a good account of his Reception. The Count, though Diguied, was o eaie to be known, that, had the Baa aid nothing, his good Mien had dicovered him: No Eunuch, no Turk had o good an air. She gave him her hand to lead her into a Chamber, where they hould not be expoed to their view who pat by. Sir, aid he, I know not what thanks to give the Baa for the favour he hath done me, to afford me a ight of you, no man being allowed entrance here but himelf, and the Eunuch whoe Habit he hath caued you to take. I cannot impute it to any thing but the extraordinary affection he hath and daily declares for you. 'Tis true, Madam, anwered the Count, the kindnes of the Baa to me is extream; but either of us have reaon to be concerned how to thank him, (as he very well deerves)
'tis certainly I, for the favour he hath procured me; yet I could wih I were not wholly beholding to him for it, but that (as he would have me believe) you had a hand in it. Sir, replyed Laura, I hall tell you no lye, I have made it ufficiently known to you, I deired this favour from him. He told us things o glorious of you, and related them o much to your advantage, you may eaily believe, I (who, for three years I have been here, have not had the Liberty of Convere with any Man) could not but deire acquaintance of a Peron o generally eteemed. Madam, aid he, this Country hath been favourable in allowing me a Reputation, which perhaps I may find difficult to maintain in your Opinion. You need not fear that, reply'd Laura, your Mien confirms ufficiently the reports that have pat of you. But to change the Dicoure, do you know, aid he miling, that ometimes 'tis dangerous in a Nation like this, to make your elf o much the ubject of Dicoure; if not on the Mens account, yet certainly on the Womens, who fall in Love meerly on report, without a ight or knowledge of the Party: The Count anwered miling, Madam, there is no
danger of your being of the number of thoe kind-hearted Ladies, I am not o Fortunate. And why, aid he, might not I be one, who have o long'd for a ight of you: but to loe no more time, I mut tell you, your Fortune is better than you think; and I do that for another, which perhaps I would not have done for my elf. The deire of eeing a Man is here reputed a mighty advancement of Love, where to ee and to agree are all one. But I have undertaken this affair, and made the Baa believe I have very favourable thoughts of you. And to atisfie your Curioity of knowing the Party for whom I have o much complaiance in tore, it is for the Baa's Lady, Madam Alhie the Sultanes: The confidence he is pleaed to repoe in me is o great, that he hath entruted me with this Secret, and my kindnes for her hould not admit one moments cruple doing her this Service. I cannot doubt but you have heard of her beauty; never was any o famous in this Kingdom, nor perhaps in the World, more worthy admiration: And as for her temper, 'tis the weetet and mot lovely that can be imagined. The firt view you have of her, will perwade you he
hath an inclination to Love, o tender, o languihing is the air of her Countenance. And though this be natural to the Women of this Country, and that the firt thing they are taught, is to igh, and appear languihing, yet I have not oberved thoe weaknees in her but on your account. To deduce things from the Original, I mut inform you, that when the Baa returned from Contantinople, having dipatched the Affair depending there between him, and the King, and Divan of this place, and being confirmed by the Grand Signior in the Offices his Father had left him, which they had diputed; the King, in order to Reconciliation, was advied to give the Baa his Daughter in Marriage. Alhie was then Sixteen Years old, and her beauty at the height; though at this day in my judgment, no man that ees her, but mut be in Love with her. Thee Marriages of Policy and State-interet, to which the Daughters of great ones are ubject to be Sacrificed, eldom prove Happy. The Baa Epoued Alhie, and perhaps loved her a Week, but after that returned to his former Engagements, and for ordinary beauties quitted the greatet of the Kingdom. 'Tis true, it often happens
thus in this Country, where Men abhor loving by Duty and Obligation, and commonly love Mitrees better than Wives: but this Lady, in my Opinion, ought to have been excepted, as wanting nothing requiite to atisfie the Paion of any reaonable Man; but he is as unfortunate as others. The Baa, though otherwie a Peron of much Gallantry, viits her carce once in a Month; yet he pays her all the Repect in the World, and he hath no caue of complaint but of his Love; but take love from Marriage, what ignifies the ret? What a trouble it is to a Young Lady, who knows her own merit, to ee her elf lighted in that whereof he is mot enible? A Lady who would think her elf happy in being belov'd, and thinks he deerves it: you mut be a Woman before you can comprehend the rigor of this uage, and the greatnes of her misfortune. But to come to what concerns you; the Sultanes hath ever had a great inclination for Chritians; and the greatet pleaure he takes, is, in tories he makes me tell of my Country, which urprize her o (epecially when I peak of the freedom Men have there with Women) that he hath a thouand times wihed her Fortune
had been as mine, and that he had fallen into the hands of a Chritian, who would have carried her into that Country. 'Tis certain, a Woman had better be a Slave with us, than free among the Turks, where their Life is nothing but a perpetual Slavery. The Adventures of Love and Gallantry have pleaed her o well in the relation, that he longs for a ight of one of thoe I called Perons of Quality and Merit, who were o Gallant and Handom, as I repreented. You were no ooner arrived, but he came with great joy to tell me, the Baa had newly bought a Chritian, of whom they poke Wonders. I fell a laughing, and ask'd if it were not uch a one he had often wih'd for her Slave. She bluhed, and turning about with a igh, anwered, who knows what may happen, and whether Fortune hath not deigned him for me. She made me her Bedfellow that Night, to entertain her on that ubject. On the morrow the Baa having confirmed the Reports of you, and commended your Peron, he and I for everal days had no dicoure but of you. The kindnes he hath for me, makes me omewhat familiar with her; nor do we very trictly oberve here our ditance towards
great ones; this made me ometimes take the Liberty to quarrel with her for the longing he expret for a Man he had not een. I confes, aid he, this were falling in Love a little too oon, if we managed our Love as the Chritians do theirs. But the Baa having made uch a decription of this Man, there is not a Woman in the Kingdom who would not have had a greater Paion for him than I have expret. And you may believe he would not have poken o much in his praie before the meanet of his Emprees; but though he light me o, that he cares not what I think, my affections are free. You would eteem your elf happy, Madam, aid I, to have uch a Chritian in Love with you. More happy, reply'd he, than you can imagine. And I will aure you, I could willingly change the tate I am in, for the condition of a private Chritian Lady: What good does it me, to abound thus with Riches, to receive o much Honour, to be the Daughter of a King, and the Wife of a Baa, if I cannot be content, nor do as I would, nor love where love is due? In a word, if I am nothing les than I am taken to be, but
a Slave more unhappy than thoe under Chains. Poor Laura (aid he, embracing me tenderly) how I pity thee, who hat tated the Pleaures and Liberty of thy Country, and hat unhappily fallen into their hands who ue o unworthily all orts of Women.

With uch dicoures as thee did we entertain our elves ever ince they poke of you at Tunis. The Baa came oftner to viit the Sultanes, though we knew not the reaon; and almot every day brought us the News of you: And, as he loves you entirely, took pleaure in relating every thing you did. Perhaps, had he known the favourable inclinations the Sultanes had for you, he had been more paring in his expreions of you, for I cannot believe he deigned to prejudice himelf in peaking obligingly of you. But it was an overight, and mot unpardonable in him who o well knew the temper of Women of this Country: Judge you whether o good a report from o good a hand could want its effect. The Sultanes was affected with them o much to the purpoe, that what at firt was a bare inclination, grew up by degrees to a ettled Paion. Her humour was uddenly chang'd from
Merry and Jocund, into Sadnes and Melancholy; and I, who alone knew her Ditemper, could not but pity her ighs and complaints, and was extreamly afraid he might fall into a Dieae, which they call Fantaie, and is a kind of Melancholy that proves Mortal to many Men and Women of this Country. I did my endeavour to cure her of this Paion, by repreenting to her all the obtacles in her way to the happines he deired. But my Remedies came too late, I did but trouble her to no purpoe, having aid to her elf all that I could poibly ay to divert her from the affection he had taken: So that depairing of Remedy on that ide, I apply'd my thoughts another way, and flattered her hopes of bringing that to pas, which I could not dicover the leat poibility to effect. But to prevent the growth and increae of her Ditemper, it was neceary to deceive her by flatteries and hopes. At lat, I know not how it fell out, that the Baa having poken of you to me two days ago, as he frequently does when he finds me alone, I told him, I hould be very glad to ee you, if it might be done without noie and oandal: I was extreamly atonih'd how eaily he promied
it: And you may believe I had not waited here for you, but that I very well knew him a Man of his word.

The Count having hearken'd to all this dicoure with marvellous attention, and thanked Laura for all her good Offices, and anwer'd all her obliging expreions in behalf of the Sultanes, dicovered to her the Baa's deign, and the reaon of his being brought thither; Laura was ravihed to hear his dicoure, and though he foreaw her concern in the Affair was like to be mall, yet he was pleas'd with the News he received, being willing to acrifice all Interets of her own, to the atisfaction of her Lady. But, Sir, to tell you all, aid he to the Count, having paid my thanks to the Baa for the favour I was in hopes of from him, I went preently to bring the News to the Sultanes, who could not ufficiently embrace me, being o extreamly tranported, that nothing in the World could have made her more joyful; he hath carcely been able to leep ever ince: he and I have laid a hundred deigns and framed to our elves a thouand devices how he may have a ight of you: but if
the Baa will not permit you to come alone hither, I do not ee how it may be effected: the Sultanes in the mean time will be ravihed with joy that I have een you, and that you know ome part of her mind.

The happy Roman being charmed at the kindnes a Lady of that beauty and quality had for him, was very urgent with Laura to oblige him on this occaion, and pres'd her to ay to the Sultanes from him, all that a heart extreamly enible of the favour he did him, was capable to expres. That he would have eteem'd himelf the happiet of men, had it been in his power to have merited this honor, and that it hould be the buines of his life, to deerve it by his actions. Sir, reply'd Laura, all he deires of you, is that you will o manage the Liberty the Baa doth afford you, that he may once have a ight of you: I find my elf engaged to it by o many reaons, aid the Count, that you may be aured I will not forget any thing that may gain this honour: I mut intreat you to aure the Sultanes accordingly, and that I have at leat as much paion as he. He had no
ooner aid this, but the Baa came to them, which made them change their dicoure, and the Baa having condecended to make himelf one of the company, and very pleaantly rallied; then aid, he perceived by their countenances they were obliged to him for the acquaintance he had procured between them, and that they were very well pleaed one with the other: the Count and Laura having returned the complement, the Baa took his leave, and he and the Count went out of the Seraglio.

The Baa had oberved uch joy in Alexander's countenance when he was with Laura, it made him believe he was very well pleaed with the viit he had given her. But he had the curioity to ask him how he liked her; and whether he appeared o beautiful as he had repreented her: the Count anwered, it was certainly impoible to ee a Lady more handom, or more witty: and that he was charmed at her Beauty and Converation. The Baa who deired nothing more than to ee him in Love, was extreamly glad at the confeion he made; and
told him it hould be his fault, if he aw her not again; and, if he deired, he might do it on the morrow, that he would give him a Key to enter the Seraglio, and that he might go alone; let if he brought him in, the Sultanes might be jealous: it being not his cutom to viit her o often, the Count failed not to acquaint him how highly that favour would oblige him; o that the Baa bid him go to bed, and take his ret, and told him he hould ee Laura on the morrow about the time he had een her that day.

Never was a night o retles to any man, as this to the Count, her inclination, like that he had to marriage, with the principal and mot beautiful Lady of the Kingdom, was a thing o rare, and o tempting for a Man of his temper; what Laura had aid of thoe obliging thoughts that charming Peron had for him, did o ravih him with pleaure, that in the depth of misfortune he could not imagine any man more fortunate than himelf: But when he conidered, that he was the Wife of the Baa, a Peron to whom he was o trictly obliged, he
was troubled extreamly, and igh'd for orrow; thee econd thoughts prevailing at that time over the other, he highly reproached himelf for entertaining a thought of o bae an ingratitude. But it is a ticklih buines to repent of a thing that extreamly delights us, and men eldom charge themelves home for a fault o pleaing and lovely, as the pleaure of being beloved: thoe reproaches of the Count againt himelf, were not altogether the mot violent that might be, and ometimes he would be angry with himelf for making o much ado. At lat, being aaulted by turns, on the one ide by Reaon, on the other by Paion, by the Glory of that, and the tendernes of this, he got up in the Morning, without having been able to take any other reolution than to yield himelf up to be guided by his Detiny, to be governed by Fate, and be meerly paive in the management of the buines; that is to ay, to love, in this particular, like a Turk, and to ee the Sultanes, if it were o predetinated: but to do nothing in order to it, though he had promied Laura to
contribute on his part all that lay in his power, and had told the Baa, he hould be extreamly glad to go again to the Seraglio. His reolution ometimes was very tottering and weak, and to peak truth, 'tis almot vain to take one againt love: he wiht a thouand times that day, that his Fate to whoe conduct he had given himelf up, would incline to bring him to the Sultanes. He waited the hour with a great deal of impatience, however he would fain have perwaded himelf to the contrary: but a young heart cannot be inenible, being o apt to take fire, that it carce requires any help to inflame it.

As oon as the Baa aw the Count in the Evening, he hew'd him (miling) the Key of the Seraglio: and he received it with the greatet joy in the World. But I give it, aid the Baa, on condition that you make me your Confident. And I think I have done enough to engage you to do me that pleaure. The hour was come for his going to the Sultanes, and the Count having put on his Eunuchs Habit, his Patron every day more obliging than other,
would needs bear him company as far as the Seraglio; Laura having notice of his coming, had waited for him above an hour at the Gate, and no ooner aw him arrived, but ravihed with joy, he gave him her hand, and told him. You are either the mot dextrous, or ele the mot fortunate Peron in the World: you bring about things o difficult, and in o hort a time, that all things eem to joyn in your favour: I am obliged for it to my fortune, anwered the Count; for, as for Addrees I had no occaion to ue any, but if you would make me believe my elf as happy as you ay, help me to a ight of the Sultanes. Laura told him, he hould preently hear of her, and brought him into a Chamber, where her Lady was ued to receive viits. It was her cutom to eat her elf in a kind of Alcove, the paage to which, was through her Chamber, made up with great Ballitres guilt, and covered with a Curtain of very thin Silk, through which he could ee thoe whom he honoured only with a ight of her; which is a piece of State ued in that Country.

Laura told the Count, that the Sultanes would ee him from behind that Curtain. And hall not I then, aid he, have the honour to ee her. I know not, aid Laura, but 'tis a favour o great, that 'tis never granted but when they are willing to grant all that may be expected: Ah Madam, aid the Count, I beeech you to deire that favour for me; tell her it will be of mall conequence to give a tranger a ight of her, and that I hall die with grief if he deny me that honour. Laura promied him all the aitance in her power, and leaving him for a moment, went to advertie the Sultanes, who quetionles longed for news of the arrival of her dearly beloved Chritian. In the mean time the Count conidered the Riches and Ornaments of the Chamber, being the mot magnificent of the Apartment, it was et out with four Chrital Glaes which had a pleaant effect on the Gold and the Jewels which glitter'd all about: Scarce had the Sultanes een Laura, but he knew by her countenance the happy news he brought; and without allowing her time to ay any thing, he pat to the Alcove, from
whence he deign'd to take a view of the Chritian, before he hould know that he was there. But he made too great a noie at her entrance, and the Cavalier let her know, he had perceiv'd her, by aluting her, as he did, after the Turkih mode: Laura arrived the ame time from the other ide, and going to the Ballitre, went to whiper the Sultanes, who was not able ufficiently to expres the pleaure he took in eeing this Chritian, and the Charms that appear'd in his Peron. As for him, he was trangely perplext at a viit of this nature, where he could neither ee, nor peak to the Party he viited. He went, he came, he turn'd about as deired, and at the end of the Shew, went ilently to the Ballitre, and addreing himelf to the Sultanes, having een a hadow of her through the Curtain, he told her a thouand pretty Stories, a thouand Gallantries to oblige her to afford him a view, for he undertood Italian, and poke it pretty well, having learnt it of Laura. She was very well pleas'd to hear the Count peak, and heartily laught at it, but anwered not a word, nor had the
Curtain drawn. The Count was impatient, and accounting every moment lot he pent in that manner, eem'd to fret and be angry, and in a frank and free way told her, he hould die of the Phantaie, as the People of that Country, if he denied him this favour, and that at lat he would with his own hand draw that troubleom Curtain: and he had certainly done it, if Laura, who fear'd the Sultanes might take it ill, had not hindred him. But Laura was mitaken, and her Lady gave her not thanks for her pains.

'Tis a Maxim among the Women of that Country, not to in of themelves againt the Rules of their duty; but pres them a little, and offer them the leat violence, they will preently yield without any reitance: their excue is, that nature is weak, that men know it well enough, and are very much to blame to pres them o home: that if there be harm done, it mut be laid to their core, who caue them to do it, and not to them who are ignorant of it, and innocent in the buines. Laura not well vert in the
ue of this Maxim, committed a fault, when he thought he had been dicharging her duty. The amorous Sultanes would have been ravih'd with joy to have been een by the Chritian, and the officious Slave poil'd all by a piece of ueles dicretion. But her Lady was willing to receive the micarriage, and atisfie in ome meaure the extream deire her dear Chritian had to ee her; he gave him leave to ask what he pleaed, to make him amends for the rigour of the cutom of that Country, which made it undecent for her Sex to hew themelves to any but their Husband. The Count preently deired he would at leat do him the honour of hewing him one of her fair hands: The Sultanes no ooner heard him, but lifting up the Curtain a little, he gave him her hand over the Ballitre. The young Count was o charmed with this favour, that tranported with joy, he laid his knee to the ground, and kied her hand with uch paion; that the Sultanes, equally tranported, wrung his hand, preing it o hard, to let him know he approved of what he did.
She was not over careful to keep her elf uneen; and having put forth her arm, he could not chooe, but ometimes appear to him in part by one chance or other (to which perhaps he contributed a little.) Her Gallant could have wih'd he had had a full ight of her, but thinking he had enough for the firt time, he would not adventure to deire any more. The pleaure the Sultanes took in the ight of him, was o great, and o charming, that he could have willingly pat that night with him. But knowing that many eyes were upon her, and that he lived where men are extreamly given to jealouie, and epecially of their Wives, he had apprehenions of being Lampoon'd in her own Apartment for taying o long in the Alcove, at a time o uneaonable for receiving a viit. And Laura had told her, 'twas time to withdraw. But how cruel a thing 'tis to be forced to part from that which we love? it cannot be done without pain and regret. Still he found ome little pretence or other to tay him a little longer; at lat he pretented him with a Gold Chain
beet with Jewels, and told him obligingly it was not fit a Slave like him hould wear any other. The happy Count better atisfy'd with this Chain, than if he had given him the Crown of Tunis, anwered her Gallantry, and the favour he did him with the mot paionate and the mot grateful expreions imaginable. And eeing the neceity of parting, he took his leave of the Sultanes, and withdrew with Laura, who accompanied him to the Gate of the Apartment.

Preents among the Turks, are the firt Evidences of affections, and often pas for declarations of love. Laura, who knew it well enough, made the Count enible, before parting, what that meant which he had received from the Sultanes; and that he was not to doubt, having heard and een o much of her, but he paionately lov'd him. Yet he was to take heed, and believe he had need of abundance of dicretion, to deal with the Women of that Country, whoe paion of love is ometimes o violent, that they oberve no bounds; that the Sultanes was indeed the mot rational he had
known amongt them, and had the mot wit, yet tender and paionate as the ret. That he and he would be immutably ruined, if the Baa, who had no mall experience in Amours, hould once have the leat upicion of the Intrigue. That there was not in the Kingdom a man more tender of his honour than he; and that all the kindnes he had for him, would not ave him from his indignation, if he once came to know he had een his Wife.

As much taken as our young Roman was with the pleaant beginnings of his Amours, and for all his rejoycings at thoe evident kindnees he had received from the greatet Beauty under Heaven, yet he could not forbear reflecting on Laura's good counels, but went muing along the Seraglio, what coure he hould take, what means he hould ue againt o dangerous a Paion, which would certainly bring him to ruin and confuion. When the Baa going to one of his Mitrees, met him by the way, and eeing him pas by without o much as aluting him, he preently fell a laughing, and taking him by the
arm. Now, aid he, I ee that you are in love. The Count being confounded at his urprizing him in that cae, made excues for his fault. The Baa made anwer, that if he deir'd to be pardon'd, he mut freely confes the truth, and acknowledge himelf extreamly diordered at the Merits and Beauty of Laura: More Sir (aid the Count with a very deep igh) than you can poibly expres or imagine. But it being late, and the Baa not willing to tay, he deferred the more particular inquiry to another opportunity, and dimis'd him to his Lodging. This was a great happines, and no les pleaure to the young Lover, who was not then in condition to give the Baa an account of his Amours. Part of that night he pas'd walking in his Chamber, as if he had intended to come to a Reolution before he went to bed. It was not the fear of death, or mifortune that troubled him, but the horrour of ingratitude; and having received o much kindnes from the Baa, thought it inexcuable in him to have any unjut deigns on his Wife: But, then ays he, hould I not be the
mot ungrateful of men, hould I light the affection of o charming a Peron, to whom, if I conider her Obligations according to their value, I owe more than to the Baa? And is it not poible for me to ee, and to love her within bounds, o as to be blameles on the one ide and the other? No, no, if there be ingratitude in that, I cannot help it, there is nothing in the World can excue me to the Sultanes, and love ought to make my excue with the Baa.

This was the lat Combate between gratitude and love in the heart of the Count; the lat carried the day, and going to bed thereupon, he reted very well. The Baa who was extreamly deirous to ee him o deeply in love, that he hould not be able to deny it, was the firt that poke to him, to return again that day to the Sultanes Lodgings: he gave him the Key of the Seraglio, and laughing, told him, he need not make uch hate to come back, if he found as much pleaure as he wiht him there: but that he mut have a care, he did not engros all the love to himelf, but he hould give Laura ome part, unles he were minded to languih,
as he had done, a long time to no purpoe.

The amorous Italian went traight to the Seraglio, and Laura, who waited for him, told him at his arrival, he might pas to the ame Chamber he had been in, and that he would give her Lady notice of his coming; but he not having the patience of waiting o long, was got already into the Alcove. The Count having an extream curioity, and longing for a ight of that place, thought it convenient for the purpoe, to make ue of that time, when he believed the Sultanes was abent; and coming up to the Ballitre, gently took up the Curtain. But how was he urprized to ee on the udden, that charming Peron in a poture the mot capable of any, to make one in love.

I hall not trouble you with a decription of the Alcove, which being a Room of State for the Wife of o puiant a Lord, you may eaily believe, was very noble and rich: It was raied a foot higher than the Chamber; the approach to it being by a pace cover'd with a fair Turky Carpet, checkquer'd
with little quares of Damask wrought with Gold. The Sultanes lay on a Bed of Damask of like work; and having deign'd to hew her elf that day to the Count, he had not forgot to put her elf in an equipage and poture capable to charm him at firt ight: he had turned her face towards the Balliter, leaning her head careletly on her left arm, which you might clearly ee in her great Tiffany leeve after the Turkih mode. Her black hair was partly pleated with great ropes of Pearl, parting down on her Breat, and part on her houlders, and et off the clearnes of her delicate Complexion (vying with the Snow in whitenes) to o much advantage, that it wrought wonderful effects in the beholder. She had about her body, a mall Gold Bodice only, her boom being half open, and the ret cover'd with a piece of fine Tiffany, like an Amazons Scarf: all was viible from her Neck to her Breat, and o admirable to behold, that it had been impoible for an eye, having een it, (as the Count did) to ecape being enamour'd of it: he had on her head,
plumes of everal colours, and in the midt of them a crecent of Silver. Her Coat was of a light Stuff Imbroydered with Gold after the fahion of the Country, with Diamond Buckles to tuck it up at the knee: her Leg was half naked, and the ret covered with Buskins all laid over with Diamonds and Pearls; in a word, he was all o Rich, o Gallant, o full of Charms, that the poor Count was utterly undone at the ight. His joy and atonihment were viible to her in that confuion of action and words, in which he was o mierably plung'd, that he knew not what was become of himelf, nor what he would ay to her. But falling into an Extaie, and wholly wallowed up with admiration, his Eyes and his Sighs were Orators for him. The fair Sultanes as oon as he aw him, would, with a Handkerchief he had in her hand, have covered her face, and hid from him part of the confuion he was in. But the happy Lover, recovering courage by degrees, paing his arm betwixt the Ballitres, hindered her from it. Once you might have had reaon Madam, aid he, to have
kept from my ight thoe treaures of love, as knowing full well that no man can ee them without dying for love of them, but now 'tis too late to conceal them from me. I have een more than any heart is able to bear, without yielding it elf; and it would be extream cruelty in you, not to compleat what is o happily begun. As the Count was peaking to her in this manner, he look'd upon him with eyes o tender and piercing, that he eemed willing to execute what he deired. The crafty Count having eiz'd one of her hands, (to which, as he look'd upon it, he gave a thouand amorous kies) by little and little drew it out o far on his ide, with o feeble reitance from the Sultanes, that he came at lat to lean her head on the Ballitre jut over againt the head of the Count. Then it was, he had full liberty to take a view at his leaure of thoe Beauties that put him to amazement, and ravihed him with uch joy as he had never before been enible of. As ill luck would have it, the Ballitres were o cloe, that not any two of them tood half the head ditance one from the other. However
the two Lovers meeting half way, made a hift to lip through a great number of Kies, the mot charming and weet that Lovers e're tated. The Count being naturally bold, made one Liberty but a tep to another, and eeing what he was permitted to do, and the pleaure he took in it, he pres'd his amorous temerity o far, that what he did may pas for half an enjoyment. Till then their entertainment was made up of dumb engagements, a thouand times more eloquent than the finet expreions in the World. Their eyes, their ighs, their actions, their toyes had poken a Language intelligible enough to perwade both they loved one another intirely. They had no need of other converation; yet, Laura arriving, they changed it a little, but they poke before her the mot tender, and mot paionate things you can imagine. The Sultanes who had that confidence in her as to conceal nothing from her, was not troubled at her coming. But the Count, who took not o much pleaure in thee dicoures though very obliging, as in thoe dumb entertainments, made
a ign to Laura to take the other turn; at which the Saltanes eeming a little angry, let down the Curtain, and o fatned it behind, that he could not take it up. But this being in Jet, and to provoke his Paion the more, her rigour was hort lived, and Peace preently made more firm than ever.

The firt favours give a priviledge for others, and a kind of right not only to hope, but demand them: The Count, to be reveng'd of his Mitres for the piece of pite he had done him, thrut both his Arms between the Ballitres, and embracing her on the udden, kied her with that violence, that he forced Blood out of her lips. The Sultanes was o far from complaining of the rudenes of his Carees, that being charm'd with the pleaure of them, he carefully aved all the Blood on her Handkerchief to preerve it as a Trophy to hew Laura, as a mot enible mark of the extream Paion her dear Alexander had for her.

Let me acquaint you by the way with a rarity of thoe parts; that for a Woman to have been beaten by a
Man he loves, is eteemed in that Country a great evidence of affection to the party beaten. I confes uch favours are omewhat rude, but 'tis the temper of the Country, and uch is their cutom: As for the Blood that came from the lips of the Amorous Sultanes, we may believe it proceeded from a tranport of Love. With us, one may be bitten, but not beaten through extremity of this Paion; but blows exceed the limits of Gallantry, and that Woman mut be an African, that loves to be o Courted. 'Tis a fahion will never pas in Europe, and though they ue it ometimes, yet never to oblige Women; none of whom that I know of, were ever pleaed with a batinade. The ret of this viit having been pent in foolery and toys, though ometimes of much moment in matters of Love, I will not trouble you with the particulars. Laura, who was not far ditant from the Lovers, appeared at the leat ign of their pleaure to have her attend. The Count and the Sultanes bid each other adieu with the greatet kindnes imaginable: And Laura brought him to
the Door of the Apartment, o deep in Love, he carce knew where he was. He went directly from thence to the Baa, who intantly oberved the viible change of the Count's former Sadnes and Melancholy into a tender and languihing air; at which the Baa taking occaion to laugh, aid, Well, Alexander, hath Love plaid his part well?

p.hi: Is it your pain, or your pleaure hath o charm'd you to day? I confes, Sir,
p.U:
aid he with a igh, it is the pleaure I have met with; but pleaure, I fear, which may cot me much pain. The Baa believing, that to be the Confident of the Count's Paion, might be of ome ue, took him by the hand, and led him to the Garden, to take a turn in the Walks. He fell preently upon the ubject of his good Fortune, and prayed him to tell him truly, how his Affairs tood. The Count having his Heart and his Fancy all full of Love, with very great eae gave him uch a ravihing decription of his tenderet affections, and painted the pleaures he had taken that Evening o much to the life, adding his ighs and exclamations,
with getures and looks o eloquent and paionate, that he awaked in the Soul of the Baa the affection he had formerly for Laura, and lately laid aleep. What care oever is taken to cure one of this Paion, till there remains enough in the Heart of a Lover to et it on fire by the leat park that falls on it. The inenibility and reitance of Laura had not Ice enough in them to quench all the heat of the Baa's affection. She had only covered it with ahes, to preerve it the better againt another time: Had the Count acted like a Politick Lover, he had eaily foreeen, how ticklih and dangerous a buines it is, to make uch repreentations before Perons who are Amorouly inclined; and epecially before a Man whom he had reaon to conider as a Rival, and in whoe Power it was to dipoe of him as he pleaed. But the truth is, that in peaking thus of Laura, he thought he hazarded nothing of his own; he had really no kindnes for her, but hoped to do his own buines the better, in making the Baa believe that he lov'd her; which is
the reaon he did not carry himelf in this with o much caution, as he would have done in another conjuncture.

div.p:
The Baa lept not that Night. Laura appear'd a thouand times more handom and charming, in the decription of the Count, than ever he had done in his Eye at full ight. He eteemed himelf the mot unfortunate of Men, not only for that he had quitted the puruit, but had contributed o much to ee her in the Arms of another: Hereupon jealouie preently poet him, attended with a train of pite, rage, and peevihnes to torment him. What great hame, thought he, could ever happen to a Man as he was, who never found reitance from a Woman, than to have been lighted by a Slave, who was his dependent, and had yielded to another Slave as oon as he had een him? For after the paionate relation Alexander had made, the Baa made no doubt but all was concluded; he had fancies of this kind that troubled him extreamly: and if he did not then hate the Count, 'tis certain, he retained not for him that kindnes he had formerly expret towards him:
And as for Laura, though he was then more in Love with her than ever, he had a pique againt her, and could not forbear reproaching her all Night, for her want of dicretion in making greater account of a mans kindnes, that could do her no Service, than of his, by whom he might have made her Fortune. Thee thoughts were followed by others concerning his Peron. He accued himelf of baenes, and weaknes of Heart, to trouble himelf with the thoughts of a Creature that o little deerved his eteem, or to intend to hinder the atisfaction of two Lovers, whoe Love he himelf had caued and promoted. All this notwithtanding, he went on the morrow with the Count to the Seraglio; but for no other end, but to oberve the countenance of Laura, who urprized to ee him come: This is extraordinary, Sir, aid he laughing, twice in one week: What will People ay of it? As for you, aid the Baa, you will ay no ill of it, I come in o good Company; and hould others believe as formerly, that I come for love of you, you know tis not for my elf, and therefore
you are the more obliged to me. Laura very civilly thanked him for his goodnes. They fell then all three into a little dicoure of Gallantry, wherein the Baa poke o many kind things to Laura, that he might undertand part of that Amorous trouble he was in, if he had mitruted it; but he delivered himelf with uch an air, that his Complements, and kind Expreions were taken for meer effects of his good humour. But the Baa's coming thither, being under pretence of eeing the Sultanes, he could not dipence without giving her a Viit; but he was not long with her, being not able to ret till he return'd to the two Lovers, which he did with all the peed in his power. He told Laura a thouand things more obliging than formerly; and having highly careed her, gave her at parting uch a look, that if he had made the leat reflection upon it, he might have eaily perceived the kindnes he had formerly for her took fire afreh with more vehemence than ever; but he could not upect in the leat he would trouble her any more, after the kindnes he
had expret for his Alexander, and having been the intrument of the pretended Paion between her and the Count. She took all for Gallantry, and made it the ubject of raillery with the Sultanes, to whom he gave an account of all that had pat with the Baa, and with Alexander. The fair Turk went that Evening to bed, ill atisfied with her fate, having been diappointed of an Entertainment he had expected, as pleaant as that he had received the day before from her dear Chritian; he could not ufficiently lament the unluckines of the Viit given her by a man who Courted other Women, and eemed to have been born to incommode and give trouble only to her. Laura anwered in raillery, She had little reaon to complain of it to her, to whoe complaiance he was beholding for a ight of her Lover: Ah Laura, aid the Sultanes, who knows for what reaon he hath been o complaiant? You may very well believe, it was not to oblige me. I believe o, Madam, replyed Laura, but you are obliged to him however, and ought to thank him for me. After this little
raillery, they fell to dicoure, what could have brought the Baa thither that evening; and could not imagine, but it was in Complement to the Count.

The Baa by this time was fallen into a deep Melancholy, eldom appearing, but when he walked in the Garden, ometimes alone, and ometimes with Alexander, and then not a word of Laura, nor any dicoure of going again to the Apartment of the Sultanes: This troubled our Lover, who beides his affliction for being deprived of the ight of a Peron he loved better than his Life, and ceaing to ee her, mut ceae alo to live; had a thouand tormenting urmies and troubleome fancies upon the Baa's change of humour, which he could not attribute to any thing but his having taken ome umbrage and jealouie of him, on the account of the Sultanes. The Sultanes and her Confident were no les tormented on the other hand; they had een a firt, a econd, a third, and a fourth long day pas without a ight of their Alexander: Lovers are very exact Accomptants,
and keep reckoning of the very moments, but account nothing more tedious than a day of abence. What hould be the meaning of all this, aid they one to the other, having a thouand fears upon them, though they knew not of what: 'tis a difficult matter to keep any thing ecret in places of that nature. Yet they could not imagine they had given any occaion of dicoure, or that any Peron in the Apartment had made the leat dicovery of their Intrigue. At lat, on the fifth day, after abundance of Affliction, the Baa came to ee them; but, the michief of it was, that he came alone. Beides, he appeared o dull, o muing, and o much out of humour, they made no more doubt but he had melt out the Intelligence they held with the Count. But that which gave them the killing blow, and raied their fears to the height, was, that Laura having, according to her cutom, waited the Baa out of the Chamber, and asked him, what he had done with her dear Eunuch? I am jealous of him (aid the Baa, making no tay) I need tell
you no more: Laura made hat to give her Mitres the Alarm, and told her, there was no more doubt to be made, but jealouie was the caue of the Baa's not bringing Alexander with him, the Baa himelf having told her o that intant; thoe who are guilty, are eaily frightned, and fear hath this property, that it o confounds the imagination, that the lightet upicions are taken for clear and unquetionable truths. With what ighs, what tears did the poor Sultanes afflict her elf; yet not o much for the ill conequences he might apprehend from the jealouie of the Baa, as for the fear he had, that if he were really jealous of the Chritian, he hould never have a ight of him more. She did heartily wih he could have written to him, but there are few truty Meengers to be found in thoe places, where there is caue to ditrut every one you convere with; and every Eye that ees you, is a py on your actions, at leat if not gained by Money or Kindnes, wherein, after all poible care, you may be deceived, as he was in this trouble. Laura received
a Note from the Count, brought her by an Eunuch, and carried it forthwith to hew it the Sultanes, being in thee words.

Madam, the Baa every day more obliging than other, is pleaed to grant me the honour of walking with you this Evening in the Garden of the Seraglio. I know not whether you can dipene with your elf till then. Let us take the hour you think mot proper. He will be there with one of his Mitrees. Send me word, if you pleae, if I may expect this favour from you.

The Baa would never have thought of this walk, but out of the extream deire he had to know certainly, how Laura and Alexander tood affected one to the other; and that he might inform himelf of what they hould dicoure. The Garden was a place very fit for his deign, epecially by Night, where he could hear without being een. He had made the propoal to the Count, in confidence he would receive it with a great deal of joy, which in appearance he did, but without hope of any great atisfaction from the Adventure, it being carce
probable the Sultanes would permit Laura to come. But that which really troubled him, was the opinion he had, the Baa was certainly jealous of his Wife, ince he gave him o clear proof of his unwillingnes that he hould ee Laura at her Lodgings any more.
The Quetion then was, how to write to the Slave, to dipoe her for the walk. But the Count having written the Billet, the Baa ent it by an Eunuch, and tay'd for the Anwer.

The Sultanes read the Billet, and was of opinion with her Gallant, that it was for Love of her the Baa was unwilling he hould come any more to ee Laura in her Apartment. It was long ere they came to a reolution in the point, whether Laura hould agree to the aignation: Laura very wiely thought it better not to go, but the Sultanes, wholly led by her Paion, and too deeply in Love, to act any thing with reaon that concerned her affection, notwithtanding any thing Laura could ay, made her write him this Anwer.

It were to act the part of a very ill Peron, to be all alone in the Garden, while
others are diverting themelves there: I conent for pity, to come and bear you company, but on condition that you will be wie, and that we be at ome ditance from the Baa, becaue I would not be known by her, that he brings with him. If you can promie me thee two things, I am for you after the fourth Prayer, when the Sultanes is a Bed. Adieu.
This Anwer was beyond the expectation of the Count, who rejoyced extreamly at the pleaure he promied himelf with the Slave, from the dicoure of the Sultanes, while they hould continue in the Garden.

Night being come, and the fourth Prayer over, the Baa told him, he might go, and bring Laura to the Garden, while he went for one of his Mitrees, who was lodged on the other ide. It is the cutom of the Grandees of that Country, among a multitude of Women they have in their Seraglio, when they have not a particular inclination for any one, to take this to day, and another to morrow; and having lot the tat of Love, to earch for Pleaure in change and variety.

It may be eaily imagined, that Alexander received this Commiion with a great deal of joy, and was in no mall hate to go to the Sultanees Lodgings. She who was charmed at the ight of him, could not expres her joy without a thouand tranports of Love, and the mot tender carees a mot paionate Lady could poibly make her dearet Lover. Alexander did his part to admiration, not only returning tranport for tranport, and cares for cares, but excelling his pattern, Love working in him, or he in the Sultanes uch things as gave her very great atisfaction. It may be admired peradventure that two Perons o little acquainted, hould in o few days become o very good Friends. But we mut know, Love in thee hot Countries makes far quicker progres than in the cold, where the Winds, and the Snow, and the Rain poil his Wings, and hinder his flight: Whereas on the contrary, the Sun is there almot till at the height, and Love being a tender Infant, and going always naked, thrives there the better, where he finds Hearts very well
dipoed, and ready to take fire.

The Count, who could not tay long there, was willing to betow the mall time he had to pend with the Sultanes in gentle reproaches for her permitting Laura to come and walk with him. You have, aid he, a very good opinion of my Affection, Madam, or ele you love me with a great deal of indifference, that this does not in the leat trouble you at all. The Sultanes anwered, he relied not o much on his Fidelity, as on Laura's Dicretion, whom he knew too well, to think he would betray her. Look you to your elf, as for her I place a confidence in her, and if you do your Duty, I am perwaded he will not be wanting in hers. Having thus poken, he would not detain him longer for fear of the Baa, but retired to the Chamber. The happy Lover, very well pleas'd with the lucky moment he had pat with the Sultanes, asked Laura if he were ready; She made him anwer, he hould not tay for her longer than while he fetched her Barnus, which is a kind of Hood that covers them from Head to Foot. The Count eeing her return
mufled up in that Garment, went his way before, according to their cutom there, and he followed: He aid not a word to her while they were in the Seraglio, for fear of being over-heard, and dicovered; but being arrived in the Garden, where they had liberty enough, Who will believe, Madam, aid he, but we made an Amorous aignation, being come to a place of Rendezvouz o fit for the purpoe. And the Baa will not fail to think us the happiet Lovers in the World. Laura made him no anwer, but kept on her way, till they came to the Bower that was aigned them at a convenient ditance from the Baa's, as Laura had deired. The Count gave her his hand, and knowing very well every turn in thoe Walks, which he viited almot every day, he made her it on a eat of green Turf made for the purpoe. Then, aid he, this, Madam, is to try a mans Fidelity with a Witnes, to expoe him to pas part of the Night in uch a place as this with a Lady o beautiful as you. Surely the Sultanes will hence-forward ret aured of my Paion. The Count made a paue, expecting her anwer,
but not receiving a word from her, he proceeded, telling her, I thought we had not been o debarred the pleaures of an Aignation, but we might have enjoy'd that of dicoure; but for ought I perceive, you mean to follow the fahion of Turky; & ince 'tis a favour in this Country for a Woman to hew her elf, or peak to a Man, you will deprive me of the one and the other: But while we are together, I pray let us live after the mode of our Country, which is far better than the Turkih. To do otherwie with me, were altogether too rigorous, and more, I believe, than you have promied the Sultanes, or he expects at your hands. Away, I beeech you, aid he, taking her by the Barnus, with this ufeles Hood, and do me the favour to tell me ome News of the Sultanes; or if you pleae, of the Adventures brought, you hither, which from the day I firt had the honour to ee you, I have had an extream longing to ask you: This you will not deny me, if you think I may be any way ueful to you, as I doubt not but I may, being your Country-man, and o well eteemed by the Baa, as to be able to
do you ome Service. All this Dicoure o obliging for Laura, he heard, without replying a word, or quitting her Barnus, as he had deired. The Count eeing this, preed her no further, but with more erious air aid, if you deire, Madam, to pas the Evening in this manner, it will be very unfortunate for me; but I mut comply. And removing a few paces from her, he went and at him down in a corner of the Bower, where he continued a while without peaking a word. The fair Lady fetched a igh, as if he had been dipleaed at his quitting her. The Count laying hold on that occaion to be even with her, took his turn of tormenting, in not anwering her ighs. At lat he came to him, took him by the Arm, and embraced him, with many grimaces, as if he would have turned all into ridicule. The Count fell a laughing, and aid, Madam, I beeech you be atisfied with the Sacrifice I make to Love, without trying my patience any further; let us, if you pleae, have a little converation, but anwer me when I peak, for I do not love talking to my elf.
