But all would not do; he laughed under her Hood, and took pleaure in vexing him. The Count at lat growing impatient; This is too much, Madam, aid he, and ince you will needs laugh, I'le hew you a trick hall make you peak in pight of your Heart; having aid o, he took her in his Arms, and not being able to take off her Hood, he ued ome Familiarities with her, would have forced peech from a Maid of Laura's Dicretion and Modety: But the Lady was till ilent, and o little concerned, that he carce made any reitance. At which the Count was extreamly urpriz'd, and after all the eteem he had for Laura, apprehended there might be a deign in the buines, and that he was abued: Then it was he did all in his power to get ight of her through a little glimmering of light that came into the Bower. Did the Sultanes know, aid he, the liberty you allow me, he would give you no thanks for your ilence, or your being hie of affording me a ight of you, which it eems you do to give me occaion to attempt greater matters,
and deny me mall favours to grant me the principal. The fair Lady not able to defend her elf longer, quitted her Barnus, and having ecap'd out of his hands, Ah, little Traytor, aid he, is this the Fidelity you have promied me? Oh Heavens, Madam, aid he, is it you? It was the Sultanes her elf had taken Laura's place, and you may imagine what a pleaant urprize this was to the Count, who could not on the udden otherwie expres it than by his exclamations; and running after her (who fled not too fat) he overtook her at the Door of the Bower, and embracing her mot tenderly, My dear Sultanes, aid he the econd time, is it you? Yes, anwered he (uffering her elf to be gently brought back into the Bower) it is I, who repent me already of what I have done for you who did not deerve it. Did you think me o imple, to expoe into the hands of another, that which I hold mot dear in the World? Do not I ee how ill it is truting of you? Your Contancy was very tottering; it was at leat half overcome. And had Laura, the
counterfeit Laura anwered your offers, where would you have been? Never was Man more confounded than the Count at all thee Reproaches: He made a free Confeion, but excued himelf by her carriage towards him, alledging it impoible for any Man to have withtood the attaques he had made. At lat, he carried the Caue, all was accommodated, an Agreement made, and Love igned the Articles.

To come in earch of a Gallant (as the Sultanes had done) into a Garden where he knew her Husband was preent, was an Adventure omewhat bold: And doubtles, there are many Women who will condemn her conduct as imprudent; but of thoe who are in Love there, are few, who being in her place, would not take the ame coure. The Baa, though accompanied with a very Beautiful Peron, pat away time omewhat wore than the Count: Chabania his Mitres had (beides Beauty) an excellent Wit, and a very taking carriage, which made her pas for the mot charming Peron in the Seraglio.
The Baa had formerly been deeply in Love with her; but Love for convenience is not very durable: Her Patron was not in an humour to Entertain her that Evening, and had not brought her with him into the Garden, but to erve for a pretence to colour other deigns; he apprehended as much, as oon as he knew that Laura was in the Garden, which the Baa unluckily told her, thinking he might atisfie her in that point, by letting her know that Laura was deeply in Love with Alexander, in whoe company he was. But Chabania was o far from believing it, that he preently fancied Alexander to be no other than the Baa's Confident in the affair, and that he had not brought Laura into the Garden but for his Mater: he had been formerly jealous of him, even to ditraction, and I know not how it came to pas the Baa was o overeen, as not to have made choice of ome other of his Women, who might have been more for his turn on this occaion: She was at her wits end for the mall countenance he gave her; all the while he was with her he had
carcely fewer words from him, and aw clearly his thoughts were wholly of Laura. This was vexation enough for a Woman in Love, who knows her elf handom, and is high pirited withal. But that which put her into abolute depair, was, that the Baa not able to obtain any truce from his jealouie, having pent ome time in her company, without any cares, or giving her the leat evidence of kindnes, though he had more than once given him occaion to hew it; told her, he had a longing deire to go hearken, and know how the Chritians in the Bower entertained one another: he made him no anwer, but letting him go, he the next minute after went another way towards the ame Bower to oberve the Baa, and ee what he did there.

The Nights in that Country are very clear, epecially in Summer: the Baa, notwithtanding all the caution he had ued to pot himelf ecurely near Alexander's quarter, under the favour of the Hedges that covered his approach, was perceived by the counterfeit Laura in the Bower. She had
dicovered him by his hadow, and having made her lover aware of it, he preently went out, and ran to meet the Baa, to intreat him not to come any further, but permit him to enjoy that moment of pleaure he had been pleaed to procure him. The Sultanes not knowing what wind had brought the Baa to that ide of the Garden, and fearing he would come into the Bower, would not be perwaded by any thing that Alexander could ay to her, to tay after him in the Bower, but went preently out to hide herelf in ome corner of the Garden, where he thought he might be in better ecurity.

The mean time the jealous Baa, confounded at the dicovery, and having lot the opportunity of executing the deign he had o unfortunately laid, uffered himelf to be prevail'd upon by the intreaties of his Rival, and returned towards his Bower, as Alexander to his; where being arrived, he was ufficiently amaz'd at miing the Sultanes, but thought he had fled away for fear, which troubled him extreamly; but jut as he was leaving
the Bower to go in earch of her, he aw in the furthet and mot retired part of it, omething that eem'd to have the hape of a Woman: then going up thither, and finding he had not been mitaken, he fancied it only to be a trick of the Sultanes; this pleaed him extreamly, and paionately imbracing her, Madam, aid he, are not you very waggih? you would fain have made me run all about the Garden in earch of you: She anwered not a word, but getting out of his arms, he went away briskly, and withdrew into another corner of the Bower: the Count was urprized at this manner of proceeding, being not o gentle as he expected from the Sultanes, who loved him o tenderly; but to undeceive himelf as oon as he could, and to find out the caue of o udden a change, he went up to her the econd time, and taking her by the hand; What may be the reaon, Madam, aid he, that you run away, and hide your elf from me? there is no fear of the Baa; he is withdrawn to his quarter, and hath promied not to give us any further diturbance. But all this could not make her
anwer a word; o that not knowing what to think of this rigour, he kneeled on the ground where he was itting on a eat of green Turf, and kiing her hand, prayed her for loves ake, to tell him the reaon why he eemed angry with him; he courted and imbraced her with great paion and tendernes, and he as patiently took it, but at lat perceiving her laugh a laughter very different from that of the Sultanes, he examined her more nearly, and knew by the difference of her hape, and her Cloaths, that he was mitaken. It was inconceivable, what a trouble this put him in. He thought himelf arrived in Fairy-land, to ee the tranget ights in the World. That Laura had been changed into the Sultanes, was not o urprizing as pleaant, but that the Sultanes hould be turned into another Woman, and perhaps a Mitres of the Baa's, this was the thing he could not comprehend: that which troubled him mot, and extreamly diquieted him, was the pain he was in, for not knowing what was become of the Sultanes; and the fear he had, the Baa might have met her
in the Garden, and known her: this moved him again to go out in earch of her, but Chabania (for it was he he had mitaken for the Sultanes) held him fat by the leeve, and taid him, telling him in the Moors Language, it was not fit for him to quit in that manner a Lady for whom he had already expres'd ome affection. The Count undertood not her language, prayed her to let him go for fear the Baa hould come, and be offended at his being with her. But all to no purpoe, he no more undertood his Italian, than he her Moreque, and was o far from letting him go, that he would have made him it by her, that he might revenge her elf on the Baa for the light he had put upon her. During this little contet, which could not but be omewhat extraordinary between two Perons who undertood not one another, the Sultanes comes in quite out of breath, and throws her elf half dead into the arms of Alexander, who happened to be in a place ready to receive her. What frightful fancies had he then in his head? He preently imagined they were utterly
undone, and that he had been dicovered. But the Baa arriving preently after, et him right again in aying, you run away Madam, peaking to the counterfeit Laura, from a Peron who wihes you no ill, nor intends you any; then turning towards Alexander, he was about to excue himelf to him for breaking his word, but eeing Chabania tand by him, he uddenly altered both his mind and his Language, asking her in Moreque what he was come thither for. She anwered him aloud, and gave him a thouand reproaches for his unworthines and weaknes in quitting her, to follow a Slave that run away from him. This was a very rare Scene, and the Dialogue not a little pleaing to the Sultanes; but he had not long to laugh at it, for Chabania being vext to the heart for the light the Baa had put upon her, and for what he had aid to her before her pretended rival, flew like a Fury upon the Sultanes, with that promptitude and wiftnes, that neither the Baa, nor Alexander, who would have taid her, were able to ave the counterfeit Laura from being
omewhat ill handled. The Count was touched to the quick at this outrage, and no conideration of life or of duty, could have prevented him from having atisfaction, had not his fear of loing the Sultanes prevailed more upon him than his reentment. The Baa was as angry as he, and taking the enraged Chabania by the hand, he drew her omewhat rudely out of the Bower, and led her away.

The Count was no ooner alone with the Sultanes, but embracing her tenderly, Madam, aid he, with a paionate tone, what dangers have you gone through for love of me! what a cruel aault have you but now endured? The Sultanes did nothing but laugh at the lat adventure he had been in, and told him he took more pleaure to ee Chabania's depair, (for whom he had ever a natural averion) than he had uffered of harm by her outrage and violence. But he confeed the ame time, that he was in extream perplexity when he met the Baa ranging over the Garden in earch of that Woman, and that it was the highet piece of good fortune imaginable, that he had
her Barnus with her, to hide her elf in. She added that her dear Husband had aid to her a thouand gallant things, and had done alo ome things a little extraordinary; but that it was her good fortune to be not far from the Bower, and to make her ecape: he told him further, that there remained no more doubt of the Baa's being newly fallen in love with Laura, and that he was very well aured of it by the kindnes of his expreions, and the tranports he oberved him in at this rencounter; that this was the true caue of all their alarms, and the reaon why he brought him not into the Seraglio as formerly: The Count was of the ame judgment, and both held it neceary to make good ue of the occaion, and that Laura who was to act the principal part, hould imploy her bet addres and complaiance in their favour.

The Baa taking mall pleaure in the Garden after the unhappy ucces of his amorous deigns, having done his endeavour to pacifie Chabania, would bring her back to her Lodgings, and pas'd by Alexander's Bower, to let
him undertand it was time to with draw. The Count followed him immediately, being extreamly joyful to have come off o happily from a walk that had prov'd o full of adventures: He bore his dear Sultanes company into her Apartment, where he taid not long for fear of the Baa, but withdrew to his lodging. He pat the ret of the night very pleaantly, though he lept not at all; and the truth is, he had reaon enough to be well pleaed, though his Patron had not, who was more labouring under mortal afflictions: Laura, whom he now was more deeply in Love with than ever, put him in depair by her Rigours and Cruelties: if no more pity from her, then no more pleaure to be expected in his life. His great affection for Alexander could not keep him from being his rival, and wihing to hare with him in the favours he did him. His paion was arrived at a point which is the highet of ufferings, that of not being loved: and when he thought of the opportunity he had let lip the night before, when he had Laura in his power, he was o cruelly
vext, he could have found in his heart to be revenged of himelf: yet he had no great caue to blame his dicretion, for he had done enough, and unles he would have driven his Gallantry to the lat puh of all, he could not have done more. He was not willing to declare himelf to Alexander, nor acquaint him with the thoughts he had newly entertained, as well to prevent the dipleaure he believed it would give him, as for that he conceived the Count might be of ue to him in the deign, and that the dicovery might be to his prejudice.

In the Morning as oon as he was up, he went (as he ometimes was ued) to the Count's Chamber without any attendant, and found him in Bed: A Man, aid he, mut be as happy as Alexander in his Love, before he can leep as quietly as he. If there be any, anwered the Count, hath caue to commend his good fortune on that account, it mut without doubt be a Peron of your comlines and Gallantry, who to gain love, need no more than ay you are in love. Yes, replied the Baa, with a mile, except it be to Laura,
who hath made me very enible that I can igh to no purpoe, and that the mater of her peron may not be the mater of her heart; It was neceary that Alexander hould come from Europe to Africk to make that Conquet: This, Sir, replyed the Count, may be an intance of the Vagaries and Extravagancies of Love, who often knows not where to fix, but follows the effects of detiny, or the Stars which are predominant over the affections. And I believe Sir, added he miling, as for the Love of Laura, you are already very well atisfied, and o little concerned where he betows it, that you never deigned to make me in Love with her, that you might be my Rival. However, aid he, oberving the Baa igh, I aure you, hould it o happen, you cannot do me a greater favour than in letting me know it. And you hall find that all the paion I can have for her, hall not hinder any performance of the duty I owe you. I will quit all my pretentions as I know you have the leat deign upon her, that I may prevent all dipute with a Peron to whom I am o deeply oblig'd, that
there can be nothing o dear to me, but I will part with it for your ake. Believe it Alexander, anwered the Baa, it is not o eaie a matter to be diingaged from a paion like yours: you may as well perwade me, you cannot be in Love. I am certainly in Love, replied the Count, and it may be as deeply as poible; but having o many favours daily heaped on me from you, there is nothing in the World I hall Love more than your repoe and atisfaction: And, Sir, if Laura appear now as amiable as formerly to you, I mut tell you again, I love her no longer; o eaie a matter was it for the ubtile Italian to be generous in parting with that in which he was o little concerned. The Baa asked him if he would ay as much before Laura. He anwered, he believed him too jut and too gallant to deire him to make a declaration of that nature before one who had been his Mitres. At lat the Baa propoed another walk in the Garden that very day, and at the ame time prayed him to write about it to Laura; which the Count having not
been able to avoid, received this anwer.

The burnt child dreads the fire; we do not commonly expoe our elves twice to the ame danger. The Baa's uage of me lat night, gives me mall encouragement to trut him the econd time. And you are an eye-witnes how ill I was handled by her he had with him. Let it atisfie you, that if you come hither, I will have the honour to ee you. But no more walking.

The Baa much troubled at o unexpected an anwer, went out of the Counts Chamber without aying a word, and pas'd in olitude the ret of the day. But in the Evening he went to the Sultanes, where he preently met Laura; who inquiring of Alexander, and why he had not brought him with him; would it dipleae you, aid the Baa, if I upplied his place this Evening: that were too great an honour for me, replied Laura miling, but the Sultanes expects you, and is not very well. The Baa gave her his hand, and would have led her into a private Chamber; Laura perceiving it, and that he was in good earnet,
Prayed him to let her go; that her Lady was not well, and he knew well enough he could not endure her being a moment out of her ight: I, I, replied the Baa, the Sultanes is ick, and cannot be a moment without you; but 'tis becaue 'tis I deire to pas that moment with you; had it been Alexander you could have taid a little longer. The Baa aid this with o pleaant a tone, he could not forbear laughing. You know Sir, replied he, 'tis another cae when you are with the Sultanes. Beides Sir, added he miling, one would venture a little for a Sweet-heart: Well, well, aid he, preing her to go along with him, 'tis Love hath brought me hither: I, Sir, anwer'd he triving to get away from him, and 'tis Love obliges me to avoid the occaion of being found alone in your company; for though I know you a mot accomplihed Peron, you will allow me to tell you, you have not too much repect for our Sex, and 'tis very hard truting you, witnes your aaults lat night in the Garden. the Baa made her a thouand Oaths he would keep within the bounds of
that repect and dicretion he might expect from the everet vertue, and proteted he deired only one quarter of an hours dicoure. Laura, who knew the violence and obtinacy of his humour, when denyed any thing he held reaonable to be granted him, dipoed her elf to entertain him that quarter of an hour. He reproached her a thouand times for her hardnes and cruelty againt him, and gave her withall the kindet words and the mot tender and paionate expreions imaginable. Laura, to defend her elf, pleaded her Honour, her Religion, and her Duty to the Sultanes her Mitres; three things he would not betray for the World: Had you but a little Love for me, aid the Baa with a igh, you would not find o many reaons for defence. I have my Religion as you have yours, and the Precepts of it perhaps as evere as yours; but Love is tronger than all the Precepts, the Laws, the Religions of the World, and thoe who erve him, worhip no other God. As for the Sultanes, how are you concerned, that is my buines, not yours; and it hall be your fault, if
ever he know it. But what do you tell me of Honour?

Surely 'tis more for your Honour to love a Man as I am, than to love uch a one as Alexander. You mitake your elf, Sir, anwered Laura, if you think that in the viits he hath made me, there hath any thing pas'd contrary to my duty 'Tis not with thoe of our Nation, as with the People of this Country: We may be together, and no body by, yet my Honour ecure. I wear to you, Sir, Alexander never received that favour from me, which I could not afford the Peron for whom I am the leat concerned in the World. The Baa interrupted her; what, not in the Garden? Neither in the Garden nor any where ele, replyed he, had he ever any other advantage than a ight of me, which with us is accounted for nothing. Can you make me believe, anwered the Baa, what you ay? Laura told him, there was nothing more true, and he might ret aured of it: But Sir, aid he, for your better atisfaction, bring him no more hither, and you hall ee whether I make my complaint for it: 'Twere pitty, replyed
the Baa, to detroy o fair a friendhip; and I do protet to you, that were it in my power, I would give you no trouble, but I am not o much Mater of my elf, to gain this point on my heart, to be unconcerned in your Love: But ince you love Alexander with o much indifference, that you can o eaily reolve not to ee him more, I have no caue to afflict my elf, but rather to hope you may one day love me perhaps as much as you do him.

After thee words the Baa retired, with a heart a little better at eae than when he came in, but as deeply in Love as before. He gave not an intire and firm credit to what Laura had told him of her indifference and mall concernment for Alexander, but did believe her paion for the Chritian not o great as he had imagined, or that their Love had been cooled by ome quarrel, for he had oberved on the one ide and the other, more indifference than is uually conitent with that paion.

But then reflecting uddenly on himelf, may not this be (aid he, reuming
his jealouie and diffidence,) an effect of their policy? may they not be agreed to deceive me? and being already ufficiently aured of one anothers affections, may they not pretend they have no Love for one another, that they may Love one another with greater ecurity? No, no, adds he, this cannot be, there is no hiding of Love, it will appear if not mothered to death: She love not Alexander at all, or loves him but indifferently; thus he the more eaily perwaded himelf to be o, in that he did mot paionately deire it might be o; and thence-forward his paion increaed o fat, it became greater than ever. Hope being a paion that more than any other foments that of Love, eaily promies it elf happy events, and flatters it elf with expectation of good fortune and ucces.

Laura gave the Sultanes an accompt of all the pleaant dicoure; and the Sultanes could have wihed Laura had not been altogether o evere to the Baa, but a little more kind and complaiant, without which he thought they could not ee Alexander o often
as he deired. Laura on the contrary told her, that to have been complaiant, would have poyl'd all, for that the Baa would then have entertained ome hopes of favour from her, and o become more amorous than before, and conequently more jealous of his uppoed Rival than ever. What hall I do then, aid the poor Sultanes, who can do nothing but fear, and cannot expect any thing but croes and mifortunes? Laura told her, things were not in o deperate a condition, that he need trouble her elf for it, for the Baa had promied to end Alexander on the morrow, and that they would conider with him how to order their buines.

The Count did not know that the Baa had been with the Sultanes; but having not heard from him that day, he went on the morrow to wait on him at his riing. He found him abed, o dejected and melancholy, that he might by his countenance eaily dicover the heavines of his heart. Yet he received him with that air of kindnes and friendhip might well aure the Count, he was not dipleaed with
him. The Baa was ilent a while, and then looking on the Count with an air of friendhip and confidence; Alexander, aid he, I am the mot unfortunate of men, epecially, in Love. Laura, added he, ighing, the cruel Laura hath not the leat tendernes for me; no, not the leat pity for the torments he ees me uffer for her: and unles you will be a little kind to me, I know not what will become of me. Ah Sir, anwered the Count, let me but know what you deire of me, and what I can do for you: you know it is not in my power to dipoe of others hearts; but if I may contribute to your atisfaction; if you would have me peak to her; if—How happy hould I be, aid the Baa, interrupting him, would you do what you can. Sir, replyed the Count, if it depend upon me, you may promie your elf ucces. The Baa held his peace for a little time, as if he tudied what to ay; but Alexander preing him to declare himelf, he told him with ome trouble, that he hould appoint an aignation with Laura in a Chamber, in the Apartment of-the Sultanes,
where the Baa might meet her in his tead. The Propoal was o unworthy and unfit for Alexander to conent to, that it atonih'd him on the udden o extreamly, that having bluh'd at it very much, he knew not what anwer to make. The Baa oberved the diorder he was in, and was more out of countenance at it than the Count; but for fear he hould interpret it otherwie than intended, and taking his bluhing for no very good Omen, he told him, (to be rid of him) that he might go think of it, and that if he gave him any anwer, it hould be a favourable one.

The Count went out of the Chamber, and made a thouand reflections on his ill Fortune, which had reduced him to the extremity of making him erve uch a peron; not but that he was fully perwaded, Laura would not come, and that he hould be little concerned, though he hould entertain the motion, and favour the paion of his amorous Patron: but beides the baenes of the imployment he put him upon, he was mad to think he took him for uch a Villain, that loving a
Maid, as the Baa believed he did Laura, could betray her o baely. This was the only thing troubled him, nor would he have done it, though he died for it.

The Baa having een him leave his Chamber in that manner, thought there was mall hope of effecting his deign that way; yet being a peron of great reaon and worth, he was o far from thinking the wore of the Count, or being offended with him on this occaion, that he eteemed of him the better, and conidered of other means to gain atisfaction to his love in the enjoyment of Laura. His paion was now arrived at a height beyond the power of reaon to manage, and capable to put him on any enterprize whatever. The mot vertuous of men when changed into a deperate Lover, become the mot furious and extravagant of all; being o much more enible of lights put upon him, as he conceives himelf a peron of merit.

This tranported Lover having failed of his deign to make Alexander of his Party, to erve his ends in a Propoal
that included Treachery, reolved to deceive Laura himelf, by going to ee her that night diguied as an Eunuch. The deign was not very well laid, but it took, as hall appear by the equel. He had not the patience to tay till his ordinary hour of going to the Sultanes; but as oon as 'twas night, he went away diguied like an Eunuch, and came to the apartment, where he found one old Moor at the gate, who not taking o much notice of him as to know him, he ent her to Laura, to tell her that an Eunuch of her acquaintance deired to peak with her in the Chamber of repoe; o called becaue it was retired, and far from noie, and the place where they ued to take ome hours ret after dinner in Summer. He made choice of this Chamber as the mot proper for his deign; and the old Woman was no ooner gone about her meage, but he went to hide him there. Laura was then buie, and the Sultanes having caually met the old Woman in earch of Laura, asked her, what he would have with her? the old Woman having had no order to keep private
her buines, told her freely, there was an Eunuch deired to peak with her in the Chamber of Repoe. The Sultanes hearing of an Eunuch who would peak with Laura, made no quetion at all but Alexander was the Man; and without further enquiry what kind of Man the Eunuch was, or any other conideration, he takes Laura's Barnus, and goes to the place of aignation; had he made the leat reflection on the meage, he could not have been o deceived, nor have expoed her elf o eaily to the danger he went into. It was not the cutom of her Gallant to ue her thus, or to ee her any where but in the Alcove-chamber; he carce knew the name of the Chamber where he was told he taid for Laura, and knowing what he did of the Baa, he had reaon to mitrut him. But thoe who are in Love as the Sultanes was, are ubject to greater over-ights than thee. She knew that Alexander was not to ee her but by night, yet he waited for him from the firt moment he awoke in the morning; and in this amorous expectation, which tantalized her extreamly,
and kept her in a mortal inquietude whether he came or came not, there needed no help to hurry her away when the time drew near. Women who have been in Love, will eaily confes there is nothing o hard as to be prudent on uch occaions, and that the name of their Gallant when expected, hath made them tart up for joy, and run to meet him e're they knew whether he were come.

The paionate Sultanes having given up her elf to be led blind-fold, where he thought Love waited for her, borrowed wings of that God to carry her the ooner into that Chamber; there was not any light there, but this did not urprize her, it being not uual to place any in that Chamber. She pleaed her elf with the fancy of putting a Love-trick on Alexander, by making him take her once more for Laura; this made her reolve to be ilent a while, as he had been in the Garden, and to divert her elf that way. But as he was entring, he was taken with a hivering all over, and uch a udden fear, that he was on the point of going back again. But the Gallant who
waited for her, having taken her by the Hand, he began to recollect her elf, and went along with him where he pleas'd: he led her away to the further end of the Chamber, where he was o loth to loe time for making ue of the occaion, that embracing her with ome tranport, though trembling withal, he had almot put it out of her power to defend her elf. The Sultanes thinking this action too violent to be Alexander's, began to mitrut; and having given him his liberty till then, he did the utmot in her power to reit him, and knew, though a little too late, that he was abued, and that this Man had neither the hape, nor the tature, nor face of her Alexander, and that it mut be the Baa, which ome marks he knew about him, oon put out of quetion, he changed her method, and tood upon her guard. The reitance he made after the kindnes he expret at the firt, was oberved by the Gallant, and made him perceive that the cheat was dicovered, and no hopes of hiding himelf. So that without further dallying he made his lat efforts, and rendred
thoe of the Sultanes o ueles, that he obtained his deign. This tranported Lover was happy at leat in conceit, which ufficiently proves the power of imagination, and that our greatet pleaures proceed from it. I am ure, there is no unfortunate Lover but may envy his mitake, and that chance could not put a greater obligation on any Man, than this on the Baa. His paion thus atisfied, he withdrew, without aying a word, and the Lady made all the hate he could to her Chamber, for fear the paionate Baa hould renew the aault. Laura who had been much troubled at miing of her, was no les amazed to ee her come in the condition he was in, which made her throw her elf on the Bed; where half weeping, half laughing, he told her the tory of the adventure: At which Laura did nothing but laugh, expecting very pleaant concluions from o comical beginnings.

The Count had been at the Baa's in the Evening, and not finding him within, came on the Morrow to acquaint him with the reolution he had
taken on the propoal. As he entred the apartment, he was told that the Baa had been ill that night, and had not lept at all, and that he had forbidden any entrance into his Chamber; but the Count having more priviledg than others, they let him pas, and he found him abed, and writing with o ad a meen, and o dejected a countenance, that the Count preently concluded he had had a very ill night; eeing Alexander on the udden, he coloured a little; but the Count laying one knee to the ground, I come, Sir, aid he, to beg one favour more of you: You are the principal Author of all the Love I am engaged in; it is my misfortune that you feel the ame paion. Accept, I beeech you, the acrifice I make you Sir, I will never love, and if you will have it o, I will never ee Laura more. Bles me! cryed the Baa, what Lovers are thee! is it poible that two perons who began to love one another with o tender affection, can part with uch eae? and that I, who am not beloved, cannot bring my elf to this: peak Alexander, and tell me whether it proceeds from
any ditat you have taken, or that you do it for my ake. No Sir, anwered the Count, Laura is this day as amiable in my eyes as the firt day I aw her; but rather than ee you in the condition I find you in, I will not pare the doing my elf any violence I am capable of; and for your quiet and my own, I heartily wih. I never had een her. This example is o rare, replyed the Baa, that nothing les than the eteem I have for you, can make it credible. In the mean time this Billet will let you ee, that I have not taid for you to et me a Preident, but that I know in my turn how to give Preidents for others to imitate, but not to out-do. It is written to Laura, read it: And there it will appear to you, that if I have done you wrong, I know how to punih my elf for it. I hould be heartily orry, o virtuous and excellent a peron as you, hould part from us, with an ill opinion of me. The Count extreamly urprized at this dicoure, not comprehending the reaon of it, after an anwer full of repect and acknowledgment to his dear Patron, took the Billet, and there read thee words.

If all the paion Man can have for a Woman, is not capable to jutifie the crime I committed againt you, you ought to pardon me, at leat having uffered in one night all the torments and afflictions of a cruel repentance, which yet fills my oul with grief and confuion. And if by giving you and your Lover your Liberty, I may in ome meaure make amends for my faults, you may make you ready for your voyage, for to morrow morning you hall go both together. Farewel, and think of the violence I did my elf, in forcing from my boom two perons, whom of all I ever aw, I loved mot entirely, and then you will find me not altogether unworthy of pardon.

The Count was o confounded at reading the Billet, as never was Man, and had much ado to hide the diorder it put him in; he kneeled the econd time, as it were to give the Baa thanks for this lat favour, which before his engagement in Love with the Sultanes, had been the greatet he could have done him; but now after his paion, it was certainly the greatet misfortune could befal him. He was willing by this action to hide from
the Baa the trouble he was in. But the Baa took him up, and told him, he could not ee him in that poture, for a buines where he had more caue to complain of him, than to thank him, that he hould know at leiure the whole matter from Laura, and that in the mean time he had nothing to do but prepare for his voyage; that he had given order to tay a Chritian Veel, which hould have gone off that very day for Italy, and hould land them at Legorn; that the weather was fair, and that without fail he hould embark with Laura on the morrow: for all which he gave him his word.

The Count having taken leave of the Baa, went out of the Chamber with a heart o full of trouble and affliction, for the News he had received, that he wanted a more proper place to comfort himelf, and to vent his thoughts of the reolution the Baa had taken to give him his Liberty, and to end Laura with him. He knew not what might have obliged him to a reolution of this nature, though upon reading the Billet, he did imagine, the Baa had committed ome outrage on
Laura; but this was not the thing troubled him; it was the Sultanes, from whom he mut part, and mut bid her adieu for ever: to part with a Woman one loved o tenderly, to part with her for ever, and to part with her in the height of his paion, ounds very harh, and where is the Lover could take uch a reolution for any reaon what-ever? Yet Liberty, which to a Man who knows what 'tis to be a Slave, to a Man of Alexander's quality, is a thing o attractive; to return to his Countrey after eight or nine months abence; the pleaure of Rome, and the conideration that if he lot this opportunity, he might perhaps never have uch another; all this, I ay, made uch a Party, that the mot beautiful, and mot charming Lady in the World, could not have hindred many excellent perons from quitting hers to take it. But true Love which values nothing above its own atisfaction, lights a liberty to be bought with too many tears: yet in this conjuncture, it was almot impoible for Alexander to refue this cruel liberty, being all he could in appearance deire, and betowed
on him by the Baa, with a Mitres with whom he believed him paionately in love. What reaon could he find to refue uch a Preent which had cot the Baa o dear, and ought to be the mot acceptable to him? He depaired to find any, and aw clearly there was a neceity of parting, unles Love, favourable to Lovers in extremity, would come to his aid, and make the Baa alter his reolution, as they commonly do who take any againt Love; never did Slave pay more Vows to be delivered from his Chain, than he did for the continuance of his Captivity, chooing rather to be a Slave the ret of his Life, than to be for ever removed to uch a ditance from that which he loved a thouand times more than his Liberty.

The Baa having paed ome hours after in his Bed, to mue upon the reolution he had taken, which he adhered to, though it made his heart ake, called for his Aga, and gave him orders for the departure of the two Chritians, cauing tore of Proviions, and very rich Preents to be carried on
board the Veel; this done he ent his chief Eunuch to the Sultanes his Wife, to intreat her to give Laura her Liberty, whom he was minded to end home to her Country, together with Alexander, for reaons of importance to her, as of neceity for him, and for the eae and repoe of one and the other. Having given thee orders, and the ame time ent the Letter he had written to Laura, he took Hore for Bardou, one of his Houes of Pleaure, a mile from the Town, and taid there till midnight, having all that time walked alone in the Gardens, to wean himelf from the ight and company of Alexander, and the pleaure he took in Laura's dicoure.

That night the Baa could not leep, and in the Morning his Aga being come to bring him an anwer from the Sultanes, as to his requet for giving Laura her Liberty; he went preently to carry it to Alexander, whom he found in appearance ready to be gone, but in truth never les dipoed, but hoping every moment ome change of reolution in the Baa. Ah, Alexander, aid he, we mut part, but I
know not how we hall; for the Sultanes who loves Laura with the ame affection I do you, notwithtanding my repreenting to her how much he was concerned in interet to have us part, and to deire it as much as I, cannot reolve upon it, but hath ent me word this Morning he will ooner looe her Life than her Laura. You mut go ee Laura, and tell her, 'twill be her fault if he be not free, and go along with you; for as for me, what I have promied I will perform. In the mean time I will give order that the Veel be taid longer, that it may not ail without you. Sir, anwered Alexander, there are frequent opportunities of Tranportation, and when you have given ome longer time to atisfie the Sultanes, and dipoe her to grant Laura this favour, our obligation then will not be les for our Liberty you are now pleaed to grant us. Alexander, replied the Baa, reolutions like that I have now taken in your favour, go o much againt the grain of a heart affected as mine, that delays may be dangerous, and time may make them faulter: make ue of the good
motions reaon and equity have inpired into me. I do not tell you my thoughts are unalterable. The pite I have againt my heart for its weaknes, the outrage I did Laura yeterday; my hame to appear before her after it, and the mall hopes I have of gaining her Love, are the true caues of your good fortune: All this is yet freh in my mind; tay not till time deface thee impreions, there being nothing men are apt o oon to forget, as the injuries they had done to others.

As they were dicouring together, a huge Moor who erved as Purveyor for the Count, and brought him every Morning his Proviion from the Seraglio, came on the udden into the Chamber with a great Basket on his head, not thinking (without doubt) of the Baa's being there. The Moor tarted at the ight of him, would have gone back, but the Baa with his hand made igns for him to tay; he obeyed, and laid the Basket on the ground, which appeared very heavy, and o he withdrew; the Baa, of pure curioity to ee what they had ent Alexander to eat, bid a Moor, who waited in the
Room, take up the Basket lid, which he did, and found the Proviion to be a Woman very pleaantly tucked up and mufled in her Barnus that he might not be known. But being in the Habit of a Chritian (which the Baa and Alexander had formerly een Laura in) they made no doubt but it was he. The Baa at firt was very much urprized, but then fell a laughing, and aid to the Count, the Invention is rare, and that he had far more wit than the Women of that Country; but this is a product of Love the Father of Inventions. However, 'tis certain nothing could have been done more proper for our deign: But hall not we ee, aid he, all your Proviion? Madam, you are here between the two bet Friends you have in the World, and you have no reaon to be hy of hewing your elf; having aid this, he drew near to the Lady, and would have taken her by the arm to help her to rie, but he refued and thrut him back. I ee Madam, aid he, you have not yet granted me the pardon I begged of you. I confes the offence was too great to be o quickly forgiven; but
you are taking your leave, and it is not fit we hould part without being friends; for it would be a perpetual grief to me, to ee you leave this Country with hatred in your heart. Deny not this favour (added he, reaching forth his hand) to a man reduced to depair for having offended you, and punihing himelf o everely for the fault, that there is no need of this extream curelty from you. But all he poke was in vain, for he hid her elf more cloely, and fortify'd her elf in the Basket to prevent being een. The Baa was unwilling to pres her any further, but addreing himelf to Alexander, told him, it was his part to make peace, and to prevail with Laura to let him ee her once more being the lat time: The Count took it ill that he made o hy of hewing her elf to a Peron to whom he was too much obliged, to deny him his requet in uch a conjuncture, what caue oever he might have had of quarrel againt him. Beides, he was particularly concerned to pres her to hew her elf; for the lat refuge he had, was his hope that the Baa's cendernes for her, would
perhaps at the moment of parting take fire afreh, and make him change his reolution; with thee thoughts he went to her, and gave her all the reaons he could invent to be reconciled to the Baa, and let him ee her a moment; but all to no purpoe. He had not one word of anwer, which angered him o, that having taken her twice or thrice by the arm to make her rie, he was jut going to force up her Barnus, and threatned to do it; but the Baa would not uffer it, bidding him force her no further; that he had caue enough to complain, without doing her new violence for love of him. But, ays he, let us make ue of the time, and ince he is brought hither to our hands, and you have no more to do but embark, let us finih what we have begun, and perform what we have undertaken, there never can be a fairer opportunity; and I cannot think that Laura will be orry to leave uch a Country as this, or part with us to go along with you. The Sultanes in all probability is yet aleep, let us not tay till he awake. We mut preently carry Laura (as he is in the
Basket) into the Ship: you hall bear her company, and as oon as you arrive, you hall hoie ail and away; as for me, I will pas the ret of the day at Bardou, and give out uch orders as may be neceary, that in cae the Sultanes mis Laura, and find he is ecaped, you may not be taid. Having aid this, he ent a Moor to the Port, with order to have a Shallop in readines to carry Laura and Alexander aboard the Chritian Veel riding at Gouletta. This done, he ent for the Captain of his Guards, and bid him accompany the Count, and commend the care of that Basket to the Moors who were to carry it along. Having given thee orders, he had no more to do, but bid his dear Alexander adieu; and having embraced him with tears in his eyes, he bore him company to the Shallop, and from thence went to Bardou with a heart full of grief. The poor Count was more to be pittied: He was not much concerned to expres how orry he was to part with the Baa; but as for the Sultanes, whom he could have wihed to have een once more at leat, his trouble to
leave her was o great, that he felt not the grief he hould have hewed when he bid the Baa adieu, who had o highly obliged him. When he aw he mut part, and no hopes of eeing her, his heart was o full he could not peak a word; the tears ran down his cheeks, which much moved the good Baa, who thought they were hed for him, and was not dipleaed to ee himelf outdone by a Man who was not ungrateful, and cordially loved him: At lat he aw him embarked, and bid him the lat adieu. The afflicted Count was o oppres'd with grief, that from the Haven to Gouletta, having given his heart a little more liberty than he durt have done in preence of the Baa, he let fall uch lamentable expreions, looking towards the Town, that the Captain of the Guard, and the ret that accompanied him, were extreamly atonihed, and moved to compaion. By good luck they undertood not Italian, but his getures, his tears, his looks, and the colour of his countenance expreed an unparallel'd trouble and affliction.

He no ooner got aboard the Ship, but he threw himelf on a Bed, and was
o much beide himelf, that he did not as much as think of his Basket; but the Captain of the Guard had eaed him of that care, and caued it to be carried into his Cabbin; after which he took leave of him, and having commanded the Captain of the Veel to hoie up his Sails, he went into the Shallop and returned to Tunis; then was it that Alexander finding himelf alone in his Cabbin, abandoned himelf to the torment of his grief. Ah Fate, aid he, unjut Fate, what have I done that you ue me o cruelly, that you force me away from a Peron without whom I cannot live. Ah my Sultanes, dear Sultanes, mut I leave you, mut I abent my elf from you for ever? For ever, aid he again riing up: Ah Heavens! let me rather be et ahore, I hall find pretence enough with the Baa; let me rather trut Love than Fortune, he hath betray'd me: Whatever happen I mut die, and I had rather die at her feet whom I love, than at this cruel ditance Having aid this, he went to ee if they were till at Anchor, but found they were already a great way from Land, and ailing with a favourable wind, had
almot lot ight of Gouletta. What depair was he in? Ah my heart, aid he, there is no remedy, now I mut perih. Dear Sultanes, added he, taking his Sword in his hand, ee whether I am guilty of this abence, and receive the Sacrifice I make you of my Life; with that he drew his Sword, and was going to thrut himelf through, when on a udden the Peron in the Basket, who had thus far hearkened to all he had aid, threw her elf upon him to prevent further michief. Let me alone to finih a Life which cannot but be unhappy at this ditance from all that I love. Ah dear Alexander, anwered the Lady, embracing him with all tendernes, her joy not permitting her to ay any more. The Count finding immediately (notwithtanding the trouble and tranport he was in) ome difference between this voice and Laura's, looked behind him on the Lady who held him in her arms: But what an atonihment, what a charming urprize was it for a heart like his, and in the condition he was in, to ee that it was the Sultanes her elf?

div.head: THE HAPPY SLAVE.
The Second Part.
div.p: OH Heavens! Is it you, Madam, cry'd the Fortunate Lover? Is it you? ays he again, overwhelmed with a full Tide of Joy, flowing o fat it had almot made him peechles; may I believe that I ee you the moment I thought I had utterly lot you? Oh happines unparallel'd and beyond expectation! But, Madam, direct me, I beeech you, where to pay my Devotion; am I obliged to Love, or to Fortune? Your thanks are due, dear Alexander, aid the Sultanes, for the Deign, to Love; and to Fortune, for the Succes.

The Happy Lover extreamly amazed at o urprizing an Adventure, found in himelf o udden an alteration from the depth of Grief to the height of Joy, that to enjoy more fully the preent pleaure of o bleed a change, he thought his moments too precious to be employ'd in atisfying the curioity of knowing by what means he was o unexpectedly arrived at o compleat a Felicity. The Veel under ail with a favourable gale rendred them as ecure as Mortals can be on an Element where the Winds are in a manner Mater of our Lives as well as Reolutions. The Happy Lovers lot not the advantage of the Seaon to enjoy one another with as much pleaure and atisfaction as properous Love is capable of.

The Captain of the Baa's Guards being arrived at Tunis, took Hore, and oon got to Bardou, where he found his Mater walking alone in the Garden, and gave him an account of the departure of Alexander. The Baa, like a man dejected and diconolate, having lift up his Eyes and Hands to Heaven, without aying a word, withdrew
into a Marble Bower in the midt of the Garden, where he continued all that day, having given his Guards expres Orders not to permit any Peron whatever to come near him; hoping thus to free himelf from the importunity he fear'd from the Sultanes, on Laura's account. His Servants and Guards were much urprized at thee Orders, not knowing what might be the caue of his dipleaure, unles it were that Alexander was gone.

In the Evening arrived at Bardou a Spahie, who brought him a Letter, and was followed by another, and he by a third, who all came to peak with him on buines of extream hate and importance; but being acquainted with the Orders he had given, they durt pas no further, but reolved to wait his coming out of the Bower.

The Turks oberve exactly the Orders of their Maters; but Aly the Captain of the Guard, gathering from the number of Couriers the importance of their buines, thought it his Duty to tep to the Town, being but three Miles ditant, to learn what the matter
was, and getting preently on Hore-back, went directly to the General of the Gallies, being one of them who had dipatched the Spahies. The General ent him intantly back, with trict Order to peak with the Baa, and tell him, that to oppoe the deigns his Enemies had againt his Life, his preence was abolutely neceary at Tunis; Aly, who apprehended the conequence of the affair, made no cruple (when returned to Bardou) to preent himelf before his Mater; who extreamly enraged to ee his Orders broke firt by him, would neither hear him, nor receive the Letter he would have delivered him from the General of the Gallies. But locking himelf up, pat his time till the fourth Prayer, when he took Hore to return to the Town. By the way he received Letters from everal, but thinking they came from the Sultanes, or ome of her party, he opened not one of them.

The General of the Gallies atonih'd not to ee him come, after News ent him what was Plotting againt him, reolved to go in Peron to ee what
tay'd him at Bardou, and by the way met him. The Baa eeing him come with a very large Train, asked him miling, if he thought he had been Beieged, that he came to meet him with o numerous a Party. You are pleaant, Sir, anwered the General; but I wih we tand not in need of far greater Forces before we come to Tunis. The Baa oberving him to peak in good earnet, fixt his Eye upon him a while without peaking a word, then askt him, what need there could be of the Forces he mentioned; and (with Indignation) what, ays, he, will they Aault me for love of the Sultanes? Do not you think, Sir, replyed the General, there is reaon enough for't? Can you believe that a Prince like the Dey, your Mortal Enemy (but from the Teeth outwards) can brook the injury you have done him, who loves the Sultanes his Daughter better than his Life? What injury, aid the Baa? What injury, reply'd the General? An injury, than which, in my Opinion, a greater could not have been offered. What, anwers the Baa, interrupting him, will they
dipute my Power to et two of my Slaves at liberty at my pleaure? No, Sir, aid the General, no quetion is made of your Right or Power in the particular you mention; but the Sultanes was not your Slave, and unles you deign'd to engage in a new Civil War, not only the Rules of Honour, Jutice, and Religion, but the Maxims of good Polity, hould have prevail'd with you, not to deliver her into the hands of a Chritian, than which a greater misfortune cannot befall a Woman of our Religion. The Baa thought this Dicoure o extravagant, that he burt out a laughing, and gave him no other anwer, but that he had taken the Alarm too oon. The General being moved, reply'd with ome heat, you know me too well to think me concern'd at that you reproach me with; but when you come to Tunis, you hall judge if I had not caue to take the Alarm. If the Dey, anwer'd the Baa, deign a breach with me, he will find a better pretence than you peak of. True it is, I have ent away Laura with Alexander the Chritian, without the conent of the
Sultanes; but there were reaons for it, and uch as the Sultanes of all Perons living had mot caue to approve. The General of the Gallies did verily believe the Baa was eriouly bent upon raillery, and willing to keep that as a ecret which all the World knew; which he took in ill part, and had not poke a word more on that ubject, had not the Baa continued the Dicoure. But, Sir, aid the General, interrupting him, what pleaure can you take in endeavouring to conceal from me (one of your bet Servants and Friends) a buines o notorious to all? Every body knows Laura is in your Seraglio, and that the Sultanes is embarqued with Alexander. Not to mince the matter, I mut tell you, the general voice is, that for Love of this Slave, you have rid your hands of the Sultanes and Alexander, and that you deign to Marry Laura, though a Chritian. But give me leave to tell you, that beides the novelty of the thing (the like having never happened in this Kingdom) not only the Dey and Divan will oppoe it, but your Friends, will to their power obtruct it, and
prevent it if they can; and I dare undertake, you will carce find a Peron of your ide.

The Baa hearing him peak in this manner, thought him ditracted, and would have ued him accordingly, but retrained by the Friendhip he had for him; Laura, ays he, whom I aw carried in a Basket, whom I accompanied to the Port (where they put her aboard a Shallop) whom the Captain of my Guard conducted to the Veel in which he was Embarked, and he aw under ail, this Laura is in my Seraglio, and I am to Marry her. Sir, anwered the General, did I not know you very well, and were fully perwaded of the good eteem you are pleaed to Honour me withall, I hould not know what to think of your Dicoure; for it cannot be but you know the whole Affair better than any Man. But to end the Dipute, let us go to your Palace, where you hall ee whether it be Laura or the Sultanes that is there.

It was not long ere they arrived at the Palace. The Baa, who took all that the General had aid to be fabulous
and vain, would not o much as have ent to the Seraglio to know how things tood, thinking it foolery to doubt of the Sultanes being there. However in complaiance, and by way of raillery, he ordered Aly to wait on the Sultanes, and to Complement her for him, upon the dipleaure he took for the departure of Laura.

The Captain of the Guard not fancying his Mater ignorant of what was pat, took his Order for a meer matter of Addres, and a colour only to hide the truth of what he would have conceal'd; and approve himelf able to manage the intrigue, as one who could penetrate into the deires of the Peron who employ'd him, he went to the Seraglio, where he preently learnt what he formerly knew, that 'twas Laura was there; and returning to the Baa, made him a civil anwer as from the Sultanes. This put the General into very great diorder, and gave the Baa new occaion to laugh, telling him, he did not undertand the deign of the Dey, in raiing thoe Reports to procure him the ill will of his Friends, and hatred of
People, and renew their former broyls with greater violence than ever; but that he hould find the means to bring him to Reaon, and that in the firt place, he would expoe the Sultanes to view of all the People, and then end her home to the Dey,—to let him ee how unwilling he was to have any Alliance with a man who made it his buines to find occaions to ruin him.

As they were Dicouring, they heard a great noie on the udden in the Palace, followed by Vollies of Muquet-hot, and People crying, to Arms, to Arms. The Baa went preently out of his Chamber to ee what the matter was, and met Aly coming to tell him, that the Palace was inveted on all ides, and that an attempt had been made to enter it by force, but that he had beat them back with ten or twelve Souldiers of the Guard, who by good Fortune hapned to be with him. The Baa, of all men the leat ubject to fear, and of a ready Wit, and admirable Judgment in the mot urprizing occaions, knowing himelf detitute then of Forces
to make any reitance, and hearing them threaten to et fire on the Palace if the Gate were not opened, order'd they hould cry out at the Windows that the Gate hould be open'd, that thoe who had begirt the Palace round, and were, for the mot part, drawn thither with hopes of Plunder, might run all to the Gate, and give him opportunity to make his ecape another way.

This Stratagem took according to his deire, and he made his ecape by a private way form his Enemies, who had hewed him no Mercy had he fallen into their hands. But he, with the General of the Gallies, and Captain of the Guard, got afe to the Mountains, Inhabited by the Moors, who had great love for him. He no ooner gave them notice of the need he had of their help, but they came to him that Night, o that by break of day he found himelf at the Head of 8000 Men, Armed ome with Muquets, ome with Pikes, both equally ueful to them.

Poor Laura was alone, abandoned to the Mercy of this Popular Torrent,
who having pillaged in a moment that Rich and Sumptuous Palace, without repect to the place or the Sex, entred the Seraglio by Order from the Dey, and took out thence the unfortunate Slave, leaving the ret expoed to the will of the Rabble. It was Laura's good Fortune, that he who had the Commiion to take her, was a Peron of great honety and worth, a private Friend of the Baa, and one who expres'd as much repect for her as he could wih in uch a Conjuncture. She was carried to the Catle, where he was committed to the ame Officers Cutody, being a Secretary, and generally eteemed by all the Divan. And being the only Peron could peak to her without danger of being heard, he confidently told her the firt time he aw her, that the Baa, whoe Conduct till then appeared admirable, had committed a fact no les difficult to be repaired, than generally condemn'd by the bet of his Friends, but that he feared the greatet mart would be hers. The poor Slave ufficiently Alarm'd by eeing her elf forced out of the Baa's Seraglio, and made the Dey's
Prioner, was frightned much more by the Dicoure of this Turk, who appeared to her a very credible Peron; he prayed him for Heavens ake to tell her what the matter was, what fault the Baa had committed, and how he was concern'd in it, that he mut be thus handled? If you are ignorant of the paages this day, anwered the Secretary, I will let you know them.

I believe, continues he, that you know Chabania, or at leat have heard talk of her, all the World is convinced of the Malignity of her Nature, and illnes of Dipoition: But to the buines in hand; that which he affirms, is grounded on Proofs o pregnant, and Reaons o clear, that her Malice hath compaed the effect he deired. Whether he was jealous of you, or in digut with the Baa I know not, but he is the caue of the diorder you have een; which, if not remedied, may prove the ruin of the Kingdom: The Dey was at Ches when word was brought him, that a Lady from the Baa's Seraglio deired to peak with him on buines of great
importance. Intantly he quitted his Game, and retiring into a Chamber to give the Woman Audience, he ees Chabania enter, attended with her Eunuchs who Uher'd her, who falling before him on her knees, pake to this purpoe. Sir, I bring you News, which doubtles will trouble you. But if I deerve Death for not being able to endure an injury done to your Royal Blood, and the whole Nation, without giving you Advertiement, I am content to uffer for it, having the atisfaction to ee you Revenge the wrong has been done you, which is, that your Daughter is gone, that he is delivered over into the hands of that Chritian who ailed away this Morning, and that a pitiful Slave is to ucceed in her place, to the infinite dihonour of your Highnes and the Nation. Take your Revenge of the Author of this diorder, and execute that Jutice which you ought againt o cruel an attempt, acted to the dihonour of God, the injury of your Blood, and dihonour of your Country. Scarce had he made an end, but the Dey inflamed with Anger, and extreamly enraged, called in thoe who had waited in the Anti-chamber, and carce
able to peak for the Paion he was in, made Chabania repeat before them all that he had aid to him. It unhappily fell out that all who were there, were Enemies to the Baa, and intead of appeaing the Dey, took the preent occaion to animate and encourage him to get atisfaction for o cruel an outrage. Women and Eunuchs were ent from the Dey to the Baa's Seraglio, on purpoe to know the truth and particulars of this Affair, who made their report, that the Sultanes was not there, that no body knew what was become of her, and that you only were able to give us any news of her. A Meenger was preently dipatched to Gouletta, to enquire at the Catle, if there were not a Woman in the Chritian Veel that ail'd away this Morning; the anwer he gave was, that the Veel was ail'd away without being earch'd, and that the Baa had ent order to that purpoe by the Captain of his Guards, who accompanied the Chritian aboard the Ship. Thee Circumtances o clear and apparent, did but too much confirm what Chabania had aid.
Hereupon divers Councils were held; and the Aembly coniting of Perons ill-affected to the Baa, or at leat too Zealous for the Dey, the Reult was, that Revenge hould be taken. I cannot conceive how it was poible the Baa had no news what pat, the report having been preently noied over the Town. It was deigned he hould be urprized at Bardou, where it was believed he would have lain this Night. But News being brought, that he was on his way hither, the Dey's Aga had Order, if deny'd entrance, to et upon the Palace, and eize his Peron living or dead. And I at the ame time was to go to the Seraglio, and to carry you away. They mis'd of him, and it was well for you he ecaped; for had he been taken, both he and you had been by this time dead. But having o luckily made his ecape, and being Mater of the Militia and Moors of the Kingdom, he may become formidable to the Dey, and be in a capacity to deliver you from danger.

The unfortunate Laura, too much acquainted with the unkindnes of her
Stars, did nothing but igh and groan at the apprehenions of the new torms that threatned her. She knew better than any, the little reaon they had to charge the Baa with the flight of the Sultanes; and being of Opinion, that by jutifying the Baa, her caue would appear better before the Dey; he told this Turk, that her Patron was not, perhaps, o guilty as they thought. I know not, continued he, what is become of the Sultanes, ince he left the Seraglio this Morning; but the confidence you have expret in me, in the freedom of your peech to me, and your generous carriage obliging me not to be o reerv'd to you, as I would to another; and eeing the extremity matters are reduced to, I mut acquaint you, that if the Baa ent away the Sultanes with the Chritian, as is reported, he was very willing to go. And becaue it is probable you will hardly believe me, without telling you more, I hall be forced to relate part of a tory which may erve at leat to excue, if not jutifie the Baa.

You know, Sir, aid he, that the Sultanes loved Alexander; and that
he loved him entirely, the occaion was this: The Baa, whom every one knows to have had a mighty affection for that Chritian, had a longing deire (whether for Divertiement, or to faten him more cloely to his Peron) to ee him Love with ome Lady, and was of Opinion, I might be fit for the purpoe, if he could but contrive how to bring us together. But becaue I tirred not out of the Seraglio, and that it would have been a very candalous thing, to ee a Chritian enter a Palace, where none of your Religion but Eunuchs have acces; he put the tranger into the habit of an Eunuch, and having prevailed with me to accept of a Viit from him, brought him to me one Evening. The Sultanes, already full of good thoughts for the Chritian, whom the Baa had a thouand times poke to her of, was extreamly glad to hear of the deign, to bring him to her very Apartment, and with very great earnetnes prayed me, if poible, to procure her the pleaure of eeing him. This proved no hard task for me to perform: The Baa, who eldom came to viit the
Sultanes, ending him almot every day diguied like an Eunuch into the Seraglio; o that I had no more to do but provide for the Secrecy of the interview between my Mitres and Alexander. They had a ight of each other; and if Alexander was o handom, as to pleae the Sultanes, you may imagine that o Beautiful a Lady could not dipleae him. Their Love increaed day by day to that height, that they aw one another very often. The Baa eeing his Chritian in Love, and thinking me the object of it, took ingular pleaure in it. The Baa had formerly had ome kindnes for me, which cool'd by my reitance; but having one day for Divertiement caued Alexander to give him an account of the progres of his Amour, the fire of his Love o long raked up and mothered, kindled afreh into a flame; and gathering from the ucces of Alexander's Addres, that I was not inenible, as I pretended to him; he renewed his Courthip, intermingled now and then with Reproaches for the little eteem I had for him in preferring the affection of a Slave before
his: I fore-aw the danger, but was unwilling to make him enible of his mitake, to ave the two Lovers from the inconveniences which would certainly attend the dicovery. And making my elf a Sacrifice to the pleaure of the Sultanes, I let him believe I was not inenible of the Merit of Alexander. The affair thus managed, there followed many pleaant Adventures and Intrigues, which for fear of troubing you too much at preent, I hall defer the relation of it to a better Opportunity. The mean time, the Baa extreamly preed me, and reproached me daily for lighting his Paion, and at the ame time favouring a Chritian far les worthy of my affection. He left no tone unturned to compas his Amorous deigns, inomuch as at lat he found the means to have a private and dumb interview in the dark with his Wife, whom he mitook for me, and did her all the violence imaginable to be revenged of the inenibility I had for him. Having atisfied himelf, he parted with her without knowing her, bleing himelf for the good Fortune of having obtained that
which he might have commanded every day. But grieved at lat for the outrage he thought he had done me, and not knowing how to excue himelf to a Mitres extreamly offended, he judg'd no better amends could be made for his fault, than etting at Liberty two Lovers, whoe Paion he had o unjutly injured, after having been not only the promoter, but firt Author of their Love. He ent me the News of his Reolution by a Billet he writ to me, wherein he pleaded in excue the great Paion he had for me; that to expiate his fault, he would deprive himelf for ever of the ight of me, and end me back with my Love to my Country, being all could be deired from a generous Rival: And that if I were enible of the pain and regret my abence would cot him, I hould find him punihed beyond his deert. My joy was not greater than the trouble of the Sultanes upon receiving this News, which put her into an unpeakable affliction. Her Nights and her Days were wholly pent in Tears; he ued all means poible to prevent the misfortune he
apprehended from Alexander's return into Italy. I gave her way, chooing rather to renounce my Liberty than ee her die for grief in the condition he was in. But the Baa, the firmet of men in what he reolves on, not perceiving the reaon he had to oppoe a deign he had more reaon than he to promote, conidering the Paion he knew he had for me, which mut needs trouble her, was true to his Reolution; and knowing there was in the Port a Chritian Veel ready to Sail for Italy, he caued it to be taid for our Embarking therein. What a trouble was it to the Sultanes to ee the Baa o obtinate, and us on the point of departing! Never was a Peron o plunged in a Sea of depair, never were ighs o lamentable as hers; I was resolved to entreat the Baa to put off our departure to another occaion, that I might gain time to dipoe her to grant me the favour; but whether it were for the hame to ee me, or for fear that the ight of me might melt him into a tendernes that might alter the Reolution he had taken, he appear'd not at the Seraglio. The
Morning we were to be gone, the deolate Sultanes reolved to die, or to follow us; he had long tudied to contrive a way how to do it: I was her Bed-fellow, but neither of us lept a wink. Laura, ays he, having conidered well what he would do, thou knowet the affection I ever had for thee, that I have ued thee more like a Siter than a Slave. Thou knowet my heart, and I need not tell thee I cannot live without Alexander. I deire no acknowledgment of what I have done for thee, (added he, kiing me with her face all bath'd in tears) but for pity ake, forake me not in the mot deperate condition that a Woman in Love as I am, can be reduced to, but do omething to ave my Life: had he deired mine with uch melting expreions, I could not have denied it her, which he might perceive by the tears I hed to accompany hers. Then he told me of an intention he had thought of, whereby get aboard with us, and that he doubted not of the ucces, if Alexander had the Paion he pretended to have for her; and if he had not, he would comfort herelf,
and find pleaure in Rage for the abence of o ingrate a Peron; that without the knowledge of any one in the Seraglio he would be carried to his Lodging, and thence aboard the Veel we were to Embark in; and that the Baa ending for me to be gone, we might all three get aboard before any Dicovery could be made of her departure. To give her content, I approved of what he aid, but did really apprehend the uces of this affair, and preage, I know not how, that I hould be the ufferer. 'Tis a dangerous buines to yield ones elf up to the conduct of Lovers, in that which concerns the interet of their affections; they are apt to flatter themelves, to puff themelves up with hope, and admit of no fear. When the day began to appear in our Chamber, we thought it high time to et about and take order for what we thought neceary for accomplihing our deires. We got up, and the Sultanes having put on a Suit of mine, commanded me to call her one of the Eunuchs, who was Purveyor for Alexander, and ready to Sacrifice his Life for the Service of the Sultanes;
he ent him for the basket wherein he ued to carry the Proviion, and placing her elf in it, wrapt up in my Barnus, commanded him to carry her to Alexander's Lodging. I aw her go away in this manner, waiting with fear and impatience enough to hear the ucces of this contrivance of the Sultanes, and expecting every moment Orders from the Baa for my going away. At lat, the time of Embarking being over and the Sultanes not returned, I was deirous to be informed how matters pat, and undertood with atonihment and dipleaure enough, that Alexander was gone, and that the Baa, having brought him to the Port, returned for Bardon. Then it was, Sir, I felt the troke of my ill Fortune, in loing, not only the hope of returning to my Country, which might have given me ome comfort, but of ever eeing the Sultanes, the Peron of the World I had mot kindnes for, and one who rendred my Captivity pleaing. I could not doubt but her flight would be laid to my charge; but the conideration of a Life o unhappy as mine, had produced in me o clear
reolutions for death, that, had you taken notice at your arrival, you could not oberve any trouble in my countenance. And in good earnet the los of my dear Sultanes afflicted me o, that the appearance of death could not have done more. They asked me oftentimes what was become of her? the anwer I made, was, that I knew not: But having been long taken for her Confident, I was hrewdly upected. As for the ret of her Servants, you might have read in their countenances, the trouble of their minds.

This is that, Sir, I had to ay to you of the Sultanes; and if you think this Story may be of ue to the Baa, and conduce to the procuring peace between him and the Dey, I hould be very glad you would relate it to him, though I may appear guilty of having committed a crime againt the one and the other. But they have prudence enough to be enible of the condition of a poor Slave, whoe happines conited in her complaisance to a Mitres, who loved her o well as to make her confident in affairs of this conequence. The Turk made anwer,
that the Baa had o much kindnes for her, and o little for the Sultanes, that he would eaily pardon the Treaon he was guilty of; and as for the Dey, he could not be much offended with her, for having done his Daughter o eminent a ervice, in aiting her in a piece of unfaithfulnes to a Husband who (the Dey knows) had not any Love for her: and that he would make ue of the particulars of this Story to reconcile them; that he would manage this buines with ome Friends of the Divan, and particularly with the Aga, the Deys favourite, who had great influence over him, and though a Renegade, loved the Chritians very well, and might do her ome ervice. To thee expreions he added a thouand aurances on his part, and civilities enough to oblige her extreamly. This done, he withdrew, to avoid the upicion her Guard might have of a longer dicoure, it being already very late, but promied to ee her again on the morrow, and bring her News of all that pat.

The Baa being now at the Head of o many Moors, thought himelf trong
enough to take the Field, and as oon as it was day, marched down towards the Town, to favour the retreat of his Friends, and of the Souldiers who came flocking in to him; o that before noon he had an Army of Moors and Turks above ten thouand trong. The Dey ued all diligence poible to arm his people, but found himelf not trong enough that day to encounter the Baa, whoe Arms were already grown terrible to his Enemies, who from his jut indignation againt them apprehended a Siege. But his quarrel being chiefly to the Dey, and wanting Cannon to attack him in the Catle he was in, the Baa was forced to wait the arrival of the Artillery he had ent for to the Port whereof he was Mater.

In the mean time, having aembled the principal of his Friends, to make his complaint to them of the unjut proceedings of the Dey, and to demand their advice, he was not a little amazed to hear them all maintain the General of the Galleys; that it was his Wife was gone away with the Chritian, and that Laura taid in the Seraglio; and that the Dey had reaon enough
for what he had done, in the belief he was in of the Baa's intentions to make away his Daughter. The Baa who till fancied that they were abued, would not vouchafe to contradict them, but calling in the Captain of his Guards, asked him before them, if he had not the day before poken with the Sultanes. Poor Aly hivering for fear, fell down at his feet with his face to the ground, and confeed he had thought the Baa had ent him to the Seraglio, on purpoe to blind the world, and that it was deired he hould jutifie before the General of the Galleys, he had een the Sultanes there, but that in truth he was not there, and that he found only Laura weeping for the departure of her Mitres.

The Baa for all this would not be perwaded, but aid, he mut ee the Slave before he could believe it, having many Reaons to the contrary, when he received a Billet from the Deys Secretary to this purpoe.

body.p:
My Lord, Mahomet Baa; I know not whether it was your good Fortune or mine, that ordered the Deys making choice of me to take away and guard your
fair; Slave; but you may be aured he could not have fallen into better hands: he wants for nothing, and you may believe, I hold neither my Etate nor my Life too dear to betow in your ervice, and obliging of her. If in the mean time I may be allowed the liberty of giving you Counel, I would advie you to endeavour the advantage and peace of your Countrey, rather than that War and Ruin which will be inevitable, unles you moderate your Paion. There is no Man more enible than I of the injury they have done you; but I am enible alo that the appearances, for which you are condemned, have mied the Dey; and thus the blame of the departure of your Wife ought to be charged only on your Wife. The rah Counel of diaffected perons, which the Dey hath followed in this affair, hath put you both into this preent diorder. God grant it proceed no further, and that we may not, to the candal of other Nations, ee our Countrey ruined by thoe who have it in charge to maintain and preerve it. I hope both of you will be better advied, and waiting your Anwer, I wih you all happines.

div.p:
The Baa, having read this Letter,
could no longer doubt of the truth of the thing, knowing Aen to be a peron of great Integrity, and his very good Friend. He was eaily comforted for the los of the Sultanes, and laught at the adventure, and could not believe he had had a deign to follow the Chritian, if he had not given order to carry her aboard in the Basket. He was not much troubled at the mitake he had been guilty of, and thought that in matters of Love, a Mitres of at leat as good value as a Wife. He never upected any treachery in the Cae, but was willing to know what reaon could have reduced her to diguie her elf in that manner, and go along with Alexander; yet he could not but think Laura of the Plot, but thought himelf revenged of her, and her ufficiently punihed in having lot at once her Lover, and the occaion of her liberty, to pleaure a Mitres, who might become a Rival. He longed extreamly to ee her, to know the whole buines; and Love adding new flames to this curioity, made him o impatient of delay, that how dangerous oever the enterprize might have
been, he would have gone that very day to Tunis, if his preence with the Army had not been abolutely neceary, to receive thoe who every moment came over to his party. He ent his Friend this Anwer.

body.p: Mr. Secretary, you have in your hands a Treaure, which if the Dey knew how much I value, he would not have truted you or any other therewith, as being aured he might with it make his peace when, and on what conditions he pleaed.
