Take care of her, I conjure you, as you would of my peron, and believe, I will never forget a ervice of o much importance. Send hither your Moor to morrow at the fourth Watch; I hall want him for a buines I cannot trut any other peron withal, nor write to you of at preent.

div.p:
By that time he had written this Billet, the night was far gone; yet for more urety he would not let the Moor go till three or four a clock in the Morning. The Walls of Tunis are very low, and in ome places eaie to get over. True it is, they were then very well guarded; but the bearer of the Billet being known to belong to the Deys
Secretary, there was no danger of his being taid; and accordingly he found his paage free as he could wih.

The generous Aen had been that Evening to viit his fair Prioner according to promie, and given her an account how matters tood, with ome hopes of accommodation between parties at difference; for that it was clear by the confeion of the Eunuch who had carried the Sultanes in the Basket, that if the Baa had a hand in ending away the Sultanes, he had contributed not a little to her enlargement, out of a criminal paion he had for Alexander, by going to ee him at his Lodging. Laura well pleaed with this News, could not ufficiently thank Aen for the obliging care he had of her. He had ent o many everal orts of excellent refrehments, that he found her elf better ued in the Prion, than in the Baa's Seraglio; he knew not what to attribute o much goodnes and complaiance to, and was a little troubled, out of an apprehenion he had there might be ome love in the cae; for the Turk appeared o civil, o punctual, and o full of kindnes, above the
ordinary rate of thoe of his Country, that he had caue to think him rather a Lover of her, than a meer Friend of the Baa's; yet had he not in a yllable trangreed the repect that was due to her, which pleaed her the more, that he had no caue on that account to be angry with a Man who had done her o many good Offices. And the truth is, he acted only out of a principle of generoity, having been five or ix years a Slave in Italy to a Patron who had ued him very well; and therefore being of a generous nature, he held himelf obliged to do the Chritians good offices, as having for them a more than ordinary Love and Eteem.

As Laura was complaining of her ill Fortune, which threw her out of one michance into another, he pray'd her to tell him how he was made a Slave Laura was o much obliged to him, that the trouble he might expect in her elf, upon a freh relation of her misfortunes, could not hinder her from giving him that mall atisfaction, in acknowledgment of the many ervices he had done her; o that having aured
him there was nothing pleaant in the tory of her life, yet to let him know the firt rie of her misfortunes, he begun in this manner.

Sir, I was born at Genoa, and of one of the bet Families of that Republick, but you hall excue me, if I conceal the name: I will ave my Family that hame, ince my mifortunes can do it no credit. I was born in a properous and flourihing Etate, and my Parents having no other Child, I was bred with that care and expence I may rather call profue than great. It was my misfortune that my Mother died when I was but 12 years old, and that my Father, though aged, married a young Lady more conidrable for Birth than Etate; but my Father had ufficient to atisfie the ambition or pride of a woman of quality. But thee were not the Vanities my Mother-in-law was ubject to, it was Love had the Acendent over her. My Father was old, he was young and handom, and he had caue to be jealous of her: He let her tir but very rarely out of her Lodging, and never but in his company, and then only to Church, or to make a viit to a Friend or Relation. But who can reit his fate? My Mother-in-law, little pleaed with the evere hand my Father held over
her, found her inclination to be unfaithful to him, increae more and more; nothing provokes deire more than retraint, and difficulties and traits are Siters of invention; he made ue of everal to carry on ome little intrigues in the Town, but all to no purpoe; my Father, an old Mater in Gallantry, was o cunning and mitrutful, that nothing could ecape him. So that the kind Lady depairing of relief from abroad, was willing to try if he could find at home any means to atisfie her inclinations. She cat her eyes on a Man, of condition o mean, I dare not for her reputation let you know what it was, though otherwie very handom, honet, and till then very faithful to my Father, who had more trut in him, than in any of his Dometicks: this acquaintance and familiarity o dihonourable for a Lady of her quality, lated for ome time without being dicovered, till at lat by ill fortune for them and for me, having laid me down to leep on a bed of repoe in my Mother-in-laws chamber, I was an eye-witnes of their Infamy: they were not aware of me, my Maid having by chance covered me with a piece of Tapetry, laid uually on the bed. I aw them, and they me, with what urprize you may imagine.
I was then 14 or 15 years old. Was he not a Slave, ays the Turk? interrupting with a tone full of joy and urprize. Yes, Sir, anwer'd Laura (atoniht at the Quetion, which made her look earnetly on him) he was a Slave, and of Turky. Ah Madam, cries the other, as oon as he had aid o, is it poible you hould not know Aen? and that you hould be Madam Elinor? At this Laura was mute for ome time, and then recollecting her elf, Oh Heavens! is it you, my poor Aen, ays he? By what good fortune have I met you here, and fallen in your hands? By the bet fortune in the world both for you and me, ays the Turk, ravihed with joy to find himelf in a condition to erve her, and being under the obligations I am to you, I hould be the mot ingrateful of men, if I imploy not my elf in your ervice. I know you may accue me on the account of your Mother-in-law, but what could a poor lave have done, tempted by the charms of a fair Lady, who offered him Money and Liberty when he pleaed? You will confes, men are gain'd by les matters, and that if I committed a Crime in doing as I did, after the Confidence o good a Mater as your Father repoed in me, and the bounty he hewed me, yet it is pardonable;
at leat I believe I have made ome amends for my fault, in aving your Lives, which your Mother would have robbed both you and him of by poyon. But I had that influence over her Paion, that I diverted her from it. She made me a thouand promies, if I would put in Execution that horrible deign; but becaue you are ignorant what followed that Adventure, I will tell you in few words.

Your ight of us, as you aid, urpriz'd extreamly both the one and the other; and in that deperate Paion your Mother-in-Law was then in, I know not what he would have done to have been rid of you. But, as I told you, I oppoed her, and made her undertand, that the coure he propoed, would certainly plunge us into irreparable Michiefs, and doubtles, cot us both our Lives. That it were better to endeavour to gain you by fair means, in hopes that being very good-natur'd, you would not purue our detruction, by making your Father acquainted with that which would certainly be the caue of his Death, and bring him to his Grave You cannot but remember I went alone with you out
of the Chamber to perwade you. And that I told you, it concern'd the Honour of your Houe to keep the matter private, with everal other reaons, with which you expres'd your elf convinced. At lat, you promied me not to make any more noie of it, if your Mother-in-Law would, for the future, keep within the bounds of her Duty. I made a relation of all this to her, expecting that the experience of your dicretion, o well known in the Family, would have pat for current Security, for your keeping your word. But it could not ecure her from trange inquietude and trouble of Mind. She could not ee you without hame, nor come near your Father without trembling. She buzz'd intantly in my Ears, that there was a neceity of making you both a Sacrifice to her Repoe; and that till then he could not expect any Pleaure in her Life. She told me, I mut help her to effect the deign, or expect to be the firt that hould feel the weight of her wrath. I endeavoured the bet I could to reduce her to Reaon, but for ome time he would not hear any.
At lat, her ill humour deired only the atisfaction of your being put out of your Lodging, and was content to find out everal pretences to perwade your Father to put you into a Nunnery, or at leat out of his Houe. Notwithtanding all the Arts of her Complaiance and Cunning, he found it no eaie matter to bring this about; but for the quiet of the Houe, it was neceary to pleae her, and place you under Penion in a Nunnery. Shortly after, whether it were that you had dicovered the buines, or that he fear'd you had done o, or rather that he was willing to be rid of me, by this Stratagem he came one Night to my Chamber, while your Father was aleep, and with a fright in her looks told me, I was undone, that my Mater knew all, and that I had no more but that Night for to ave my elf. Whereupon he gave me Money, and eeing me reolved to be gone, bid me her lat farewel. I kept, as you remember, the Keys of the Houe, and o got eaily out. I had, for a Diguie, taken a black Suit of your Fathers, and as oon as it was day, and the
Port open, I hired a Felucca, which carried me to Legorne, where I lay private three days, taying for a Veel of the Great Dukes, which was to carry a Preent to Mahomet Baa, my Ancient Friend, who made ue of his Interet with the Dey to retore me my Etate, which ince I was a Slave, had been Conficated, upon a belief I was dead. But having fail'd of his deire, he procured me in recompence, the Secretaries place, which is no great matter here. This, Madam, is the account of my Life ince I left Italy. You may oblige me in acquainting me with yours, which I could not come to the knowledge of, having never heard ince from Genoa.

That which remains to be told you, ays Elinor (whom we will yet call Laura) is a tory full of troubles and misfortunes; the more difficult for me to relate, that a Peron of Quality cannot but be ahamed of them. But I will be free with you.

Having pent two Years in the Covent I was placed in, my Father moved with many tears, took me home; where for the time I tayed there, I
was under continual Perecution from my Mother-in-Law; who having got the Acendent over the good Man, made him believe what he pleaed. She had new deigns in her Head, which you may believe was the caue of the fear he put you in: for my Father never had the leat knowledge of your familiarity, and was much troubled at your running away, declaring he had lot in you the bet Servant he had. He had deigned to have et you at Liberty, which was the reaon he ent not after you as he might have done. I was by this time become omewhat clear ighted, and what I knew of my Mother-in-Law, made me upect every thing he did: I watched her narrowly, and in few days dicovered a new Gallant. You may believe, that after the michiefs he had done me, I fail'd not to do her all the ill Offices in my power: it is the nature of our Sex never to Pardon. But beides the pleaure of Revenge, I was engaged in Honour againt her. This raied a War between us more violent than ever, and my Father had trouble enough to content us both.
At firt he thought her elf hard enough for me, having once already turn'd me out of the Houe, and afterwards ent you packing; and putting on a bold face, fear'd nothing, as knowing I would not accue her of any thing, but her impudence could bring her off, my Evidence being gone. But when he perceived by my obtructing her new practices, rallying her on all occaions, and other cutting effects of my reentment, that I undertood her Secrets, he pared nothing that Rage and Fury could ugget to her againt me. At lat, he fell heavy upon me with my Father; and having not prevailed with him to return me into the Monatery, forced him to turn me again out of his Houe, and place me with his Relations; where I paed ix Months with one, and ix Months with another, to the great dipleaure of the Family. Till at lat a Grandee of Spain, an old Friend of my Fathers, having been created Viceroy of Naples, and paing by Genoa to go and take Poeion of his Government, my Father intreated him to take me along with him, which he readily did. The
Viceroy and his Lady received and entertained me, not only as the Daughter of their intimate Friend, but as their own, and honoured me with uch expreions of Civility and Bounty, that I thought my elf too happy in being of their Train. And the truth is, I was not deceived; thee beginnings of kindnes growing every day to greater perfection, epecially on the part of the Viceroy's Lady, who appeared not able to live a moment without me. She had been a great Beauty, and was not then unhandome, though not very young. She kept nothing from me, but imparted to me her mot private thoughts, and made me the Confident of her dearet affections. This lated as long as I was diinteres'd, but there is no truting one another of our Sex, epecially in matters of Love. I was reputed not unhandom, and having a full Pure at command, I lived at that Court with Splendor enough. It was preently known, I was not the mot inconiderable of Genoa, and this advantage et off with a little Beauty, raied o great a number of Pretenders to
me, that I could not pas a day without treats and addrees of Love. The Court of Naples hath always pas'd for the mot Gallant of Italy, by reaon of the multitude of Perons of Quality in the Kingdom, but was never o pleaant as then. I was o young that I knew not what Love was, and was not concerned to make hate to learn it, but made the Cares and Sighs of thoe in Love, my port and divertiement. But Love will in time be revenged, and make port of us that made port of him. I had not yet een the man who had the ecret to affect my heart, no not one who could pleae, though that Court had of all orts, and ome very handome. The Son of the Viceroy, being a young Lord very well accomplihed, and not a little concerned for me, did but give me trouble. But as I hinted before, I pay'd dear for that indifference and thoe lights I gloried o much in Five or ix months after our arrival at Naples, there appeared at Court a young Gentleman whom Love eems to have raied up for my ruin. It was the Marques Hippolito of the Houe of Accelyn, equally
coniderable for his good parts as his Birth; a Youth whoe outide was taking enough to charm at firt ight, but as traiterous and wicked within, as he was outwardly handom and well accomplihed. When you have heard out my tory, you will ay I peak with too much moderation. It is hard to hate what we have been once truly in Love with. In pite of that unpardonable outrage he did me, I find that if I aw him, and had it in my power to take my revenge of him by death, which he hath but too well deerved, my reentment would give place to the inclination I had for him. He was newly come from France, and had got the Court-air, o peculiar and natural to thoe of quality of that Nation. I was extreamly pleaed to ee him, and looked upon him with delight, the firt time he appeared at Court; and was enible of it, though with hame and anger at my elf. From thenceforth he was contantly in my thoughts, though very troubleome to me. I was dipleaed with my elf for it, and would upon any terms have put him out of my mind, but the
more I endeavoured it, the more I found him ettled there. I aw him everal times after, and to the end the War within me would fain have perwaded my elf, it was not for my honour to entertain uch thoughts of that Gentleman; but I found in the end my ingenuity deceived me. That which contributed mot to my ruin, that both by his looks and his actions he eemed to prefer me before all the Ladies of the Court, and though he did not declare o much, yet I could oberve he had more than an ordinary repect for me, and would now and then ay to my elf ome things I fancied he might and would have aid to me. At lat I made my elf of his Party, and blaming my pat coynes, I thought it very allowable and jut, to have ome eteem for a man who merited it from all the World: Having once entertained this thought, and convinced of it as reaonable, my paion and Love finding my heart already more than half open, pres'd in and abolutely took it. The Viceroy's Lady, who often diverted her elf in entertaining me with all the Intrigues of the Court,
having one day told me everal Stories, asked me if I knew the Marques Hippolito's Mitres, for that, for ome days pat, he oberved him very olitary and out of humour, which he took for an effect of ome inclination. Had he look'd upon me when he asked me the quetion, he might read in my countenance how much I was concerned; for I chang'd colour three or four times. But being upon the Tarras of the Palace on the Country ide, he was looking that way and took no notice of me; o that having time to recover my elf, I anwered with an affected coldnes, that he was a dull young fellow, and I believed incapable of Love: and thereupon out of Jealouie her quetion had raied in me, I made a decription of him as really unlike him, as contrary to the thoughts I had of him. The Viceroy's Lady fell a laughing, and having looked upon me o, as he believed, would have put me out of countenance; is it poible, ays he, that you hould think o of a man whom all the other Ladies eteem the handomet of the Court? If I were not very well perwaded of
your indifference for all men, I hould believe of you quite contrary to what you ay. But look to your elf, for ooner or later you will be met with, and your inenible heart hall have her turn as well as others. As for me, I confes, were I as you, that young Gentleman would pleae me, and I would not have you light him: think of it, he is a Peron of merit and worth, and wants nothing of what may jutly deerve Love from a fair Lady as you are. Who would not have believed but he poke in good earnet? Who could have mitruted her after o many kindnees and favours he daily laid out on me? I know not whether I was to blame, but mut confes I yielded my elf to be taken, and was ready to unay in her preence all that I had poken againt the Marques Hippolito, and to acknowledge I had prevented her in the thoughts he had been pleaed to inpire into me of him, but my modety retrained me. I thought my elf concerned in honour, to expect an Addres from him, before I would confes my elf taken. I could never dicover perfectly this
Ladies deign, but as far as I can gues by the conequence, he quetion'd me of pure jealouie, endeavouring to dicover whether I had any affection for the Marques. She had often een us talk together; judging by her thoughts of him, that it was hard enough for a Lady to be acquainted with a Gentleman of o many charming Qualities, without loving him; he had doubtles ome apprehenion I had on his account ceas'd to be inenible. But finding by what I aid, that I continued indifferent, her jealouie giving place to Love-policy, he deired to ettle ome friendhip between him and me, to erve her for a pretence to ee him as oft as he deired. At leat I am of opinion thee were the reaons obliged her to peak of me as he did, and to tell me, if ever I meant to love, I could not make a better choice. I tood out tifly to the end, telling her, my Liberty was o precious, that I would not part with it for any conideration in the World, if the keeping depended wholly on me: But becaue thoe of my condition were not born to enjoy it all their Life; whatever I
endured, I would be guided by my Friends, and abolutely obey their pleaure who had the right to dipoe of me. Hereupon he embraced me, and aid, All the Maids of the World would be wie, were they of my humour, and followed my example. In the mean time, ince I was reolved not to light the Counel of Friends, it was her advice I hould admit the Marques Hippolito to ee me ometimes. But Madam, aid I, interrupting her, hath he deired leave to do it, and is it at his requet that you make the motion? She anwered, aying, that I need not trouble my elf for that, but might believe this overture came not altogether from her; and that the Marques had found me out as well as others. You may imagine what a pleaure he did me, in telling me this, who deired nothing more than the love of that Gentleman.

This dicoure being over, we parted extreamly mitaken in our thoughts of one another. She imagin'd I was till the ame, and altogether inenible of love; and I thought he had poken as a Friend, and really deired to
ee me in love with the Marques: We began to have the young Lords company, after the particular kindnes between him and Don Alphono, Son to the Viceroy, gave him free entrance where he pleaed; and the Viceroy having no mall eteem for the Marques, was not only glad to ee him at Court, but ingaged him by his Civilities to come to him oftner. I hall forbear mentioning what the Lady contributed on her part; but you may believe it very probable, that having the kindnes he had for him, he omitted nothing in her power to further thee Viits. At firt he was altogether for me, at leat in appearance; for everal days he wanted nothing of diligence or complaiance to pleae me. Whereever I went he till waited upon me, approved all that I aid, and took my part on all occaions. In a word, he practied all that may be done, for gaining a-Mitres; and was preently looked upon in Court as a new Servant of mine. Many of my Friends congratulated my Conquet, and I could not but laugh at them. Not but that I believed it, being eaily perwaded
to credit what I o much deired, but that I was afraid to believe it o oon, and was unwilling it hould be known, to avoid the hame that might attend a mitake. He had not as then poke to me of Love; and the leat I could do, was to expect he hould declare himelf. A Lover of o much Wit as the Marques, could not fail of finding an occaion. But I know not whether fortune befriended him o ill, as not to afford him one. However, 'tis certain he never took any to dicover his Paion by Speech: All that I knew of it, was from his looks and his ighs, which perhaps my kindnes interpreted too favourably. Men being now accutomed to a general Gallantry, that in hew and appearance, both their words and their actions peak altogether of Love. Thee promiing blooms of an apparent affection, were all blated on the udden. I was urpriz'd at it to atonihment, to ee him o far advanced to make o udden a top, at a time I leat expected it, and prepared my elf to give occaion to dicover his affection, which I fear'd his repect for me, or his fear
to dipleae me, had hindered from doing. I could not imagine the caue of o udden a change; for three whole days he abented from the Court, and when he appeared there, he looked like a man o cold, o altered, as if he durt not cat an eye upon me, whereas before he was jovial and complaiant, and his eye never off me, you cannot eaily imagine how terribly this vext me. I was upon the point of asking him the reaon, and had certainly done it, but that I was over-rul'd by a little haughtines and pride, which making me look on his incontant proceeding, as an effect of manifet Treachery, inpired me with corn and averion againt him; which however I marted for in the end: for two whole days I did nothing but weep and complain of Love and my own wickednes. The Viceroy's Lady oberving me ad and dejected, though I did all in my power to hide part of my trouble, asked me what I did ail, which probably he knew but too well, but was willing to have the pleaure of hearing what I would ay, I, who till then had not the leat reaon to ditrut her, made no cruple
of telling her in plain terms the caue of my grief, and told her, he had more than any contributed thereto. This made her bluh, and comprehending on the udden what I meant, but thinking without doubt I had dicovered her ecret. But I fell unhappily to explaining my elf, and eriouly confes'd to her, that what he had aid to me of the Marques Hippolito, had produced in me ome dipoition of kindnes for him, which cot me then very dear, having been very confident he would not have deceived me, but that the Marques had now deceived us both. I mut confes, ays the Traytres, I was willing to conceal from you the incontancy and change of a foolih young flah, and did deign not to peak to you any more of him, not thinking you could be much concerned for him after what I had heard you ay of him. But ince you are aware of his incontancy, and o much concern'd at it, I mut tell you, that to my grief as much as yours, I have dicovered he is otherwie engaged. She perceived me bluh extreamly at that word, and in truth I was o
diordered within, it was impoible to hide my depair. Otherwie engaged! Madam, aid I, ighing: Yes, anwered he, to a new Mitres very lately. Judge you, continued he, what I aid to him on that occaion, and whether he did deerve to be reproached, having expret o much paion for you, that I thought it impoible a man could have been more deeply in Love. Oh Heavens, cry'd he, how deceitful are men now adays! He excued himelf by the Friendhip he hath for my Son; that to be his Rival, were to betray him, and that the confidence he had in him, in acquainting him at his arrival, with his affection for you, obliged him to make a Sacrifice of his heart, to erve my Sons interet. Sorry excues, I confes ays he, but how can we help it? 'Tis a mercy however, he knows not the favourable inclination you have for him, for which he is unhappily beholding to me, as the caue of your kindnes. He hould never have known thee worthy inclinations, reply'd I: I never dicovered them to any but your elf Madam, for whom
I had no reerve, and I hope you have not told him. Think not, ays he, I could o far forget my elf; though I were not o much your Friend as you know I am; I know very well with what caution to manage their concerns, who repoe a confidence in me. Then I asked her trembling, whether he knew the fair Lady had robbed us of him? That, ays he, I cannot learn of him, but I will endeavour to dicover it by my Son, who without quetion knows who he is; leave that to me, and I will bring you news of her as oon as I can dicover her.

Thus did my Rival triumph and laugh at me. I mut confes I was a very Fool, in that I had not then more wit, than to trut any Woman; but it was the confidence I had in her, that blinded me. Yet when I call to mind a thouand things then poken and done, I cannot but wonder, I who had een o much of the world, could not make dicovery of the treachery they acted againt me. I did nothing but torment my elf night and day, and avoided all occaions of being with the Marques, for fear my weaknes
hould to my digrace prevail over my reolutions. I aw him entertain himelf commonly with the Viceroys Lady, and asking her one day, what it was they dicoured of; and whether he had dicovered the ecret I was o deirous to know; he anwered me, no, but that I hould not trouble my elf, for the Marques would come to me again; and that he tudied how to bring it about. I was vext at this, and told her I did not deire it: that he might do her pleaure, but that I deired to be unconcerned. And the truth is, the pains I endured, would, I believe, by degrees have made me inenible, and cured me at lat. But on a day the Viceroy treated us in the Garden, I quitted the Company, and walking aide to mue in a dark and olitary place, I met with the Marques. I thought it an effect of the Ladies care, and that he had made ue of this occaion to reconcile us. I know not whether he took the haughtines and eriounes of the Looks I entertain'd him with for an ill Omen, or not; but ure I am, he trembled as he approached me,
and with a very ettled tone, told me, it was very trange to ee a peron of my Humour finding out o olitary a Walk, there being o much good company in the Garden: it had been, aid he, excuable in any other, as an effect of ome amorous thoughts; but for you Madam—for me, replied I, interrupting him, and who hath told you but I may have been led hither by Love? Ah Madam, anwered he, we know you too well to entertain any uch upicion; and I am ure, if you can love any thing, it mut be only your elf, 'Tis well, replied I, if it be true as you ay, that I love nothing at all; but as for what you reproach me with, 'tis reported you are not altogether indifferent: there is ome ground for the report, Madam, indifference being a Quality I never tood much upon, epecially towards you of all the people in the World. What not towards me? replied I, when you knew me inenible. 'Tis true, Madam, anwered he, I was told o, but ubmitted however to the detiny of thoe many unfortunate Lovers, you have made uch in this
Court. In matter of affection, aid I, we are not to be led by example; ome have more merit, or at leat better Fortune than others; we are enible towards ome, when we are not o towards others: One peron hall pleae, without knowing wherefore amongt an infinite of others who hall not have that advantage though equally handom. In a word, every one hath his lucky moment: you may believe I could not have aid all this without bluhing. The Marques having heard me with uch attention, as clearly dicovered him urpriz'd at my dicoure, was jut going to anwer me, when the Viceroys Lady, who would never with her good will have us both out of her ight, unhappily interrupted us, and urprizing us on the udden, aid, I dare lay a good wager you were peaking of Love: 'tis true, anwered I miling, we were dicouring of a very pleaant quetion, occaioned by being reproached by the Marques for my inenibility. He hath reaon, Madam, replied the Lady to prevent an anwer from the Marques; he who is o deeply in Love, may jutly reproach
you: if you know it not, I can aure you of it, and will in time tell you more. I thought, aid I, we had not been o great trangers, but I might have known it from himelf, without being obliged to another for the News, and if we two were alone, I know how I would quarrel with him for it. All this was poken with an air of raillery, which wrought very effectually on the inclinations of the Marques, which the Lady dicoured of; I applied to my elf, imagining what he poke of it, was done for my honour, and to engage me to an obliging anwer which I gave. She preently fell into other dicoure, and led us inenibly towards the company.

On the morrow, the Marques having mued all night on what I had aid, found me alone looking out at a window of the Palace, and falling inenibly on the dicoure of the day before, asked me, though I had no inclination to love, whether I would be dipleaed at one who loved me with the greatet paion in the World: I anwered, there were but few I would allow that liberty
to; and that in the whole Kingdom I knew but one I could permit to ue that priviledge. I believe he could not but undertand I meant him, and my looks did but too much confirm him in the opinion; he, though he oberv'd it, but would not take notice of it. I know, Madam, ays he, it is extreamly imprudent to propoe a peron of a meaner rank than yours, or one of mall merit, or not Mater of Qualities worthy your eteem; but the peron I peak of, is beyond all exception. Finding him take a coure o contrary to what I expected, I had not patience to permit him to make an end, having ground enough to believe, it was not for himelf he made this Declaration; and interrupting him briskly, A Lover, aid I, (bluhing with anger and hame) perhaps would not dipleae, provided he were like the Marques Hippolito; any other may come too late. I had carce poken thee words, but I repented me of them, and unwilling to hear any more in the confuion the torrent of my Paion had put me in, I withdrew. Oh Heavens! cry'd he, running
after to tay me, How unfortunate am I? Unfortunate, aid I, turning toward him: Is the eteem I have for you a means to make you unfortunate? Yes, Madam, replied he with a igh; that precious and charming eteem, I was made believe, could never be gain'd, which I would have purchaed with all I have dear in the World—He topped there. Well, aid I, what of that eteem? Ah Madam, anwered he, they have made me renounce it. I had no ooner heard thee words but I went on my way, having given him ome looks full of indignation; but eeing him follow me, and not able for very grief to peak to him, I made igns to him with my hand, that he hould come no further. It is beyond imagination what a deperate condition I was in that night: Rage, hame, pite, fury, repentance; in a word, all the Vexations of a Lover, mock'd, betrayed, aaulted me by turns I fell o ick, that for many days I kept my Bed; however I reolved to peak to him once more, to know who had caued him to renounce my eteem, as he had told me.
I preently fancied it was Don Alphono; but was very deirous to learn how the matter had been managed, and expected every day to ee him with his Friend, or with the Viceroys Lady, and that I hould find an opportunity to peak to him of it. In the mean time he came not to my Chamber, though all the Court did me that honour, for the hort time I continued indipoed: this urprized me extreamly, and hearing one day he was in my Anti-chamber, I ent Clarice my Servant to deire him to come and ee me, having omething to ay to him. He would have come intantly, as the Maid brought me word; but the Viceroys Lady, with whom he was dicouring, tay'd him: at which I was not a little atonihed; but much more, when oon after I aw him come in, in the company of that Lady. He looked very pale, and his countenance much altered, which contributed not a little to allay my bitternes againt him, though I had mall reaon to think my elf concerned in honour of that change that appeared in his looks. You ee, Madam, aid I to the Lady at their
entrance, this Gentleman mut be ent for, if we deire the pleaure of his Company. Thee are favours, continued I, not uual with me, and uch as I would not by any means have done him, while it was in my power to have any eteem for him. But ince he hath told me, they have made him renounce my eteem, you may believe, Madam, I am not much dipoed to have any eteem for him; and that what I now do, proceeds not from any uch caue. 'Tis true, anwered the Lady, he does not deerve your eteem, but you mut pardon his Youth. I will pardon him, replyed I, on condition he will tell me who had the power over his Heart or Wit, to make light of an eteem not altogether unworthy a Gentleman of his Quality; and 'tis for that purpoe I have ent for him hither. He tood mute; o that turning my Head towards the Lady, to ask her the reaon of his ilence, I was again urpriz'd to find the Lady in greater diorder than he. I was jut peaking to him again, when I aw him rie to tell me with trouble in his face; I will atisfie
you, Madam, in that particular, but intreat you let me take a fitter time. A fitter time, aid I, and why not now? Is it my Lady that hinders you? You know I conceal nothing from her. Ah, if it be I, aid the Lady, I will withdraw to leave you at liberty; and with that he retired towards a Window, in far greater diorder than if he had been angry. This made me more curious than ever to hear what the Marques would ay to me. Yet he declared himelf no further, but reaching forth his hand towards me, he hewed me a Billet, which I would not have received on any other occaion; but in this Conjuncture I made no cruple of it, believing I hould find in it the Secret I longed for: Hereupon he withdrew without aying a word. And the Lady returning towards me; Well, Madam, aid he, how comes it he is gone, without naming to you the Peron you have o much caue to hate? I mut tell you, 'tis I, and that will urprize you. It really did o, the word he had poken having atonih'd me, I could carce make her an anwer:
You mut know then, continued he, that having told me he had been obliged on the account of my Son to change his thoughts of you, and engage himelf to another Beauty; I preed him for your ake to tell me who it was; and after a long refual, he had the inolence to tell me, 'twas I. You may imagine how I ued him on uch an occaion: However, I was of Opinion, that a little more than ordinary complaiance I had expres'd for him, had given him that Confidence. But finding him enible of his error, I was a little better pacified, and let him ee he was mitaken on all hands. That he hould not have quitted the deign of erving you, being unquetionably the bet deerving in this Court of Paion and eteem of a Peron of his Quality, and that he was very ill advied to make addrees to me, who was neither for Gallant, nor Gallantry. I was no tranger to the Character of this Lady, and knew very well what he aid was quite contrary to the inclinations of her temper. And having had leiure while he poke, to recover my elf from the
atonihment he had cat me in at the beginning of this Dicoure, and to oberve the alteration of her Countenance, I made no doubt of her perfidiounes. This, Madam, aid I very eriouly, was to engage further in my concerns than I deerved, and in truth than I deired. You had formerly told me, this young Gentleman would have pleaed you, had you been as I; and ince he preferred you before me, it was too much for you to part with him for my ake. I did, ays he, but what I ought both for you and my elf. This, Madam, replyed I, is a piece of more than ordinary Friendhip; and I quetion very much, whether among the bet Friends of our Sex, the pleaure of being beloved by a Peron whom all the Ladies of the Court own to be the handomet and bet accomplih'd in Naples, would not prevail over their Friendhip, and make it appear that one Woman eldom cruples to be treacherous to another in caes of this Nature. But, Madam, methinks what you now ay, is omewhat contrary to what you formerly told me of the Paion of the Marques
then wholly for me. I thought o then, I confes, aid he, but I was mitaken. And is it not poible, you hould be now alo mitaken, anwered I, for I have ome reaon to doubt it. You do but deceive your elf, replyed he. Well, Madam, aid I with ome heat, let us try which of us is deceived; peradventure it will appear in this Billet I received from him. Whereupon I fell to the opening of it. The Lady much urpriz'd, asked me, if it came from the Marques. I told her, it did; and that nothing but the curioity I had to clear this Affair, could have prevail'd with me to take it from him. Alas, ays he, what aurance can that give you of the inclinations of a man who changes them every moment; and will, it may be, tell you the ame he hath told me already. I was in uch hate to open the Letter, that I made her no anwer, but fell to reading it, being to this purpoe.

body.p:
How great an unhappynes is it, Madam, in matter of Affection, and great trouble of Heart, to follow other Counels than thoe of our Paion! Never was Peron
o deeply in Love, as I was with you, from the day I firt had the happines to ee you. And I may very well affirm, I continue o till, notwithtanding the many Oaths I have been forced to the contrary. But ome Perons, whom I had not the leat caue to upect of deign, having taken the pains to repreent your humour o haughty and inenible, that I almot depair of gaining your eteem, I was obliged to addres my elf to ome more indulgent Beauty; not out of incontancy, but to cure my elf of a Paion, the conequence whereof I extreamly apprehend. Thoe who advied me to it, were o kind as to condecend to erve me in it: And the truth is, their Complyance was uch, being Perons of Quality, that had not I deired their Aitance, I could not have refued it. But, Madam, there are ome evils for which there is no Remedy. That which your Eyes have done me is of this nature. If I have committed a fault, in entertaining thoughts of breaking my Chains, I mart for it more cruelly than you can deire. I know not to what extremity my grief would drive me for the time I have lot, were it not for the hope I have to redeem it. Be pleaed,
Madam, to give me leave to wait upon you with more Love than ever, and by erious Repentance to deface thoe ill impreions my error have wrought on you, concerning the contancy of my Affection. For hould you be more haughty and inenible than you have been repreented, yet I am reolved to die altogether yours.

div.p:
Ah, Traytor, cry'd the Viceroy's Lady, as oon as I had done reading the Billet, is it poible he hould have the Confidence to jutifie the mot viible incontancy man was ever guilty of, and to accue others of it? Madam, aid I without any Paion, 'tis fit we hould hear him peak for himelf; and if you pleae to tay, we will end for him, and ee how he will defend himelf againt you. Alas, ays he, what hould I tay for? I am not otherwie concerned than on your account. You may now do as you pleae, but if you will be advied by me, ee him no more. That mut not be, Madam, replyed I, though it were but to know who they are he peaks of in the Billet; I mut ee him once
more, and then I hall undertand what meaures to take. I had hardly done peaking but the Marques came in. He thought without doubt the Vice-Roy's Lady would not have favoured me o long with her company after he had been gone; and the impatience he had to know how I took what he wrote in the Billet, or perhaps to tell me what made me o earnet to be informed of, made him preently return. He was not a little urprized to find us together. He was jut tepping back to be gone, but I prayed him to come in. The Viceroy's Lady eeing him, and confounded at the ight of him, or for fear I would put him upon making the dicovery before her, as I had certainly done in the condition things were in, tood up, and taking him by the hand, turning towards me: I have omething (aid he) to tell him; after which you may atisfie your elf. This action of hers moved more my pity than my jealouie. I know very well he was not a Woman of the bet conduct in the World, but I hould never have imagined her Paion could have carried
her o far as (after all he had aid to me) as to make her give in my preence uch an intance of her weaknes. I let them go without aying a word to one or other, but expected to ee the Marques again, and aured my elf of very pleaant divertiement by what he hould tell me of the Lady: But he came not at all that day, which anger'd me not a little. On the morrow I perfectly recovered. My malady was a pure effect of jealouie and vexation, and when I knew how matters tood, I was oon cured of both: Not but that I had reaon to fear the Vice-Roys Lady. But the orry coure I aw her take, and her pitiful conduct, ecured me from the apprehenion of any harm he could do me: I was well enough to appear at Court, but hearing there was a Ball at night, I reolved to be ick one day more, that I might teal at night in Maquerade to the Ball, and there peak with the Marques. My deign took not, for he came not thither all the while I tayed. But by reaon of my going to and fro to eek him out, the Vice-Roys Lady knew me, and being
Alarm'd at my Diguie, followed me to my Chamber, where I was amazed to ee her, and could not believe it was he. Well, and what News of the Marques, aid he? I mut know that of you, Madam, anwered I, for I have not een him ince yeterday, when you denied me the pleaure to dicoure him one moment in a buines you and I were ufficiently concern'd to be atisfied in. I believe, reply'd he, you are now to eek for atisfaction. How can that be, reply'd I, when I have not poken with him never ince. It is reported however, anwered he, you were this Evening together in Maquerade. Thoe, aid I, who report it, are very much mitaken; but I mut beg your pardon, Madam, if I tell you there is not any one but you capable of uch a mitake. I know what becomes me, and there are but few who make a doubt of it: Perons of my Honour are eldom guilty of uch faults. The Vice-Roy's Lady having a deire to vex and fall out with me, never gave over till I had told her part of my mind, and let her undertand I was not to be fool'd
by her. The truths I told her, madded her to that degree, that he broke out into expreions o cruelly offenive, I could not forbear crying, and unwilling he hould have the pleaure to ee the Tears run down my Cheeks, I roe up to retire into my Cloet. What, ays he, I interrupt your Meditations in the Charms of your fine Marques, is not that the caue of your withdrawing? Or rather, continued he, to provoke me yet more, are you going to eek him in your Cloet where you have hid him? That which you ay, Madam, doth o little become you, that nothing but extream madnes could have made you think o unworthy of me; but I ee what pleads your excue. What, reply'd he, I hope I have not great reaon to trut her that will not trut me. And the right I have to over-ee and regulate your Conduct gives me the priviledge to viit any place I upect. With that he took up a Flambeau that lay lighted on my Table, and went up towards my Cloet: I looked upon her with that light and indifference as wholly unconcern'd at her action, which
angred her more than any thing I could have aid to her. I do not yet know what was her deign; for he knew me too well to have the leat upicion of what he charged me with, but it eems he was reolv'd to try me to the utmot, and be reveng'd of me that way. In the mean time, by very ill Fortune for me, the Marques was in the Cloet, and he was the firt that dicovered him; he hrieked out with the urprize of it, which made me turn about that way, and put me into uch a fright, that together with the dipleaure that accident gave me, cat me into a ound, and made me fall as dead upon the Bed near which I then tood. The Marques eized with true or feigned grief for his being the caue of o unhappy an accident, begged my pardon on his knees with tears in his Eyes. What the Lady aid to this I know not, but one of my Chamber-Maids, who came to help me, told me he aw her go out o angry, that fire eemed to parkle out of her Eyes. When I was come to my elf, I aw her not, but the Marques kneeling
before me with a countenance o ad and o dejected, it melted me into pity, and eaed me of more than half of my anger. What have you done, Sir, aid I? you have utterly ruined me. Go and ee me no more but at eaonable hours, and when every body might ee me; after which, though I was very well pleaed with his company, I pray'd him to withdraw, to prevent further occaion of Dicoure.

I am enible, dear Aen, I pend too much time in relating particulars o inconiderable, and abue your Patience in entertaining you with uch trifles. But this having been the bet of my time in that Court, and bet part of my tory, you will excue the difficulty I find in my elf to come to the relation of Accidents o hameful for me, that the memory of them is more terrible than Death. Aen having anwered, that all he had aid was very material; and that he thought himelf equally concerned in the mallet Circumtances of her Life, as well as the greatet, he proceeded in this manner.

The Vice-Roy's Lady having fallen out with me, and finding reaon enough of difference with the Marques, who in pight of her viited me often, you may believe he pat her time very melancholy and ad. The firt time the Marques came to ee me, I inited, that if he deigned to pleae me, he hould begin to do it by telling me in particular all the kindnes and carees pat between the Vice-Roy's Lady and him. But he intreated me with o much Ingenuity not to make ue of the power I had over him, to oblige him to a thing o mean, that his Dicretion prevailed over my Curioity, and made me eteem him the better for it: however he let me know 'twas of her he poke in the Billet, as I had eaily gues'd. The diconolate Lady, who could not but be concern'd for us, was willing to eek Peace, and having found a fair pretence for it, ent me word by one of her Women, that I might do her a pleaure if I would give her a Viit, which I fail'd not to do. She received me chearfully, and with miles in her Countenance, being an Excellent Mitres of the Art
of Diembling, after ome Civilities hewed me, he brought me to the Cloet, where beginning her dicoure with a very great igh, Well, my dear Elenor, aid he, are you till angry with me? I am heartily orry, Madam, aid I, that you gave me caue, who never deerved it. Come, let us agree, aid he, to ay nothing of what is pat, and give me leave to let you ee I am your Friend. It is that I deired, Madam, reply'd I; and the Honour I have always had for you, mut needs make you believe your Friendhip very precious and dear to me. 'Tis enough, aid he; come, tell me preently if there were a propoal of Marriage between the Marques and you; do you love him o well, as not to refue him? Such a Propoal from her appears very upicious, and eeing me laugh, as one who would not be caught in that Trap, I do not peak to you now (continued he, as a Rival) as you have believed me to be, and as perhaps (added he miling) I have formerly been; but as your true and incere Friend I tell you, that if you deire to Marry the Marques,
it hall be your fault if it be not done; with that he hewed me a Letter from the Vice-Roy to my Father, written to that purpoe at the requet of the Marques, and aid, your Father hath o much repect for my Husband, that there is no doubt but it will take effect; the Marques having deired my leave to peak of it to the Vice-Roy: and finding by the Character of the Letter, they endeavoured in good earnet to unite me to a Man who was furnih'd with all I could wih, as well for a ettlement, as to pleae my Affection; I was ravihed with Joy, but let it appear as little as I could, mitruting my Fortune, epecially being in the hands of a Peron who would dearly repent it, before it could be effected. I thanked her with the mot acknowledging and affectionate expreions I could invent; and there paed o many Carees on the one ide and on the other, that you would have thought we had never been o great Friends before. At my return I found the Marques in my Chamber, where he waited to bring me this pleaing
News, with a Countenance full of Joy; and that the Vice-Roy had given him free liberty to viit me. I told him I had heard all this from a Peron he could not eaily gues, and in truth it was hardly credible it hould be the Vice-Roy's Lady. I told him it was he, and related all our Dicoure.

The Liberty granted the Marques to viit me when he pleaed, having heightned the affection we had one for another, degenerated by degrees into a kind and tender familiarity. He took a little more upon him than had been allowed him, and more indeed than I ought to have permitted him. But 'tis hard for one in Love, o deeply as I was, to be proof againt the Amorous aaults of a Man he expects to be her Husband on the Morrow. At firt I made reitance enough, and would not o much as give him my hand to kis; but Love blinds o, that he doth inenibly lead us away, and accutom us to things we never durt think of. After the firt bluh, the ret follows of coure. We expected with equal impatience my Fathers anwer.
We were already mutually engaged, o that if his anwer hould not have proved favourable, we were reolved to compleat our happines: Such engagements given to ave a Maids Honour, are but nares Love lays for her Virtue. The Marques, as all true Lovers, being impatiently earnet for the poeion of my Peron as well as Affection, whereof he was aured, and fearing cros Accidents that might hinder our Blis, let me know, amongt ome little favours I allowed him to take, that he was very deirous to obtain of my gift what I had forbid him to hope without my Fathers conent; and that if I loved him, I would make it appear in obliging him in that particular. I made as if I did not undertand him, but by degrees he poke o intelligibly, that I was under the neceity of being very angry with him, or of defending my elf with Arguments: Finding it impoible to be angry with a Man I loved, I fell to Diputing, but he was too hard for me. And certainly, in matters of Love, a Maid that comes to reaoning, is in danger of being lot.
However our combat lated long enough, to make me fancy I had atisfied my humour; but at lat I mut yield. I thought there needed not o much caution, with a peron who had given the Viceroy his word that he would marry me, and aured me (as I believed) by a thouand Oaths, that he would make me his Wife. He was to come to me in my Chamber at night, an hour after all hould be in bed; and becaue my Chamber was near that of the Viceroys Ladies, where I had liberty of entrance at my pleaure, I told him I would leave the door open, and pray'd him not to make a noie, or peak a word, let the Lady hould hear us. You ee Aen, I conceal nothing from you; though I might alledge many reaons in excue of my fault. I cannot tell you all this without bluhing; for I mut confes had I been more wie, or more prudent, I could not have been o unfortunate as I am. The Viceroy was gone that day out of Town; all things eemed to favour us, but it was for my ruin. The hour was come, and I heard a man entring oftly into
my Chamber, for there was no light to ee him by, and I eaily believed it was my dear Servant. I received him with the kindnes of a Woman in Love, and made no doubt but it was he; for he had the ame imbroider'd Watcoat, which he had caued to be made againt our Wedding, being one of the richet ever een in the Court. Part of the night we pas'd in an amorous ilence, till at lat he fell aleep. As for me, I found my elf a little indipoed, and wanting a light to find omething to take, I ventured to go into the Ladies Chamber, which commonly had a watch-light burning all night. Having opened the door from my Chamber to hers, I was not a little urprized, when approaching the watch-light, and cating my eyes towards her to ee if he were aleep, the Curtains being all open becaue of the hot weather, I aw a man in his cloaths lying by her. I doubted very much whether it were bet to go back whence I came, or take away the watch-light; but the need I had of this prevail'd with me to go on, and light the candle I had in my hand:
and having een o much, I was poet with a Spirit of curioity to know who that fortunate Gallant might be; I perceived him in the habit of Marques Hippolito. I was urpriz'd at the adventure, and had I not been fully perwaded I had newly left him in my Chamber, I do not know what extravagances I might have run into. However this Circumtance inflamed my deire of knowing who it was. I perceived he was of the ame tature with the Marques, and had the ame hair; the Ladies arm was over his face, o that I could not ee it. I was at the beds feet, and could not be mitaken; I trembled all over, as an Omen of my mifortune. Heavens! aid I within my elf, am I awake or aleep? is not that the Marques? could he quit me this night to come to this Lady? perhaps they held correpondence together, and he knew he was to pas this night with me. All thee Reflections were made in a moment, and the next moment after that, I came into
my own Chamber, to find out the truth. But how was I atonihed to find the Marques there too? Oh Heavens! cry'd I, which of the two is the counterfeit? And drawing near him in my Chamber, I perceiv'd by the colour of his Hair, how unhappily I was deceived, and that it was Don Alphono was there. What a Fury, what Rage did this put me in? I eiz'd the Ponyard he had laid on my Table, and not knowing with which of the three to begin, being all equally perfidious, I thought the Marques as mot criminal, was firt to be acrificed to my jut revenge, for fear of an Ecape. So that I went into the other Chamber; but the noie that I made, having awaked Don Alphono, he was amazed to ee a Light, and perceiving me enter his Mothers Chamber, he got up in a trice, and frightned at the ight of the Ponyard in my Hand, he ran after me, and laid hold on me by the Arm, jut as I was going to tab that Traytor the Marques: but he
was alo ufficiently urpriz'd to ee me lifting up my hand to kill the Marques, lying by his Mothers ide. He was enraged at the ight, and to wah away the tain of his Family with the bloud of the Traitor, was ready to execute that vengeance he had hindred me to take; but I taid him, and throwing my elf upon him, Traitor, aid I, this blow was not reerved for thee, thou halt not have the pleaure of being firt reveng'd. At thee words, and the butle that we made, the Marques and the Viceroy's Lady awaking, were at their wits end, not knowing what reolution to take. The Marques judging that the Ponyard Don Alphono had in his Hand, threatned only him, made ue of the time I held him, to lay hold of his own, and tand on his Guard. I left them in this furious Diorder, hoping they would ufficiently revenge one on another, for their Treaon againt me; and re-entring my Chamber, I hut the door on that ide, and having taken with me
all that was coniderable in Money or Jewels, I went out at another door, and ran through the Streets like a mad Woman, to eek a Felucca in the Port, to carry me to any place my depair would lead me. I was o unhappy as not to find one ready, and had not the patience to tay, for fear of being purued, and forced back to that Court, where I had rather die than appear. At lat with much ado I found a Barque bound for Barcellona; provided they went far enough from Italy, and that my Name and my Birth were concealed, I cared not whither they carried me; o that I went on board, without taking a moment to conider. 'Tis not a ingle Accident makes us unfortunate; the greatet diaters have commonly a large train of misfortunes: Thus far my oul entertained not a thought, but what the tranports of depair and reentment had uggeted. But when I aw my elf at Sea, and in no other Company than that of five or ix poor Mariners, who knew not what
to think of me, my heart was o full, that nothing could eae it but a torrent of tears. I will not trouble you with a Relation of the ad thoughts I had for two or three days that I had the opportunity of a olitary entertainment; but on the fourth I found my elf plunged into new afflictions. About Sun-riing the Sea-men put up uch a lamentable cry, it almot broke my heart: I thought we had been Shipwrack'd, and asked what the matter was, more out of curioity than any fear of death, being the thing I heartily wih'd for. I found the Gallies of Bierti had us in Chae, and took us an hour after: I received this diater with uch tranquillity of pirit, as really atoniht all the Spectators. All my fear was for my peron, having fallen into the hands of men who are the mot barbarous and inhumane on earth, and have no repect for our Sex. However, whether it was my particular good fortune, or that they had ome regard for a Woman which appeared of more than ordinary Quality, I may truly ay, that etting aide the haughtines
and rudenes of their firt approach, in forcing open the door of my Cabbin with their feet; I was better ued than the ret, and more favourably than I expected. As oon as the Souldiers aw me, not one of them entred; only the Captain of the Galley took that liberty, and very civilly asked me in Italian who I was, and for what place I was bound. I hid from him both my Name and my Quality, telling him, I was called Laura, and went for Barcellona to my Father, then in the ervice of the King of Spain. Then I put into his hand a little Box, in which were my Money and my Jewels; and the more to oblige him, I told him I made him a Preent worth above twenty thouand Crowns (as in truth it was) and that I might have thrown it overboard, as mot of the Sea-men had done their Cloaths and their Merchandize. The acknowledgment I deired of him, was that I might be civilly ued; which he promied me, and the ame time told me, I hould ay nothing of the Box, auring me of a hare at our arrival at Tunis. I was
ravihed at this Conjuncture, not o much for the hopes he gave me of retoring part of my Jewels, but becaue this ecret rendred me ueful and neceary to the Captain, and obliged him to a greater care of me. And the truth is, I had no reaon to complain; he caued me to be preently carried aboard his Galley, and gave me his own Cabbin, and never came into it till we arrived at Bierti. Our Voyage was not long; we had a great Calm, and having in three days gain'd the Cape of Carthage, we got afe on the fourth into the Port of Bierti; where being landed, I was put into a kind of Litter carried by a Camel, and o carried to Tunis, under a Guard of five or ix Hore-men. I fell to the Baa's hare, who joyful of it, made a Preent of me to his Lady.

Thus you have, dear Aen, the fortune of a Maid born of an illutrious Family, and to a plentiful Etate, as you very well know. The Turk being perfectly acquainted with the condition of her Family, could not ufficiently admire the trangenes of her fate, and aured her of his bet endeavours
to make her more happy for the future, and to gain her liberty to return to her Countrey, which he had no caue to cruple; That the Accident at Naples was a diater to be remedied by her Marriage with the Son of the Vice-roy, who doubtles would be glad of it: That if it hould fall out otherwie, he had many excellencies and advantages to comfort her againt all the diaters of her life: That her misfortune in the Neapolitan Court could not be laid to her fault, but the infamous Treaon of a man, who ooner or later was ure to be punihed for his Crime. In a word, after long dicoure to this purpoe, he renewed protetations of his readines to erve her, and to leave no tone unturned to free her from her miery: That he had many good Friends about the Dey, and was very well aured he could not take any initer reolution againt her, but he mut have notice of it time enough to prevent, or ecape it. Laura was not wanting to her duty of gratitude, for thee ignal tetimonies of Affection to her Family and her; and could not ufficiently thank Heaven,
that in the midt of her misfortunes he had met a Man o devoted to her Service, and of unquetionable fidelity.

Thus Aen left her a little comforted againt the malignity of her detiny, and promied to come again, and pas part of the night following with her, being obliged that day to wait on the Dey, to ee how Matters were carried.
div.trailer: The End of the Second Part.

div.head: THE HAPPY SLAVE.
The Third Part.
div.p:
ASSEN got home, but was extreamly atonih'd the Moor was not return'd: he went to bed, but had very bad ret, fearing ome ill accident had befallen the Moor. And conidering of what dangerous conequence it might be to him in the preent conjuncture, to be found to have held correpondence with Mahomet, he began to repent he had o rahly expoed himelf to dicovery. The thought of this kept him from leeping; but at length the Moor arriv'd, and having given him an account what had taid him o long,
diipated his fears, and quieted his Spirits.

Aen was atisfied, took the Baa's Letter, read it; and intantly dipatched the Moor back again, it being a pretty while before day, and a fitter time than at the fourth watch, as the Baa had appointed by his Letter.

The Baa was urpriz'd to ee the Moor o quickly returned; but having heard the reaon, he was not dipleaed, but hid him in his Tent; and as oon as it was night, ent him in earch of his General confident and dearet friend the Mater of the Gallies. Romadan, ays he to him, with ome diorder in his looks, what think you of me when I tell you I intend to lye at Tunis to night. I mut tell you Sir, ays Romadan the Mater of the Gallies, I think you too wie to expoe your elf to that hazard without aurance from our Friends there, that they will open you the Gates; nor do I believe you can take pleaure in putting your Country to Fire and Sword. You undertand me not, replies the Baa,
when I tell you I deign to lye at Tunis to night, 'tis not to execute my jut vengeance againt it; I am too tender of the Blood of my friends, to revenge my elf by night, when I cannot ditinguih my Friend from my Foe; I peak of going thither, only attended by a Moor I have here, to peak with Aen, to learn what pas'd at the Divan, to enter the Catle, ee Laura, and return, Romadan heard him with that attention and ilence, which ufficiently expres'd his wonder and atonihment. He thought it unneceary to ue reaons to diuade him from a deign o rah and extravagant. The Baa who read in his looks the ubtance of what he might have aid to him. I confes, ays he, I expoe my-elf to ome hazard, and that it is impudence, or (you may call it) folly to run uch a rique; but that matters not, and to eae you of the fear of being charg'd for not telling me what you think of the buines, I declare to you, I ent not for you to have your advice, whether I ought to put it in execution or not for that's already reolved. The
tory they tell me of my Wife, that he is gone away with the Chritian, and that Laura is at home with the Dey, are the things that prevail with me, nothing but a ight of her, can convince me 'tis true; the more I think of it, the more it perplexes me: I would be atisfied at leat how the buines was carried, and there is no knowing it but by the Slave. However, were the reaons I have told you, not ufficient to make you approve of the deign, I cannot refue an irreitible paion to o mall a compliance.

The Baa having aid this, held his peace, in expectation of Romadan's anwer, who having for ome time fixt his eyes on the ground, lift them up on the udden, aying, God preerve you Sir from the michief you run into; but if it be o ordained, you cannot avoid your detiny. Then he hewed him the many obtacles and dangers he hould meet with before he could get to Aen. How impoible it was to effect ome of the things he deired; that he could not enter the Catle without being dicovered, and that for a ight of a
Chritian Girl his Slave, he hazarded the ruin of himelf, his friend, and his party, that a little patience would make him mater of his deigns without pains or danger. The Baa, intead of being perwaded by Romadan's reaons, expres'd by his countenance a viible impatience to hear a dicoure o unneceary and ueles after the reolution he had taken. His paion tempted him to try his fortune, and deprived him of patience as incompatible with love.

The night being pretty well advanced, he diguied himelf the bet he could; and having given Romadan uch orders as were neceary, that his abence might not be perceived, he went away with the Moor, who led him a way he came the night before: they entred the Town without meeting any, but being heard by Aen's Houe, they fell among a company of People belonging to the Divan, the Baa's worn Enemies: But by good fortune he pas'd undicovered, for which he was obliged to the Moor, who being
a witty fellow, told thoe who would have taid them, that he was one ick of the Plague, whom he had in charge to carry to the Pet-houe. This made them tand at a ditance, and give them free paage; though that dieae be not o dreadful there as in other places, being very common and ordinary in thoe parts.
The Baa was glad of o eaie an ecape; and when he got to Aen's, he rewarded the Moor according to the merit of o coniderable a ervice.

Aen was abroad at the Baa's arrival, but was extreamly urprized at his return to ee the Baa there. Ah! Sir, aid he, embracing him, is it poible you would hazard your elf thus? it might have been excuable in a hare-brain'd young fellow, who had nothing to loe but his life, but for a man of your prudence and conduct, (being the econd Peron of the Kingdom) to come, without deign perhaps, at leat without neceity to throw your elf into your Enemies hands, and expoe your life to a thouand
dangers. This Sir, how ill oever you take it, is a thing I can never pardon you: For Sir, adds he, what could have oblig'd you to hazard your elf thus?

The Baa fell a laughing, and taking all in good part that was poken by Aen, whoe kindnes he was aured of, asked him if he had ever been in love, and whether he knew not that love had made the greatet of men guilty of faults, and that thoe faults had always their pardon: But Sir, aid Aen, what have you to do with love? is it not Laura you are in love with? and is not he in the Catle? Yes, replies the Baa, but being in your cutody, it cannot be impoible to have a ight of her. Aen would have diuaded him from the deign, as the mot extravagant and rah he had ever enterprized; but prevailed no more than the mater of the Gallies. Strength of reaon and fear of dangers are obtacles too weak to top the progres of a paionate Lover. Love feeds upon hope, and death is not half
o formidable as the happines of eeing a Mitres is charming and pleaant. The Baa reolved, whatever befell him, to go into the Catle. But it was impoible to do it by Night, the Gates being then open only for Aen, and others the Dey's principal Officers. So that it mut of neceity be between Nine in the Morning and Six at Night; and the trict Examination they ued in that time would have cool'd any Man but the Baa from proceeding in o deperate a deign. But thoe Southern Lovers are too hot to be cold by Obtructions that appears invincible to others. Aen told him, he had no better way than to put him into one of the Meal-acks he had order to end into the Catle on the morrow in a Cart. The Baa was content, and thought it an excellent invention; and that there could be no danger in it at all. Having reolved on this, they pat part of the Night in Dicoure of the preent poture of Affairs, what pat at the Divan, what deigns the Dey had, what Forces were raied, and uch other particulars as were neceary for the Baa to know. After
this, they went to Bed, where Aen took his ret; but as for Mahomet, he had no mind to leep, he dreamt waking of the happines of eeing the fair Laura on the morrow.

At length the day appear'd, and the Cart was loaded with Meal-acks for the Catle, and among them the Bag with the Baa in't, was o plac'd, that he lay pretty conveniently. The Moor led the Hores, and Aen walked at ome ditance before; the Catle-gate was opened and no earch made in the Cart, the Dey's Secretary was Peronally Convoy to. They pat freely to the Magazin of Victuals, where everal Moors intantly attended to unload; but Aen very dextrouly got rid of them, ending them away on everal Errands. This was well for the Baa, who having been almot tifled in the Bag, had untyed it, to take a little breath, and had certainly been dicovered, had thoe Moors taid in the Magazin. Aen left him there all that day, not thinking it fit to bring him to Laura till Night; o that he locked him up there, took the Key in his Pocket, and went
to the Dey's Palace to learn what News.

Poor Laura being all day alone, thought it very long, and with great impatience wih'd for the Night, that he might have a ight of her dear Friend Aen. At length the hour came he uually viited her, but no news of Aen, which troubled her extreamly. At lat, he heard the Door open, and riing to meet him, Did you but know, Aen, ays he, the Sufferings I lye under in the condition I am in, having no Friend but you, you would not have made me pine o long for a ight of you; for in good truth, I am half dead with taying for you. Aen fell a laughing, and turning about to the Baa, who followed him, here is one, ays he, knows how to bring you to Life again, and I doubt not but for his ake you will pardon my long tay. Aen had not told the Baa of the Ancient intimate Acquaintance he had with Laura; this made him interrupt her o quickly, to make her take notice of him. But he was o white all over with lying in the Meal-ack, that he took him for one of Aen's Men; but eeing him
laugh, he viewed him more narrowly, and knew him, Oh Heavens! is it you, Sir? ays he. Oh! whither are you come in earch of an unfortunate wretch, which hath already given you o much trouble, and too great caue of complaint! It is eaie, anwers the Baa, to pardon thoe we love. But is it poible you are here, and that the Sultanes is gone away in your tead? tell me, was it he that betray'd you, or was it Alexander? I know not what to think of it; but when I conider his proceedings in this lat adventure, I cannot upect him treacherous. For 'twas not his fault I dicovered not the Sultanes, it was I hindred him to take off her Barnus, that I might ee her, However, if he loved you, I am ufficiently Reveng'd of you, for you have lot more than I, and if he was fale to you, you may comfort your elf with the aurance of the affection of a Peron not o unworthy of your favour as he was. Thee lat words put Laura to the bluh; but making no anwer to them, As for me, Sir, aid he, I neither lot a Lover in him, nor have caue to charge him with falhood,
but mut lay on my ill Fortune all the blame of my being left behind him. You urprize me much, replies the Baa, and make me conclude you an excellent Diembler, or my elf the mot abued Man in the World. Call to mind, Sir, ays Laura, what I told you o often, that my affection for Alexander was very indifferent; and to be taken off when I pleaed. The Ladies of your Country differ very much from thoe of Chritendom in their coure of Love; yours are very uceptible, eaily take impreion, and are equally uncontant. Ours are more hie of engaging in Love, but when engaged, their love is more lating. You believed me a Turk, and everal times did me Honours, due only to the Sultanes, whom you often mitook for me. The Sultanes, replies the Baa, much urpriz'd at the News. The very ame, Sir, ays Laura, for 'tis now time to diabue you; and ince I may jutly glory to have made of my Paion for Alexander a Sacrifice to her Love, I may now be allowed to declare it, when he is out of all danger of inconvenience by my owning it. The Sultanes, Sir, continued he, more affected than I with the good qualities of that Chritian,
looked upon him as worthy of her Love. But permit me to ay, you may thank your elf for it, who firt ought out the means to gain the Honour of finding a Gallant for your Lady. You may believe, replies the Baa, I deign'd no uch matter, yet I pardon it in a Woman I had no kindnes for. But the falenes of the Chritian was unpardonably bae, who beides the regard he hould have had for the daily favours I did him, ought to have oberved at leat the Laws of Hopitality. The Sultanes, Sir, aid Laura, had a Beauty of power to corrupt the mot upright of Men; and had he been anothers Wife, I durt not have undertaken for your integrity in the cae. I had a deire to ee the Chritian; you brought him into the Seraglio; he had a ight of him: He was handom, he loved him, and told him o; what could he do? The Baa could not forbear laughing at her relating the tory. And 'tis all the concern the Turks expres for the falenes of their Wives, epecially thoe they have no love for, having Seraglio's well tor'd, and the
priviledge to change Wives at pleaure. The Baa very patiently took the los of his Sultanes, and told Laura it mut be her fault if he hould not be now more happy than ever. The ubtile Slave, very enible how ueful he might be to her in the preent conjuncture, thought it uneaonable to give him a repule, but reolv'd to manage to advantage o good an overture; he told him only, that was not a time to make Love. You ee, Sir, continues he, I am here in a Prion, I know not how to get out of. But I know how to do it, replies the Baa haughtily; and if within three days you be not at Liberty, I'le fill the Streets of this Town with the Bodies of the Inhabitants. Ah Sir! anwers Laura, that were the way not to ave me, but to haten my Death. And it beeing known I am the caue of this Diorder, you may eaily gues what Mercy I hall find. If you have, Sir, any value for my Life, ince it may be aved without hedding Blood, and that matters are now in a way of accomodation, let me intreat you not to think of thoe horrible extremities. Believe me, ays the Baa, 'tis their
deign to amue me, till the Troops they expect from Tripoly be arriv'd; but I hall take Order for that, and if you will prevent inconveniences that may happen, you mut reolve to get out hence this Evening, and go along with me. Get out hence, Sir, replies Laura, and how hall it be done, out of a Catle where I am under Guard, and have o many Gates to pas? You ee, ays the Baa, pight of all thoe Guards, and thoe Gates, I have entred, and reolve to get out again; and may not you o too? But, Sir, ays Laura, conider I am a Woman, and however diguied, may be eaily dicovered by my gate, or my tature; and the leat obtacle we meet with, will put me into uch a fright, will infallibly ruin both you and me. Aen fortified her Reaons with his, and abolutely condemned the Enterprize propoed, as expoing the Baa and her to apparent danger of inevitable ruin. You hall ee, Sir, adds he, by the difficulty you and I hall find to get out, the trouble we hould have to get a Woman along with us. I am of Opinion with the ret of your Friends, 'tis bet to come
to an accommodation. The Troops from Tripoly will be long a coming, and if you keep the Town treightly block'd up a few days longer, you will oblige the People to Petition the Dey to make Peace, which we of your Party will not fail to help forward: And the Dey being of a timerous irreolute temper, will be glad of the pretence to come to an Agreement.

The Baa, though more inclin'd to violent than moderate actions, yielded this time to the perwaion of two Perons who were the dearet to him of any, and whoe interet he knew it was not give him any Counel to his diadvantage. He told them he would tay a Week longer, but if in that time neither the Threats nor Interceion of his Friends hould prevail, he would make ue of ome Stratagem to reduce the Town; and if that failed, he would employ all his Force to bring the Dey to Reaon.

Aen was eaily induced to aent to all this, knowing the Town was ill provided of Corn, and that the Inhabitants began already to be treightned, and murmured at the exigences
they were reduc'd to, and not without caue, although it was given out thee murmurs were raied by thoe of the Baa's Party, in favour of his deigns.

The Baa hifting his Dicoure from the general affairs to his private concerns, deired Laura to give him a particular account of Alexander's Amour with the Sultanes, which Laura related in the mot civil expreions he could, not forgetting the Adventure in the Chamber of Repoe, where the Baa had mitaken his Lady for her: the Baa could hardly believe this, and was more vext at it, than all the ret of the tory. Then he told him the deign the Sultanes and he had to go both aboard, and why the Sultanes had put her elf into the Basket without acquainting Alexander with her intentions. I do verily believe it, aid the Baa, for I was in the Chamber when the Basket was brought in, and feign'd it was you; and was unwilling Alexander hould do you the leat violence. I gave Order my elf to have it carried aboard, and together with Alexander went along with
it to the Port. Aen and Laura could not forbear laughing. The Baa told them he was as ready to laugh at it as they, but that Laura made one of the party, and had a hand in putting the trick on him. For as for his Wife, the hatred he bore her Father, and the mall kindnes he had for her, were ufficient aurances he was not orry to be rid of her. But he expected atisfaction from Laura for the ill Offices he had done him; none being more guilty than he of the Treaon of the Sultanes. Raillery made up the ret of the Dicoure, and the Night being far gone, Aen, not affected as the Baa with the Charms of Laura, told him it was time to withdraw. The Baa intreated him to tay a little longer, and aid, while Night lated, he thought there was no danger; and that he had not taken o much pains to enjoy that lovely Girl only for a moment. At lat, Laura acquainted him with the fear he was in, having been o long together, which heightned the danger; giving the Guards caue to upect o long an interview, and to top his paage if he taid
