much longer. The Baa, to atisfie her, retired, making new protetations of a Paionate Lover, who would rather perih a thouand times, than not ee her delivered from the hands of her Enemies by an Honourable Peace, or a bloody War.

A new invention mut be thought of for the getting out of the Catle, where the Examination was as trict almot at going out as at entrance. Aen led the Baa back again to the Magazin, and having daubed his Face ufficiently with Meal, laid a parcel of empty Sacks on his houlders, without any diturbance, pat all the Guards with him, as a Servant of Aen's. It was not yet day; and the Baa thought it fit to make ue of his time, to return before Morning to the Camp, where he thought his preence very neceary. Aen bore him company to the Walls of the Town, and having help'd him over, took his leave.

Laura longed extreamly to hear what was become of him, and could not ret till he aw Aen. Cheer you, Madam, aid he, as he entred her
Chamber. The Baa is out of danger, and all will be well. Alas! dear Aen, anwers he, peradventure things may go well, but not for me. You will be certainly et at Liberty, replies Aen, and in very few days. Yes, ays Laura, I hall be et at Liberty from the Dey, to be made Prioner to the Baa, whoe Paion will render my Imprionment a thouand times more unfortunate than my preent retraint. Heard you not what he aid? And what will become of me, when in his power? Ah, Aen, adds he, with Tears in her Eyes, I did but too clearly fore-ee the misfortunes that did threaten me, unles Heaven divert them. A Maid of my Quality had better die a Prioner, than buy her Liberty at that rate. Aen ighing for pity, anwered, he had already thought of all he aid, and that it was not without caue, he o much oppoed the Baa's deigns of taking her away that Night. That he could have found means enough for it, had he thought it for her advantage; But that he reolved to repreent to her firt, how much harder it would be for her to get out of the
Baa's hands than the Dey's. And that he was very glad he had firt poken of it; that he would keep his word with her, to do her all the Service he could, to help her back into her Countrey; that he was very enible it was as much as his Fortune was worth, and perhaps his Life; both which he mut hazard in the cae: but that he never crupled to expoe the one, or the other, but was ready to acrifice both for the interet of a Family he was more indebted to; and that he was very willing to return among the Chritians, whoe Religion and Cutoms he loved far better than thoe of his Countrey.

This uhered in a long Dicoure of the Buines in hand; the Concluion was, that Aen hould ue the interet of his Friends with the Dey, to perwade him to et Laura at liberty, and end her back into her Country, to prevent the Confuion to be feared, if he hould be obliged to retore her to the Baa, and ee her upply his Daughter St. Room. That, if this would not take, he hould try the utmot extremities, to endeavour
the getting her on board a Brigandine of his, which hould be made ready to carry her away with the firt Opportunity. Poor Laura, deeply enible of the Obligation he had to o honet a Man, told him more than once, he might aure himelf, he would not be ungrateful for o coniderable Services; and that he hould never fail of a Friend while he lived, but might command any thing in the power of her Family. Aen, who needed no promies to perwade him in this particular, took his leave; and went to pend the ret of the Night in thinking of the buines, for which his inclination and gratitude were motives ufficiently powerful to engage his utmot endeavours. He lept not a wink, but as oon as it was day, he went to viit thoe he thought to make ue of, to peak to the Dey. Of thee, Beyran-Aga, the Dey's Favourite, was one, in whom he placed mot confidence, as mot favouring the Chritians, and his particular Friend. He found him ready to erve him, but at the ame
time, he deired the favour of eeing the Slave. Aen fearing the effects of her Beauty on a young man, as the Aga, might obtruct the deign, was o far from expreing a willingnes to comply with him, that he trained his invention to find the mot pecious pretences to divert him. Beyran took it for a denyal of his Requet, and was omewhat dipleaed. He thought Aen was in Love with her, and told him only, he would do him all the Service in his power to peruade the Dey to give the fair Slave her Liberty. But the truth is, he endeavoured it but coldly; o that neither the Dey believed, a time might might come he might give Laura in exchange for his Daughter, or that the Baa loving her as he did (in cae of neceity) to make Peace with him, would for her ake grant him better Conditions, he was not of Opinion with Aen's Friends, who advied him to be rid of her.

Aen much troubled his project had failed, reolved to put himelf into a condition of tealing her away, helping to effect it as a thing depending intirely
on himelf. Beyran whoe deires to ee Laura increaed, by the difficulty he found of obtaining it from Aen, would not ask it of him the econd time; but went traight to the Dey, to beg leave to ee her, under pretence of learning from her, the truth of what was reported concerning the Sultanes, and the Chritian, who was fled. The Dey too well aured of the amour betwixt them, by the evidence of the Moor, who carried the Basket; and of everal Women of the Seraglio, and other Circumtances little needed further Information. But Beyran being his Favourite, and thinking his requet proceeded meerly from curioity of eeing the fair Slave, he granted it; and gave order to Laura's Guards to let him ee her.

This Favourite had heard the Slave was very handom, but could not learn how long he had been at Tunis, nor how taken; fortune having o ordered it, that he addreed his inquiry to Perons that could give him no certain account.

Aen had been buie that day, arming his Brigandine under pretence of ending her a cruiing, and commanded his People, being almot all Chritian Slaves, to be ready at the Cape of Carthage to ail with the firt Orders. Laura was dipos'd the night before, to venture paing the Sea in that little Veel: The weather was fair, the Seaon pleaant, and they hoped, if the wind erved, to reach the Ile of St. Peter in two days. Aen goes to viit her, and finds her trembling for fear: Madam, ays he, this is not a time to tremble, but to arm your elf with Reolution and Courage. I am a Woman, Aen, anwers he, and one unhappy enough to have caue to fear the wort, both for you and my elf. Aen endeavoured to hearten her, aying, he hould be et at liberty on the morrow, and that he would take her out of the Catle without difficulty or danger. Laura was in fear till, and o much diordered, he knew not where to begin to provide for her ecape; when on the udden, he heard her Chamber door open, and turning about, aw a man enter, which frightned her
o (apprehending a dicovery) that he fell in a Swoon with thee words in her mouth; Ah! Lord we are undone! Aen extreamly urprized at the accident, and the Moor foreeeing the Aga, knew not what to think might occaion his company thither, believing it could not be, but in behalf of the Dey. Both Beyran and he were buie about Laura, holding her up, but of the two Beyran eemed mot concern'd. He viewed and reviewed her Countenance, her tature, her hair, her hands, with a diligence and trouble too extraordinary, not to urprize Aen, to whom he had not yet aid a word. But all on the udden, giving free paage to a thouand ighs, his urprize had topt or upended: Oh Heavens! Cries he as a man tranported, 'tis he, 'tis he, my Dear Eleanor. And at the ame time falling down at her knees, embraced them with that tendernes and height of affection, you would have thought he would have died there for joy. Thee words and tranports, and hearing him call her Eleanor, urprized Aen, he knew not whether it was the
Aga he aw there, or ome other that had borrowed his hape. Laura the mean while was pretty well come to her elf, and angry at eeing at her feet a man he knew on no other account, but that the ight of him had almot cot her life, truggled the bet he could to get from him But the Aga, with eyes full of tears, and not able to ay a word held her o much the fater. Laura extreamly atonih'd, Sir, ays he, if this be an effect of pity, you have for the fortune of an unfortunate Slave, I have done ill to be o much alarm'd at the ight of you. But I thought you came on a deign contrary to my wihes. You little know, Madam, ays the Aga, with a languihing tone, the Peron protrate before you.

Laura, feigning he knew the voice, fixt her eyes on him to take a better view: Heavens! cries he, what do I ee, is it poible it hould be he? With that he falls into a econd Swoun into the arms of Aen, who much troubled at it, intreated the Aga to withdraw a little, fearing the ight of him might be the death of the poor Maid, not knowing who he
was. What ay you, ays the Aga? Alas! he knows me too well, being the ole caue of all her misfortunes. Aen, I know you be honet, and my very good Friend, and therefore I apprehend no danger in telling you, he is a Peron, whoe Merits as well as Birth make her worthy your Care; and one for whom I would loe a thouand Lives to ave her from harm. Aen hearing this, fell from one atonihment to another, and would have fain cleared the Mytery of the Adventure, but was o buied with endeavouring to fetch Laura again, that he thought it convenient to repite the Dicoure to a fitter Opportunity. The Aga extreamly concerned, aited him with extraordinary diligence; and Laura beginning to take breath, Aen asked her, if he deired that Turk hould quit the Room, and told her, he was the Aga, the Dey's Favourite, he had told her of. She making no anwer, turned her dying Eyes towards the Aga, and with a languihing voice, Ah cruel, aid he, What Fate brought thee hither to perecute me to Death? Beyran could not hear that Language,
without falling the econd time at her feet, and wahing them with a torrent of tears without peaking a word: Leave me Traytor, ays he, leave me, that I may dye in quiet, rather than be deluded again with thy tears, which deceitfully as they are, have but too trong an effect on my feeble heart. Aen the pectator of o tender a Scene, having freh in memory the tory of Laura, with Marques Hippolito, and Don Alphono, knew not what to think of it. The Aga was a Renegado arrived at Tunis a year before; and Aen fancied he might be one of thoe Lovers, and rather the Marques Hippolito, than Don Alphono. Laura in the height of her anger, having expres'd a tendernes for him, which he could not have retained, but for one he had loved. He had a deire to know the bottom of the buines, but thought it uneaonable to interrupt them, and was in hopes this Scene would end in a dicovery of the Mytery. Yet being himelf traightned in time, and that they were fallen into a deep ilence, uing only expreions of mutual ighs. He thought fit to ay to
the Aga (whom he ufficiently perceived no Enemy of Laura's) had my former acquaintance with you been too mall to give me hopes, you would not cros the deign we have in hand; yet Sir, what I have but now een and heard, were enough to perwade me, you will be o far from obtructing it, that I aure my elf, we hall have your aitance to compas it. By my requet to you yeterday, you know my endeavours for the Liberty of this Slave: thoe proved ineffectual but I have thought of other means, which if you pleae, we will execute this evening. You know well enough the Baa is paionately in love with her, if we give him time to ee her once more, it will not be in our power to get her out of his hands: If a War be reolved on, it will be equally difficult to ave her: And who knows but he may be put to death here, the People being already extreamly incened againt her, as the caue of all this diorder; and upon the noie of a War, they will be too apt to make her a Sacrifice. Let us be wie
in time, all things are in readines, and if you will make ue of them preently, I do warrant the ucces. The Aga looked upon him as a man newly out of a Trance, and oppres'd with grief. Let us do, Dear Aen, ays he, whatever you think fit; for in the condition that I am in, I am not capable to give you any reaonable Counel, but will do all you hall deire of me, and imploy my whole power in the Catle to favour your deign, and help this Lady out of danger. Ingrateful man, anwers Laura, do you peak of helping me out of danger? you who are the caue of all my misfortunes. Go wretch, go, I'le never be o much obliged to you, but chue rather to dye here in Prion, than not to have till jut caue to reproach you. This is not time, Madam, ays Aen, (whoe conceptions were too gros to apprehend the delicacy of her Sentiments) to refue any help, epecially the Aga's, who being Captain of the Guard, can give order for opening us the Gates, when we pleae, without top or examination. What confidence can we repoe, anwers he, in the mot perfidious
of men? No, no, Aen, were it poible for him to be more honet on this occaion, than he was faithful in his love, I will rather dye than make ue of his aitance, after the double Treaon he committed againt me: The very thought of it, adds he with tears, is more cruel than Death. 'Tis true, Madam, ays Beyran, with the mot moving action imaginable: I have deerved death, yet peradventure I am not o guilty as you think me. Don Alphono and Clarice, who betrayed us both, have expiated their Crimes with their Death, and if mine mut be punihed with equal rigor, my life is at your dipoe. You ee me in a Country, Madam, whither nothing but depair on the news of your death, occaioned my coming; for after diligent earch of the way you had taken, having been told you were embarqued for Barcellona, I took the ame road, and arrived at that City, where oon after it was reported, the Veel you embarqued in was cat away, and not one Peron aved. Never was grief equal to mine, every one pittied me; nor had I ecaped death, but that Heaven moved at my tears, reerved
me the happines of eeing you again, to jutifie my elf before you, and not dye in your ill opinion, the thing next the los of you, I was mot of all troubled for. The life I have ince led, hath been full of afflictions ufficient to expiate any Crime, if not committed againt you. Laura took pleaure to hear him, and heartily wihed to find it true. He was not o much to blame as he believed. But the evidence was o apparent againt him, that the very thought of what he had een, made her more angry than ever, o that he commanded him out of her ight, bid him quit the Town, and never ee her more. Poor Beyran being till on his knees, endeavoured with the kindet and mot tender expreions imaginable to pacifie her. Aen, who by this time was ufficiently aured he was the Marquis Hippolito under the name of Beyran, moved with his tears, took his part againt Laura, whom he thought not inflexible, and intreated her to have ome regard to the penitence of o tender a Lover, ready to deliver her out of all her troubles, and free her from Slavery
which he had occaioned; but perhaps without any fault of his, and o againt his will. But Laura more angry than before (at leat in appearance) anwered, he valued not her Slavery, but would chooe rather to return to the Baa, than go away with a man he hated wore than Death. This troubled Aen, but he could not depair to ee the fair Lady yield at lat to the pains and tears of a Lover, though he appear'd unwilling to be overcome by the perwaions of a Friend.
div.l: For anger in a Ladies heart,
Is but hort liv'd, though it may be mart,
Againt their Crimes who have the Art
To pleae;
For thee
No ooner at the Bar appear,
Kneel, igh, look ad, and drop a tear;
But they with eae,
A pardon for the offence obtain,
And are admitted into Grace again:
While the fair Judge, whoe angry brow,
Lowr'd, and look'd terrible but now,
To the poor Lover there below,
Finding her tender heart relent,
Begins her Anger to repent;
Thinks her elf Criminal, that he,
So rigorous to him could be;
Owns her Severity a fault,
And that he may it expiate,
Submits his Prioner to remain,
Bound in her own affections Chain.
div.p:
Laura's heart was of this temper, he thought her elf concerned in honour not to yield too oon. Aen did her no mall pleaure in taking the part of Marques Hippolito, whom we will yet call Beyran. And he was very willing Aen hould have the honour of obtaining from her a pardon for the ungrateful Beyran, if he could plead any thing to jutifie himelf, or extenuate the Treaon he was guilty of, but that would have uhered in a Dicoure too long for the preent conjuncture, and Aen told the Aga, if he had a mind to execute the deign he had told him of, he mut be at the Cape of Carthage before day; for there the Brigandine waited their coming. Beyran anwered, it was impoible to get that
night out of the Catle, the Dey having not above two hours ince had news from the Spies, he maintained about the Baa, that the night before, the Baa entred the Town, whereupon the Dey gave trict order no Peron hould go out or in but by day. Laura and Aen were urprized at the news, and perceived the Baa had been in danger. Beyran eeing Laura a little mollified, was extreamly deirous to improve o happy a beginning by a uitable progres to an intire pacification. But though he aw him much troubled and very penitent, he gave him not the comfort of a kind expreion or look, but againt her inclination forced her elf to appear harh, and act the cruel againt him. Aen, who thought one night at leat neceary to be afforded Laura, to dipoe her elf for an intire Reconciliation; and that being upon the point of executing o hazardous a deign, care hould be had to take their meaures aright, asked the Aga whether he thought it not fit to retire, let being een to come from Laura o late, he might give caue of upition.
The Aga anwered, he need fear nothing, the Dey having given him full power to tay as long as he pleaed. But Laura, who had more reaon to be of Aen's than of the Aga's opinion, who was wholly led by his paion, poke to him, though omewhat againt her will, to withdraw. The Aga ready to obey this order, begged the favour of her to give him hopes at leat, he would pardon him, if he made it appear he was altogether innocent as to the matter of Alphono, and that her hatred of him hould be at an end. She made him no anwer, but her eyes betrayed her heart; and poke clearer in his favour than her voice could have done, Beyran kied one of her hands, which he could not refue him, and left her full of that evenings adventures which found her entertainment. The ret of that night not knowing what to think of Beyran's fortune, whom he believed, turned Turk for depair; at the thought of this, the tears trickled down her Cheeks, and he perceived, that if what he told her was true, of her having been betrayed
by her Maid, and that he had not any hand in Alphono's bae action, as in truth it was carce credible he had, he would love him more than ever, and pardon his being found with the Vice-Queen, though this was a tender point, and not to be remembred without a volley of ighs.

Aen found the Aga's news true, and not able to get out of the Catle, went with him to his apartment, where the pretended Renegado caued a Bed to be provided him, but they pent the whole night in dicoure. Aen you may believe had an itching curioity to hear the tory of Marques Hippolito, having heard Laura's; Aen as oon as they were private, fell into that dicoure. The Aga, who knew how much he wanted Aen's help to plead for him to Laura, was ready to pleaure him with the relation, and having undertood Laura had told him part of what concern'd her, he was willing to acquaint him with what came not to her knowledge, and began thus.

When I arrived at Naples, I found there the Vice-Roys Son, whom I was acquainted with in my younger days, and renew'd our friendhip, etablih'd rather in the conformity of our age, than of our Inclinations: he brought me to Court, and eteemed it neceary a new-comer hould be a little intructed in the paages there, he took the pains to tell me all the principal Intrigues and Affairs of Love, and made me the Confident of his Paion for the fair Eleanor, expecting from the fair friendhip between us, I would, when acquainted with her, do him the bet ervice in my power; I had a ight of her, and by the firt effects of that view, could eaily foreee there was no continuing Alphono's Friend, without becoming his Rival: I was troubled at it, and reproached my elf for my unfaithfulnes; but what ignified that when there was love in the cae? There was no reiting Eleanors charms, and I had intantly taken the reolution to love her, had not the Vice-Queen ued all poible arts to divert me; he expres'd no mall complaiance for me, which I attributed to the friendhip between her Son and me.
But having found me one day in deep meditation, he asked me, whether I would freely acknowledge the caue of my melancholy, if he could gues what it was, and might erve me in the buines? I aur'd her I would; he adds, I was under the Fate of many other unfortunate Lovers, who could not ee Eleanor, without being affected with the excellency of her Beauty. I was trangely urpriz'd, to find a paion carce entertained in my Soul, already known to the Vice-Queen, and could not imagine how he came by the dicovery of a ecret, I had reolved to keep cloe as long as poibly I could: it was not in my power to deny it; the trouble in my face and change of my colour, having given her ufficient evidence, how truly he had gueed. I told her I found my elf too weak to reit the Charms of that beautiful Maid, and was orry only Don Alphono her Son, and my Friend was concern'd: he anwered, that a paion we cannot mater, was not to be complain'd of, nor blam'd, and that her Son could not be o unreaonable, as not to pardon my
falling into a ditemper, himelf had been afflicted with. But he believed, I hould prove as unfortunate as her Son; but to keep her word with me, he would let me ee, my concerns were more dear to her than the Interet of her Son: but I mut not blame her, if her endeavours hould prove ineffectual, which he had too much caue to expect, from the trange and unparallel'd inenibility of that fair Maid, that he would peak for me that very day, and ee what hopes of a favourable reception, and whether he defi'd Love, out of a general averion for Mankind, or a particular digut againt ome of that Sex. The ame time he aigned me Ten a Clock at night, to meet her in the great Walk in the Garden, to receive an account of her Negotiation: I was there to wait for her, and he kept her Aignation. I aw her come with one of her Maids, who was her Confident; and having given her my hand to lead her into a Bower, I went in with her trembling, for fear of having ill News, which I preently apprehended from her Countenance. Poor
Marques, ays he, you have no better fortune than others; this Girls heart is proof to all Eays; and did you but know that ill-favoured decription and curvy character he gave of you, you would oon judge it to no purpoe to apply your elf to her: but I would have you believe, I ay not this to dicourage you, but hould be orry to ee a young Gentleman as you, have qualities worthy the eteem of a fair Lady, hould imploy them, where there is not any hopes to prevail. I had certainly upected this extraordinary condecenion, and goodnes of the Vice-Queen, had not what he aid been agreeable to the report of the whole Court, that the fair Eleanor was the mot inenible peron in the World. I knew well enough, 'twas not any concern he had for the paion of her Son, made her peak as he did; he loved him very little, and the complaiance he had expres'd for me, ecured me on that ide. I might have been o agacious and quick-ighted, as to ee he poke for her elf, and advied me to quit the thoughts of Eleanor, to gain her elf Advantage; but I was o oppret with grief at the News,
that I was utterly incapable of making any reflection: he was a Lady, the mot dexterous and ininuating on Earth, and made o good ue of the power he had over me, that he not only hook the paion I was under, but help'd me to take reolution to rid my elf of it, though with the los of my life. To bring this about, I thought it neceary to find another Beauty to amue my Affections; but where-ever I cat my eyes, in the Court, or out of it, I could dicover nothing capable to make me forget one moment, the Charms of the beautiful Eleanor. The Vice-Queen having after that evening aid nothing to me of it, aw me one morning alone in her Chamber, where her Son had newly left me; he asked me miling, Whether I had taken her advice, and followed her Counels? Madam, anwered I, that cannot be done, without my having equal command over my Affections, as you have over yours; or finding at leat in another Lady, thoe Excellencies I admire in the fair Eleanor. This Dicoure had not pleaed her, could he have thought her elf of the number
of thoe others I mentioned, not comparable to Eleanor. But the good opinion he had of her elf, and the repect due to her quality, contributed to the good contruction he made of my expreions, o that my words gave no offence; but on the contrary, being extreamly glad, no Beauty at Court but Eleanor's pleaed me, he told me miling, She would find me out a Peron, that wanted nothing of what might engage the affections of a gallant man, and that he was very well aur'd, I would not deny it. I gave her a thouand thanks, not doubting in the leat of the good ucces of her choice, but was very unwilling to abue her great goodnes: that as to Eleanor, he had done her pleaure; but that the repect due to her, would not permit me to give away, he hould be at the trouble to find me a Mitres. She told me, he took delight in't; that he was loth any ones Affections hould be lot for want of being engag'd; and that knowing my merit, he would think it a pleaure to erve me, and take care I wanted nothing in her Court.

All this he aid with an air o free, o full of goodnes, it charm'd me: And I had almot anwered, She might without further earch, find in her elf what he promied me elewhere. The truth is, etting aide her Age, he might have pas'd for one of the fairet and bet humoured Women of the Kingdom; but I was not willing to venture o far for fear of micarriage, and was content to wait for a ight of her, he would provide for me. I deired her not to make me languih, being an impatient Lover, and in a condition required preent remedy. She aur'd me, I hould hear from her that day, and that I had no more to do, but prepare my elf to be deeply in Love.

At this we were interrupted by company coming in, which oblig'd me to withdraw. I pent the ret of the morning in muing of what pas'd between us, gueing ometimes he meant one Lady, ometimes another of thoe I knew mot intimate with her, and mot proper for the deign, but could not fix my judgment on any. This gave me ome diquiet and trouble, with an impatient deire to ee the Vice-Queen
again. I made in the afternoon forty journeys to Court, to ee if he had any thing to ay to me; he laughed at my hate, and at length told me, my hour was not yet come, nor the day gone; that I hould go home and have patience, and when the time came, he would end me news. Night came, but no news from the Vice-Queen, which made me believe, he fool'd me; o that I could not forbear returning to the Palace, where I heard he was gone to viit a Lady her Friend. I was o ready to imagine it was the Lady he poke of, that I enquired her name, and where he lived; but could not learn either. The caution he had ued in that particular, fully convinc'd me, he was gone about my buines, and that he made the viit private, that my love might be as ecret; and the Court kept ignorant, how far her complaiance had carried her to erve me.

I return'd in all hate to my Lodging, as aur'd of all this; nor was I much mitaken, for I was carce got thither, but I received from her a Billet, brought me by a Lady attended with two Chairs, and expres'd as follows.

I have done what you deired, and I think, found out the peron you wanted; you will eaily confes I am very much your friend: the ole acknowledgment I expect is, you would not make me a Lyar, having promied the Lady that upon the bare decription I made you of her, you would bring her a heart full of love. See you do it, for it you deceive me in this, I hall never pardon you the fault. You have no more to do but follow her that brings you this Billet without noie or attendance; for you are to come into a place of afety.

Had it come from any other I hould not have gone without a Guard at ditance, but coming from the Vice-Queen, I could not upect danger. All I thought of it was, that being a jovial and pleaant Lady, he had a frollick in her head, and reolved to put on me ome pleaant trick: without more ado, I made me ready to laugh with her in good earnet: I went into one of the Chairs, and followed her who brought the Billet, and was got into the other. They carried us a great way into a private part of the Town, and there et down the Chairs which my Guide ent away, and
we marched a little further, till we came to a houe which made a fair hew; I learnt afterwards it belong'd to a Lady of her Bed-Chamber, her Confident, who indeed was my Guide, and having open'd the door, made me go in without noie: I aw neither lacquey nor light. This urpriz'd me, and made me the more confident, ome frollick intended: I ald not a word but prepar'd, in cae things went not as I could wih, to have my hare of the mirth with them, who came to laugh at my cot. At lat the Lady took me by the hand to lead me up a pair of tairs in the dark, which brought us to a room no lighter then the tairs, and thence into a Chamber where were two Flamboys lighted. It appeared a good room, but what pleaed me mot was, the ight of a fair Lady, who carelely laid on a very rich bed, eemed aleep with her hood over her face. I began to repent my cenure of the Vice-Queen, whom I then thought to have written in good earnet: I ay nothing in this Lady but what pleaed me extreamly, and to peak the truth, it was the ole moment I
may be aid to have forgot the fair Eleaner, ince I loved her. She was in a looe dres, but handom, and rich beyond expreion: I had not een the like at Court, and knew not what to think, the Richnes of the furniture, as well as her dres declaring her to be a Lady of no ordinary quality: but I was very much perplext to gues who he was. I made up to her, and poke; and the amorous impatience I had to know her not permitting the ue of much Ceremony towards the Lady that tayed for me I put my knee to the Ground, and laying Hold on one of her fair hands, which he allowed me to kis; It was but reaon, Madam, aid I, I hould have languihed all this day as I have done, who could not expect this happines, without being put to the pain at leat of longing for it. I looked for an anwer in hopes to know the voice, but he aid not a word. I intreated her to eae me of the pain, he might believe I was in, and that if he reolved not to be een, he would however vouchafe to peak to me, that where I was directed to bring a heart of love, I hoped to
ee a Lady that had Beauty and Wit; that as yet he had only moved my curioity, but if he meant to reach my heart, I mut ee her. As I poke thus, I perceived her laugh, which gave me the boldnes to lift up her hood: She put back my hand, but o weakly, I thought it would not dipleae her to pres a little further: there were but we two in the Room, her Confident having doubtles received Orders to withdraw, and I was ready to put her to the queek, when at lat he threw off her hood. But how was I urpriz'd to ee 'twas the Vice-Queen. Well Sir, ays he, bluhing, will you be content with your good fortune? And will it not be preumption in me to fancy my elf capable to make you forget all other Beauties. I anwered her more like a Gallant then a Lover: he was atisfi'd however, and without ingaging further in the relation of a dicoure, of which you may gues the conequence, I will tell you only that having pent two or three hours in her company, I return'd to my lodging the way I came, and he to the Pallace.

I aw her on the morrow, and our Correpondence held for ome time, but cur'd not my paion. Her Son with whom I had particular as well as general reaons to maintain a fair Correpondence, expret more friendhip for me then I could have wiht: he was not content to make me the Confident of his affection, but imploy'd me to peak for him to the fair Eleanor, expecting more benefit from the Interceion of uch a Friend, than any addrees of his own: I did, and you have doubtles heard from her; he let me undertand, I hould peed better in peaking for my elf then for him, 'twas then I thought my elf the mot unfortunate of men, for believing o eaily what the Vice-Queen had aid to me, whoe conduct convinc'd me ufficiently, how far he concern'd her elf in my buines. I deign'd that moment to abandon her favour, and give my elf up intirely to my firt paion; but to prevent the trouble I might expect from the Vice-Queen, if he knew it, I thought fit to diemble a little, and diingage my elf by degrees without
declaring on the udden for Eleanor. I oberved the bet I could the meaures I had taken, but 'tis a difficult matter to conceal a paion from a jealous and a witty Woman. The Vice-Queen perceived my relape, before I made Eleanor acquainted with it; he punihed my Apotacy with a thouand reproaches, which were econded with tears, and I (the better to manage her) pretended a firm Reingagement to her. But what will not a lighted Lady do? or what more dangerous than a jealous Woman? I was thenceforward more curious of eeing and peaking with the beautiful Eleanor, and avoided the occaions of being found in her company, which the Vice-Queen was by, but all to no purpoe: the Vice-Queen knew all, and o well dicern'd what was true, from what was feigned, that he gueed exactly right of the privatet of my thoughts. One day as I walked with her in the Garden, he told me, we had both lot time to no purpoe, I in forcing my elf againt my Inclination, to pretend continuance of affection
for her, and he in endeavouring to make me love, though againt my will: That he aw well enough what I now did, was but the effect of my civility to a Lady of her quality, who had expret kindnes for me. But 'twas time to put an end to our pain, and to atisfie me he intended it. She aured me, he would no longer oppoe my Inclination, and that I would believe it, upon the Confeion he made me, that I might expect from Eleanor not only a kind reception, but omething of love; yet I put no great confidence in all thee good words, as coming from a party too lyable to upition: But when by an Exces of goodnes he added, that to convince me, he was more my Friend then I could Imagine, he would contribute more then any other to my atisfaction; and procure a Letter from the Vice-Roy to Eleanor's Father, to perwade him to conent I hould have his Daughter I was o tranported with joy, I could not forbear making her very large acknowledgements. She told me, I hould ee by the anwer to that Letter what good
Service he had done me: She did as he promied, and after the Letter he procured from the Vice-Roy, I doubted not of being compleatly happy in few days. The news was confirmed by the beautiful Eleanor, and I had the pleaure to ee her glad of it as I was: nothing troubled me then but the low pace of time. The Vice-Roy had ent an expres to Genes, but the Courier was carce got a Horeback, but I wih'd him return'd: every moment eemed a year by my longing and impatience: the only pleaure I had, was the time I was in Eleanor's company, who aur'd on her part of the ucces of the Vice-Roy's Recommendation, who had great Interet with her Father, and enible of the pain I was in to have the matter confirmed; had not the power to deny my paion the favour of a viit, which I begged I might make her, having ingaged my elf to her with all the promies and oaths, to be expected on uch an occaion from a Lover belov'd. The aignation was made, and her Chamber agreed for the place of Rendezvous. Pardon me, my dear Aen, for
fetching a igh at the remembance of that day, which hould have been a time of love and of joy, but was the mot dimal and unfortunate of my life.

Night was come, and when I thought my elf jut ready to be poes'd of o great a happines, Clarice, who waited on Eleanor in her Chamber, and was her intimate Confident, brought me a Billet, I will hew you, having by good fortune kept it afe to this minute. With that he took out a little Pure from his pocket, and out of the Pure the Billet, which he read to Aen in thee words.

I am heartily orry, my dear Hippolito, I mut fail my aignation. But an unhappy accident I mut not now tell you of, will for a few days retard our happines: you may believe me, as enible of it as you are, but love me as you have done. Love will furnih us with opportunity enough, Adieu.

I had never received a Letter from Eleanor, nor knew her Character; o that it was eaie for Clarice to make me believe that Billet came from her: I asked her what her Mitres ail'd; Nothing, ays he laughing, but that he
is not very well this evening. I fancied I undertood her meaning, and examin'd her no further; but withdrew ufficiently dipleaed with my ill fortune that night, when a Page of the Vice-Queens met me coming down tairs, and told me, his Lady deired to peak with me. In the humour I was in, I could have wih'd a Dipenation from waiting upon her; but not knowing what excue to make being o near her, and fearing he might have omething to tell me from Eleanor, being the common ubject of her dicoure with me, I followed the Page into her Chamber, where I found her expecting my coming: he was at her Toilet, and the Vice-Roy being out of Town, as oon as he aw me, he reproached me for deerting her o: he could of late carce ee me in the croud; that if I would not out of Gallantry, I hould at leat out of civility have afforded her my company, when detitute of other. I was not dipoed for giving her o pleaing an anwer as I would have done another time, however I aid not any thing to dioblige her:
I was melancholy and vext, but o deeply in love, I had a tock of kindnes, and complaiance which abundantly furnihed me with pleaing expreions, which the Vice-Queen did not diapprove of: I had not een her in a better humour; and falling into dicoure, he kept me with her a great part of that night; but he thought me out of humour, and quarrelled with me upon't: I excued my elf, as having at up all the night before at play. Hereupon he invited me to lye on her Bed; I was priviledg'd to be familiar, and without further intreaty made ue of my liberty: for the truth is, I was almot dead for want of leep; within les than two hours I was awak'd on the udden by the light of a Flam-boy, held before my eyes, and the firt object I aw, was Eleanor with a Ponyard in her hand, to take away my life, had not Don Alphono laid hold on her arm, and prevented the troke. Judge you what amazement I was in, I might with ome reaon have upected all this a Dream: But my Rival having eized the Ponyard, to execute what he had hindered Eleanor
to do, had he not done me in her turn the like Service. I thought it high time to take care of my life, and running to my Arms, put my elf in a poture of defence. The Vice-Queen half dead with the fright, came running to part us, but was like to have been kill'd by her Son, who eemed as eager to dipatch her as me: I happily aved her two or three times, and at lat tanding before her, the fury Don Alphono was in, made him run on my Weapon, and kill himelf rather than be killed by me: I aw him fall, which troubled me extreamly, foreeeing the dreadful Conequence of uch a misfortune. I turn'd towards the unhappy Mother, to ask her what he would do, and found her woun away, and lying without motion: I was o much afflicted with the pectacle, I wih'd my elf dead: at lat neceity preing me to withdraw, I entred Eleanor's Chamber, to ee her once more, and dye at her feet, if he deired my life to expiate my fault, but I found her not, and o left the Pallace without any obtacle. My deign was to pas into Sicily, and being in earch of
a Felucca to embark in, found Clarice almot drown'd in tears at the Port. I knew her, and asked whither he went, and what he would have: Ah Sir, aid he, I have been looking for my Mitres, who the Mariners tell me, is embarqued not a quarter of an hour ince for Barcellona. I was trangely urprized at the news, and without further deliberation, took the firt Felucca I met, and Clarice being very willing to go with me in earch of her Mitres, or rather to get away from a Court, where he had reaon to fear the everet extremities, after the diorder lately happen'd, wherein he knew her elf concern'd; I put her aboard, and had the weather o favourable, we hoped to reach Barcellona before Eleanor could be there. I took care to inquire the Name of the Felucca he was embarqued in, and the Maters. I was till then o ditracted and oppres'd with grief and depair, it was not in my power to make any reolution on all thee misfortunes; but being got to Sea, I recollected my elf, and conidered all thoe diaters; but the more I thought on them, the
more was I perplex'd about them. I could not imagine by what accident Don Alphono and Eleanor hould be altogether to urprize me in the Vice-Queens Chamber; unles we had been betray'd, or Don Alphono more in favour with Eleanor than I believed: and if that were o, why hould my Rival prevent my death, as he did, and why did he take her turn too, to ave my life from Alphono, unles both were ambitious of the hour to have killed me. However I mut confes I deerv'd death, and wih I had received it at Eleanor's hand; I hould not then have had the dipleaure of imbrewing my hands in the Blood of a Peron, who had all the reaon in the World to be reveng'd of me.

Clarice was very ill in the Felucca, of the fright he had taken, or ele Sea-ick. I had not een her all the time of the diater at Naples, I told her part of the tory, and found it o much afflicted her; epecially when I acquainted her with the death of Alphono, he grew wore and wore: I asked her everal quetions, which he anwered with a great deal of trouble, pretending
Ignorance, but in uch a manner as gave me caue enough to upect the contrary, and believe he was more concerned in this buines than I was aware of: I was unwilling to pres her in the condition he was in, to reveal the ecret, though I was curious of a dicovery, but hoped to make it, when he hould be a little better.

We arriv'd at Barcellona, but no news of the Bark Eleanor went aboard of: I reolved to have patience a while, as well as the Merchants, who had effects in it of great value: But how careful oever I was of Clarice, he grew wore than at Sea, and all the Phyicians could do for her, prevented not her being reduced to that extremity, they gave her over as deperate; o that finding her elf at deaths door, he ent for me to her Chamber, and having deired to peak with me in private, the ret of the company quitted the Room, and he told me, that Don Alphono having gained her, he did him all the Service he could againt me with her Mitres; and having over-heard part of my lat dicoure with Eleanor, he intantly
acquainted my Rival with it, who tranported with rage and depair, againt a deign o fatal to his Affection, reolved by any means to defeat it, and if poible make advantage of it for himelf. That in order to this, he made her write a Letter, and carry it me, as from her Mitres; that Don Alphono took his time, and his meaures accordingly, having learnt from her the hour, and the manner of my coming to Eleanor's Chamber; that he got in without difficulty: but what pas'd further, he knew not; only ome hours after, hearing the noie of Swords, he ran in, where he found her Mitres all in diorder, packing away; that he would have followed her, but her Mitres begg'd of her to let her go alone. At lat finding the noie increae in the Vice-Queens Chamber, he was frighted, and went towards the Port, where I found her; with that the unhappy Girl with abundance of tears, begged that now at her death, I would pardon her a Crime had cot her her life. She aid no more, but two hours after died: I will not tell you the
different motions of my heart, during the dimal Relation this Wretch made me; but the appearance of Death in her face made me pardon her. As for Don Alphono, I heartily wih'd him alive again, as not ufficiently punihed by one Death for his Treaon; but the Traytors being both in another World, I had no Subject to exercie my Revenge on, unles my ill Fate, againt which I pent my time in fruitles Complaints.

To compleat my miery, News came, the Bark we expected was lot, which was confirmed by Advice from everal Parties. Never man in uch depair as I; I will not tell you the extravagancies it made me run into; it ditracts me to think on't: there was no other remedy to bring me to my elf, but to perwade me the News from Sea were not o ure, but that we had reaon to expect further Confirmation, and that Veels reported cat away, came frequently afe into Port: that the Sea was a large Countrey, and one Veel might be eaily mitaken for another, and that many fell into the hands of the Turks, which
were uppoed to have been wracked, becaue they were not heard of. This gave me but mall comfort; yet I thought I had ome reaon of hope, undertaking a Voyage to viit all the Ports of the Levant, till I hould learn ome certainty of the Felucca I was in earch of.

The Aga having finihed his Story, Aen told him, he was very glad for his ake, that Matters pas'd otherwie than Eleanor believed; that it would be no hard matter to make his peace, when he undertood the Treachery of her Chamber-maid; that he was not to wonder at the Anger he expres'd againt him, for that he knew not any of the Particulars he related to jutifie himelf, but upected him of Intelligence with Don Alphono to betray her. Heavens! is it poible, cries Hippolito, he hould do my Love the injury, to entertain uch a thought of me! had I not loved her as I did, could he fancy me capable of o much baenes? Sir, aid Aen, when there's Evidence againt us, and no Plea in defence for our jutification, we are eaily cat: what could you expect a Lady dihonoured
by the Son, hould have believed of you, whom he found in the Arms of the Mother, but that he acrificed the one to you, that you might leave him the other. Ah! Aen, replies the Aga with a igh, let's talk no more of what's pat; as innocent as I am of the one ide, I mut acknowledge my elf guilty of the other. But let me entreat you to excue and extenuate the fault as much as you can before her; or rather never peak of it, but endeavour only to diabue her, and alter the ill opinion he hath of me, and aure your elf, what-ever Fortune befal me, I will not be ungrateful for the Service you will do me. I believe you have heard from her who I am, and if the condition he is in, or any other Reaon, hath oblig'd her to conceal her Birth, and other things concerning her, that might render her more worthy the zeal you have for her Service, I will atisfie your curioity in every particular. Aen thanked him, and fell a laughing, and anwered, He had known her too long to want Intructions in thoe Particulars, and could give a better account of her Birth and
Family than any Peron what-ever. The Aga, urpriz'd at it, entreated him earnetly to let him undertand, how he being a Turk, hould o long and o particularly know her. Aen told him the Story, and part of what happen'd at Genes.

It was day by that time Aen had done, which put them in mind of taking ome reolution about the deign in hand, and the means to be made ue of, to get Laura out of the Catle without danger. They thought of everal ways, but all appeared full of uncertainty and inconvenience; yet they two could bet do it of any, the one having all the power over Laura's Guards, and the other over the Garrion of the Catle. But all things were o trictly examined by the vigilance of the inferior Officers, whom the Dey (a man as vigilant as fearful) had trictly commanded to be always on Guard, and not permit any to come in, or go out, without taking exact notice of them, that it was abolutely neceary to take right meaures, and till fear the ucces. Aen at length bethought himelf of a Stratagem, the
les ubject to dicovery, as covered under a cloak of Religion, though in truth, apt to tartle a nice Girl as Laura. There was a Souldier of the Catle dead the night afore, to be buried that day; he reolved to lock up the Corps in a Chamber, and carry out Laura on the Bier, as if he had been the Souldier, to be buried in the Church-yard behind the Catle. The Aga was of opinion, there could be no danger in the expedient, but doubted much whether Laura could be induc'd to make ue of it; yet after long conultation, and dicoure of other means, they thought that not only the bet, but the only one they could promie themelves a good deign from. But to prevent the trouble Laura might have upon the apprehenion of Death, or other ad Accident, they agreed not to tell her of the Bier, but propoe carrying her out in a Chair. This being reolved on, Aen, who was to ee her that morning, undertook to perwade her to it, and the Aga in the mean time gave order, the dead Souldier hould not be buried till the Evening. He recommended to Aen, the
care of his Affairs with his Mitres, gave him Clarices Letter to produce in jutification of him; and after a great deal of Civility and Kindnes on both ides, they parted, to meet again at Dinner at Aen's, for fear their long Conferences in the Catle might occaion upicion in the Garrion, being extreamly jealous and mitrutful. Laura, who had carce reted all night for Dreams, which troubled her, was very joyful to ee Aen come o early, to divert her from the thoughts of them. Well, dear Aen, ays he, hall we be once eaed of our Chains? and mut we carry this Traytor along with us? Traytor, Madam, anwers Aen, he is the mot honet and mot paionate of Lovers. Ah! ays he, I foreaw he would corrupt even your fidelity; I know too well the power he hath to gain affection, and had reaon enough to ditrut him. Be not o haty, Madam, replies the Turk, to condemn a man unheard. Why, what ays he, can he offer againt what I have een? Did not I find him with the Vice-Queen? Was it not he that help'd the Traytor Alphono to abue me? No, Madam, I
aure you, anwers Aen, be pleaed to let me tell you, what you know well enough, that he loved you too well, to be capable of an action of that kind; and to clear all your doubts, adds he, hewing her Clarices Letter, Know you that Character? Well, aid he, omewhat urpriz'd, 'tis my Chamber-maids: Read it, replies Aen, and you hall ee who was guilty of the Treaon. Laura read it, and had carce done, when relenting at the Injury done Hippolito, or troubled for the Treachery of a Maid, he had o much confided on; O God of Vengeance, cry'd he with tears, wilt thou leave unpunihed a Wretch o treacherous, and one who hath been the caue of o many diaters? No ure, ays Aen, for he is already dead, if not as her Treaon deerved, yet for grief of having committed it. With that he related to her, what he knew not of the Story of the Marques, and found it not difficult buines to appeae the great wrath he had expres'd againt him, to procure him her general pardon, and obtain her conent for his going along with them. Aen, like a dexterous
Confident, aid not a word of what concerned the Vice-Queen; and Laura, who had no deire to be any more angry with her dear Servant, was not very curious to quetion him on that point: he was content to believe him innocent of one ide, and to be furnihed with a pretence not to hate him; o hard a matter is it to ue ill thoe we love, how criminal oever. Aen then told her of the reolution taken by the Aga and him, to have her carried out in a Chair, and found her dipoed to do what-ever they hould think fit, but with condition there hould be no more danger for them than for her. Aen undertook it, and told her, he had no more to do, but make ready againt the firt Watch, whilt the Aga and he took Orders for other things. Aen went home, where Beyran-Aga, came hortly after, and gave him an account of all he had done. Aen laboured with much diligence and dexterity to ee the Brigandine well tored with Necearies; you may believe, Beyran failed not, as buie as he was, to deire an account of what mot concerned him, the tate
of his Affair with his Mitres. His dear Confident acquainted him with what ucces he had dicharged the Commiion he gave him, which Beyran was o glad of, as it was not in his power to expres his Acknowledgment. All was ready, and Aen had given out the neceary Orders, as well for the Brigandine, as for Hores and Men. The Aga and he went together to the Catle, where the Aga made him a Preent of all the Jewels he had received at everal times from the Dey, and entreated him to accept them not as a atisfaction, but a pledge of the aurance he had given him to be ever his Friend, and erve him on all occaions. Aen, who endeavoured, but in vain, to refue his liberality, would not accept of it, but on condition the Aga would make ue on all occaions of what he had betowed, as till his own, and believe Aen enible, he had not ufficiently obliged him to merit o rich a Preent. They went from the Catle, to make their Court to the Dey; and the hour being come, Aen firt changed Laura's Guards, relieving them by three of
his Servants, whom he was to take with him, that none might be left behind to dicover the Deign, or the Road they hould take. The Aga quickly followed him, longing to ee Laura; he fell down at her feet in uch a Tranport of Joy and Love, it moved her to that tendernes, he could not forbear embracing him. As he raied him from the Ground, they were falling into amorous Dicoure; but Aen told them, it was not a time to dicoure, but to put their Deign in execution, unles they had a mind to ee it micarry; and that when they hould be once out of danger, they hould have leiure enough to ay what they pleaed. Laura and Beyran, who deired nothing more than to ee themelves at liberty, were eaily peruaded to follow his Advice. And the Chair being brought by the Aga's Order, who had hidden the Corps, they wrapt up Laura in a clean Sheet, and without aying a word of the Bier, put her in it, and caued it to be carried out of her Chamber, where having according to the cutom of the Place,
thrown a Carpet over her, one of Aen's men took the Lanthorn, and the other two carried the Bier; Beyran leading the Van, and Aen bringing up the Rear. A Corps is a acred thing among the Turks; nor would any of the Guard have thought of earching the Bier, though neither Beyran nor Aen had been with it. They went to the Church-yard, where having taken Laura out of her Grave, they marched towards the Carthage-gate, which the Aga commanded to be opened, that they might take Hore, which attended them hard by. Laura and the Aga, whom we will hereafter call by their names, could not yet take any pleaure to ee themelves out of the Catle and City, for fear of ill Accidents, but long'd to ee themelves at Sea; however they were glad they got happily o far, in hopes Fortune would in favour of Love, improve that lucky beginning to a uitable end. But this mall Lightning of Joy quickly vanihed, being dah'd out by the cruelty of their Fate; for being arriv'd, where they expected to take Hore, they found by Aen's Servants, the Baa's Sophies had taken them
away. In what perplexity then was this unfortunate Company? they were five or ix Leagues ditant from the Cape of Carthage, where the Brigandine was; they had no time to loe, and knew not what to reolve on, when on the udden they heard the noie of Hores making towards them. Aen hid Eleanor and Hippolito under an old Wall, and advanced with ome of his people towards the Hore-men: They marched apace, and quickly asked, who is there? Aen told them who he was, and by good fortune, found it was Romadan, the Mater of the Gallies, coming from Port-farm with a Guard. He told him, the Baa's Sophies had taken from his people ome Hores he had in readines to go for Cape-Carthage, to ee a Brigandine he was ending out to Sea. Romadan, who knew the repect the Baa had for Aen, was angry for what was done by the Sophies; and to remedy the inconvenience, told Aen, he might take his choice of what Hores he pleaed out of his Troop, and not trouble himelf for his own, they hould be ent him where he pleaed to order.
Aen, glad of the opportunity, accepted his offer; and Romadan taking him aide, told him, The Baa had a deign to come again to him, and by any means to get Laura out of the Catle, and that he would do well in his return from Cape-Carthage, to take the Camp in his way, and endeavour to divert the Baa from o dangerous an Enterprize. Aen having promied it, di-engaged himelf from Romadan as oon as he could; but Romadan would oblige him at parting, with two of his Hore-men, to accompany him, and erve him from the Parties that were abroad, and might et upon him unknown. This put Aen into a little perplexity, but he would not refue the kindnes, for fear of giving caue of upition: And having taken his leave, he advanced towards his company, and acquainted the two Lovers in few words, what fortune he had met with. All mounted, and Eleanor in Boys Cloaths, pas'd for a young Slave of Aen's, the night helping to cover the diguie, they made all the hate poible, Hippolito being till at Eleanor's
elbow, the Mater of the Gallies Hore-men led the Van, to anwer thoe they met; and Aen, as Commander in chief, ometimes on one ide, ometimes on the other, without affecting much to be near Hippolito or Eleanor, by the help of the Hore-men they had free paage; and were everal times aved from being taken and carried before the Baa. At lat being come to the Brigandine, they delivered the Hores to be retor'd to the owners, and having rewarded them well for their pains, Aen ent them back with this Letter to the Baa.

body.p:
Sir, Be not dipleaed with me, for endeavouring the liberty of a Maid, to whoe Family I owe mine: you have often heard me peak of my obligations to my Patron, when I lived among the Chritians; I have met with an occaion to atisfie them in the Peron of his Daughter, being that ame Laura the Dey kept Prioner. Wonder not my gratitude hath prevailed with me, to expoe my life for thoe who aved mine. The Dey perhaps may have as much reaon as you to excue me, but in actions
that honour and reaon inpire, I fear no reproach. Laura was the caue of the difference betwixt you, the Peace will be eaier made now he is gone. Thus doing my duty, I procure the good of my Country, which every honet man wihes, and will certainly thank me for. Adieu, live content, and proper in your deigns, and be o jut as not to condemn

div.p: They intantly hoied ail, and the Weather being favourable, they doubled the Cape, pas'd Port-Farine, and were got a great way to Sea, before the Hore-men could have come to the Baa, whom we will leave foaming with rage and fury againt Aen, and return to the happy company, now beginning to take pleaure in eeing themelves out of danger at leat from Land; for as to the Sea, while you are on it, there is no ecurity againt it.

I told you formerly of the reolution I took, of earching every Creek of the Mediterranean, for the Veel this Lady embarqued in: I did o for even or eight months, in a little Frigat with ix pieces of Ordinance, wherein I was at lat taken by a Veel of Tripoly of no les than thirty Guns, after ix hours Fight, and the los of almot all our men: I was carried to Tripoly, where they preented me to the Baa, who upon the good report they gave of my behaviour in the Fight, ued me very civilly, and having in few days expres'd no mall affection for me, wihed I would turn Turk, and ent me for the purpoe to a famous Cady to be intructed in their Faith: this Mahometan Doctor was a very honet man, and witty; he was the Son of a Renegado, and had les Faith than his Father in what he taught others: he poke very freely to me, and I opened my elf to him, and pray'd him to make the Baa believe I was turn'd Turk; he did o, the Baa believed it on his
word, and expres'd for me more kindnes than ever; but he had a Nephew who was jealous of it, and often quarrelled with me on that core, which might afterwards have produced further inconvenience. The Baa, who had a tender love for this Nephew, foreaw what might follow, and reolved to part us for ome time, till this Nephew were cured of his jealous and tempetuous humour; he ent me with great Preents to the Dey of Tunis, his intimate Friend, recommending me very earnetly and affectionately to him. The Dey within a week after my arrival, made me his Aga: You know Aen, what a ad life I led; but who would have thought, ays he, addreing himelf to Eleanor, I was o near what I earched for, and loved above all the World, yet knew nothing of it; and that my Fate hould make me o happy, when I was jut upon loing you.

The Marques and Eleanor entred into further dicoure of their adventures; and the Maters of the Veel coming to conult Aen, he left them together to go on with their tories.
The wind chopped about, and threatned a Storm, the Veel being mall, they thought it inconvenient to venture further to Sea: They tack'd about, making towards Bierti, intending to ail near the Coat of Barbary, till they hould come over againt Sardinia, that they might cros over (as oon as the weather erved) into the Iles of St. Peter, where they hoped to anchor. This was their reolution, and 'twas well for them they followed it, for the Storm was o great, they were forced to lye at Anchor three or four days among the Rocks on the Coat of Barbary. They were o far from Tunis, they had no caue to fear puruit, being at Anchor in a place where a thouand Veels might have pas'd by without dicovering them in the torm.

The torm at length was pretty well over, and the Brigandine puru'd her Voyage along the Coat of Barbary; meeting by the way everal Creeks, floating Hogheads, and Planks, and other pieces of broken Ships, which they doubted not were cat
away in the lat torm. For two days they cruied along that Sea; they were frequently entertained with thoe lamentable pectacles, and at lat heard the voice of a Man, which they fancied mut have come from a Rock at leat three miles ditant from Land; they preently concluded it was one ecaped out of the late Shipwracks. Eleanor was moved to pity at the cry, and Aen at her requet, turn'd the prow of his Brigandine towards the Rock. The Sea was then calm, and when they got within ome paces of the Rock, they aw a man almot naked, without Hat, without Stockins, without Shoes, o maimed and disfigured, they knew not whether they hould more fear him or pity him. Aen having ordered the Sea-men to ceae rowing, asked him in Moreque, how he came upon that Rock, and what he would have. I am an unfortunate Chritian (anwers he in Italian) and not unknown to you, and if you will take the pains to get foot on land here, you will find what perhaps you are in earch of, but you mut loe no
time, otherwie your help may come too late. Aen amazed to hear him peak o, oberved omething in his Countenance, made him think he had een him elewhere. Eleanor was particularly atonihed at his voice, and fancied he knew it; but the man was o disfigured, he could not poibly call to mind who he was Aen asked him his name, and where he had een him to know him: I tell you, anwers the man, I have here what you perhaps go in earch of much further; the man you ee is Alexander the Baa's Slave, and if he has ent thee for his Wife, thou may't find her on this Rock half dead with her Sufferings thee two days we have been here: he had carce done peaking, but Eleanor invaded at once with joy and grief cry'd out, which made the man turn his face, and he knew him to be Alexander. Ha Sir, ays he, is it poible it hould be you, and not know Laura? As he poke thus, Aen having commanded the Oars to turn the prow to land, ordered a Plank from the Veel to the Rock, and
pas'd over it firt, Hippolito following with Eleanor by the hand, and all to embrace poor Alexander, who was o tranported with joy, he could not ay a word: he pray'd Aen to get him omething from aboard to comfort his dear Sultanes, who had not eat any thing for three days pat. They gave order accordingly, and intantly ran towards the place where the Sultanes lay under a Buh, where they found her half dead; a ad ight for Laura, yet mixt with joy to ee her; but what an atonihing urprize was this to the Sultanes, who could carce open her eyes, and knew not whether he were awake or in a Dream, and whether what appeared to her, were Perons or Spirits. You may imagine the hate Eleanor made to help her, being readily econded with Hippolito's aitance: What are you here Laura, ays the Sultanes with a feeble and languihing tone, and am I not mitaken? what good Angel hath ent thee to recue me from the Jaws of Death? Heavens! my dear Sultanes anwers Laura, not able to
forbear crying, Heavens! which hath had pity on us, and delivered me alo out of the hands of the Baa. The Sultanes began to recover, but had not trength to peak long. Aen told Alexander he would be better aboard than at land, the Sea being till. The Count, who had not yet had leiure to dicoure them, asked where they were bound for, and having undertood they ail'd for Italy, he could not ufficiently bles Heaven for o happy an accident. The Sultanes was carried aboard, and the weather being fair, they reolved to put out to Sea, and divert their coure for Sardinia.

Laura was o careful of the Sultanes, that he began to gather trength; Aen and Hippolito did their part with the Count, who had no les need of nourihment and ret: This took up one day; on the morrow the weather continuing fair, and the Sultanes finding her elf in a condition to dicoure, they related to her what pas'd at Tunis ince her departure, and deired Count Alexander to inform them how they came to be wrack'd, and by what Fortune
they got upon the Rock; he anwered to this purpoe.

You have heard without doubt, how the Sultanes was carried aboard by the Baa's order, who thought (as well as I) it was Laura: You may imagine my urprize great, and my joy inexpreible. At our putting to Sea we had a good wind, but carce pat the Cape of Carthage, but we aw the Heavens cloudy on the udden, and had the wind in our Teeth, and o trong a Gale, that our Veel being mall, and the torm increaing, we were driven on this Coat and cat Anchor; preently a violent and mot terrible Hurricane broke our Cables, et us a-drift, and cat us upon the Rocks. I leave it, to you to gues, what an extremity this was for a Lover, having her he loved above the World ready to be lot before his face, which heightned to the utmot the terrours of danger and death: I tood by the Sultanes, who with grief and fear was already half dead; and reaching out her hand, Dear Alexander, ays he, ince the hour is come we mut dye, let us dye together. Thee words o reolute and
kind, pierced my very heart, and turned me into a Statue, leaving me without ene or motion. All I could do, was embracing my dear Sultanes for a final Adieu, when the Veel giving a great crack, made me turn my eyes towards the Window of my Cabin, where I aw a Rock almot touching the Poop; this urprized me not a little, and taking a uden reolution, I placed the Sultanes on my back, got upon the Deck, and in pite of the Sea-men, who would have diverted me, I leaped on the Rock without doing my elf or the Sultanes harm. A moment after, the Sea which cat the Veel on the Rock, carried it off again, leaving me and the Sultanes there helples of help, unles our Sea-men would pity us, but they could not mater the winds, and the night was far gone, o that no good was to be expected from them till the morrow, if the torm would over. A ad night it was, the poor Sultanes endeavoured to comfort me with hopes the Mariners would not forake us; but what a lamentable pectacle had I at break of day, to ee ome Leagues ditance
half a Ship a float, which by the number of People I aw returning from one end to another to get nearer land, was unk by the greatnes of the waves, and all the men drown'd. What afflicted me mot, was the ight of the Sultanes, though he by I know not what preage, would not depair of good Fortune, but would tell me till, Heaven had not aved us from the Sea, to let us perih on that Rock; but would end to our aid one of the many Veels that pas'd by that way. It was a piece of good Fortune I did not expect, yet I looked contantly about to dicover ome ail, when at lat having almot lot hope, having for two days een nothing on the Sea, I ken'd on the udden omething floating on the water, but being at ditance, and dicovering no ail, I knew not whether to think it a Wrack, or ome mall Veel with Oars; yet eeing you draw towards the Coat, and the nearnes of the objects magnifying them every moment, I knew it to be a Brigandine that brought the Sultanes the News, who was not much pleaed with it, fearing the Veel came from
Tunis, and being more willing to dye on the Rock, than return thither, I hollowed, and cry'd, and had the good luck to be heard by you; and if I did not preently expres that joy which might have been expected upon knowing you, you will pardon it as an effect of the mierable condition I was reduced to, and will eaily believe it could not but be great.

Count Alexander having ended his dicoure, every one poke his thoughts of all thee adventures, mingling ighs with their joy, which increaed at the news of one of Aen's Servants, that he dicerned land, and that it could be no other but Sardinia: He was in the right, but they could not anchor till the morrow; and the weather continuing good, within eight days they arrived at Genes, to the infinite atisfaction of this happy company, and all Eleanor's Friends. Her Father was dead, and thoe who were intruted with the tuition and dipoal of her (if heard of) were eaily induced to conent he hould be married to Marques Hippolito, who found means to make his Peace with the Vice-Roy of
Naples. The Sultanes turn'd Chritian, and Count Alexander married her: Aen followed the example of the Sultanes, and Count Alexander as well as Marques Hippolito erved him with their Credit and Etates, to make his Fortune, and live happily the ret of his days.
